PETITION.TITLE: Australia Card Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled. The petition of the undersigned Australian citizens shows that:
An ID Card numbering system for all Australians would give future governments tremendous power to collect sensitive information and use it against us.

Criminal elements could benefit by forging cards and documents needed to obtain them, or by illegally accessing the data in the system. The dangers are much greater than with current systems such as Medicare, as the Australian Card number could link so many different confidential records.

Your petitioners therefore pray that you will reject the Australia Card Bill.

PETITION.TITLE: Pine Gap Defence Space Research Facility
PETITION.PARA: We, the undersigned, call on the Federal Government to give the required 12 months notice (on or after October 19, 1988 to the United States Government to terminate the lease of the US base at Pine Gap.
We believe that in the interests of world peace and the Australian people, this lease should be terminated and the base closed.
Pine Gap is a nuclear target-it is a danger to Australia's security;
Pine Gap is a ground control station for US Signals Intelligence;
Pine Gap is virtually a US colony in the middle of Australia;
Pine Gap spies on Australian and overseas telephone and telex communications-last year Pine Gap was caught spying on Greece;

Pine Gap is heavily staffed by the US Central Intelligence Agency because it is the single most important US facility in Australia and one of the most important US satellite ground stations in the world;
Pine Gap is situated on Aboriginal land, specifically a sacred dreaming tract;
Pine Gap is an obstacle to the achievement of a nuclear-free and independent Pacific;
Pine Gap helps the US select nuclear targets in the Soviet Union and other countries and as such involves Australia in US nuclear war plans.
PETITION.PRESENTER.BLOCK: by Senators Jenkins (from 2,551 citizens) and Vallentine (from 1,587 citizens).

PETITION.TITLE: Watsonia Army Barracks, Victoria
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate assembled. The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth that:

1. The Watsonia Army Barracks contains a satellite communication dish, that sends to the United States the information, gathered by the ``joint high frequency stations'' in Australia and New Zealand, indicating the position of the Soviet naval ships and submarines.
This information from Watsonia is combined with data from satellites and underwater sensors to calculate the location of the Soviet vessels with great accuracy.

2. This would make it possible for the US nuclear naval ships and submarines to destroy all nuclear Soviet naval ships and submarines, while the US nuclear submarines, naval ships and bombers launch their missiles in a ``first strike'' attack.
3. This makes Watsonia a potential nuclear target. A nuclear attack on Watsonia would have a disastrous effect on Melbourne.
4. The ``joint U.S.-Australian'' bases in Australia endanger rather than protect us. They also add a new menace to nuclear arms race, that must be stopped.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate in Parliament assembled should close the ``Joint Australian-U.S.'' Electronic Communication Facilities in the Watsonia Army Barracks.

PETITION.TITLE: Superannuation Legislation
PETITION.PARA: To the Honourable the President and members of the Senate in Parliament assembled.
The petition of the undersigned respectfully showeth:

That we consider the 2% discounting of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Scheme pension adjustments on 10 Oct. 86 to be a serious breach of trust by the Government. The Commonwealth has reneged on an established commitment as incorporated in Commonwealth legislation and benefit promise pensions are not being paid in full. In particular we resent the long-term effect of the discounting. The pension loss is compounded throughout the life of a pensioner and surviving dependants-into the 21st century for many. We consider this Government-induced penalty to be out of all proportion to the short-term ``extraordinary circumstances of the economy'' given as the reason for the discounting.
Your petitioners most humbly pray that the Senate, in Parliament assembled, should urge the Government to:

1. limit the pension discounting effect of the Superannuation and Other Benefits Legislation Amendment Act 1986 to the period 10 Oct. 86 to 1 July 87 so that pensions are restored to the 9 Oct 86 level as a base for the 1987 pension adjustment; and
2. consult with organisations representing pensioners before changing the terms and conditions of Commonwealth Occupational Superannuation Schemes.
And your petitioners as in duty bound will ever pray.

DEBATE.TITLE: AUSTRALIAN LAND TRANSPORT (FINANCIAL ASSISTANCE) AMENDMENT BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Bill received from the House of Representatives.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

Leave granted.
The speech read as follows-

The purpose of this Bill is to amend the Australian Land Transport (Financial Assistance) Act 1985 to give effect to recent announcements made by the Government on Federal road funding in the May Statement and the 1987 Budget.

In the May Statement the Government announced that 1987-88 payments under the Australian Land Transport Program (ALTP) and the Australian Bicentennial Road Development (ABRD) Program would be maintained at the same level as last year, $1,250 million.

This level of expenditure has been confirmed in the Budget. However, the Treasurer announced in the Budget that $1 million of this amount would be used to offset ALTP administrative costs attributable to the Department of Transport and Communications. The legislation already provides for the States to recover part of their own administrative costs.

To achieve $1,250 million expenditure in 1987-88, the Government has decided to run down Trust Fund balances and adjust that ALTP rate of excise. This Bill reduces from 1 July 1987 the rate of customs duty and excise on petrol and diesel earmarked to the ALTP Trust Fund by 0.723 cents per litre.

It authorises the repayment from the ALTP Trust Fund to the Consolidated Revenue Fund of the revenue generated in the period from 1 July 1987 until the legislation comes into force, by the 0.723 cents per litre adjustment after taking into account subsequent indexation adjustments and interest earned by these funds.

The Bill also provides for administrative expenses incurred by the Department of Transport and Communications in administering the Australian Land Transport Program to be recovered from the ALTP Trust Fund. This will be limited to $1 million in 1987-88 and be achieved by expanding the existing research and road safety component of Trust Fund revenue from 0.618 per cent to 0.752 per cent to include administrative costs and making a compensatory reduction in the National Roads share of revenue.
These amendments in no way change the Government's commitment to the development of a road network which will meet Australia's national economic objectives.

This commitment is clearly demonstrated by our decision to maintain the current road funding level despite difficult economic circumstances and to extend the 2 cents per litre surcharge on fuel currently levied under the ABRD program for five years from 1 January 1989.

The Government's economic agenda clearly focuses on establishing the basis for Australia's long term economic security. An efficient national transport and communications infrastructure is needed to assist in achieving this objective. The Government has clearly indicated that it will give high priority to improving this sector.
Let me now turn to the details of the Bill. Clauses 1 and 2 contain the usual citation and commencement provisions.

Clauses 5, 6 and 7 of the Bill provide for the rate of excise payable to the ALTP Trust Fund to be 3.241 cents per litre from 1 July 1987 by the insertion of section 14b into the Principal Act. This varies by 0.723 cents per litre the rate which would otherwise have applied from 1 July. Provision is also made for the continuation of the indexation provisions to apply to the new relevant rate of 3.241 cents per litre.

Clause 13 of the Bill provides for the revenue generated by the 0.723 cents per litre adjustment, in the period prior to these amendments coming into force, to be paid out of the ALTP Trust Fund to the Consolidated Revenue Fund.

In accordance with the established indexing procedure for the rate of duty of excise on motor spirit and diesel fuel under ALTP, this variation of 0.723 cents will be indexed with the associated revenue to be paid into the Consolidated Revenue Fund in due course.
It also provides for any investment income which may accrue to these monies whilst they are held in the ALTP Trust Fund to likewise be paid to Consolidated Revenue.
Clauses 3 and 4 of the Bill make provision for the declaration of an approved administrative organisation. The Department of Transport and Communications will be declared.
Clause 8 of the Bill enables payments to be made from the ALTP Trust Fund to an approved administrative organisation.

Clause 9 of the Bill includes administration of road programs within the limit of allocations under Section 18 (2). It also increases the percentage share for this category from 0.618 per cent to 0.752 per cent with a compensating adjustment to the National Roads percentage share. There will be no variation to funding for arterial and local roads.
Clause 10 of the Bill provides for payments to an approved administrative organisation on closure of the Fund.
Clause 11 of the Bill provides for the Minister to request that a proposed program be submitted to him for approval from an approved administrative organisation.

Finally, Clause 12 amends the current audit certification requirements for annual statements of expenditure to be provided by the States and approved organisations pursuant to Section 30 of the Act. This is to bring the certification requirements into line with current audit practice.
I commend the Bill to the Senate.

DEBATE.TITLE: OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS BILL 1987INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSIONER BILL 1987INSURANCE AND SUPERANNUATION COMMISSIONER (CONSEQUENTIAL PROVISIONS) BILL 1987

PROCTEXT.PARA: Debate resumed from 7 October, on motion by Senator Tate:
That the Bills be now read a second time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Haines Sen J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987 were before the Senate when the Parliament was dissolved in June this year. They make up a particularly depressing example of what can happen when governments persist in legislating by Press release. On 11 June, on 30 July and, again, on 22 December last year the Treasurer (Mr Keating) announced in Press releases a number of operating standards which superannuation funds and approved deposit funds were going to be required to meet in order to be eligible for relevant taxation concessions. These announcements were made, I admit, following consultations with various interested groups and they were made with the specific purpose of ensuring that superannuation arrangements are directed at meeting genuine retirement needs and also at ensuring that members' entitlements are protected.

SPEECH.PARA: In essence, the standards provide for such things as improved vesting of benefits arising from both employee and employer contributions, improved preservation requirements and measures that will ensure greater member involvement in the control of superannuation funds and improved security of members' benefits. The Bills are supported by the industry, which is particularly anxious that they pass as quickly as possible. After all, it is now well over a year since the first two of the Minister's Press releases were issued.

As I have indicated, the Bills in this package essentially establish not only the grounds for the new standards but also the bureaucracy for the regulation of superannuation funds, and simultaneously alter the administration of the insurance and life office commissions. A new regulatory bureaucracy is to be established by integrating the Commonwealth's various regulatory functions in the insurance, superannuation and actuarial areas by bringing them under the responsibility of a new, single statutory officer-the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.

The major Bill, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, establishes the regulatory structure for the superannuation industry, but does not, itself, establish the guidelines, most of which, as I have said, were announced by the Treasurer and commenced operation on 1 July 1986. However, they still require legislative backing for validation purposes. The Bill also allows for guidelines in the future to be made by regulation.

The Bills are long awaited in practically every sense; they are considerably overdue. At the time they were first before the Senate-that is, in June, prior to Parliament being dissolved for an election-the question of whether the guidelines should be made by regulation was the only concern that we had with the legislation. Since then, we have consulted widely with the industry. The Life Insurance Federation of Australia, indivi-dual companies involved in the industry and the Institute of Actuaries of Australia have gone to considerable lengths to impress upon us the need to get this legislation through quickly. The guidelines announced by Mr Keating on 11 June 1986 commenced operation at the beginning of the following month and, as I have said, they still have no legislative backing.

Often there are good reasons for having delegated legislation; that is, regulating to implement changes in government policy, particularly when it is in response to what can be quite quick changes in the needs of industry. We need to remember that the Senate's powers with regard to regulations are the same as they are with regard to other legislation, as the Government discovered, to its cost, when the regulatory start-ing date of the Australia Card legislation was discovered. As a consequence of that, we were able to indicate that, even if a joint sitting had been held to pass the Australia Card legislation, the Senate was in the position, and was prepared to use its powers, to refuse to establish a starting date. As I said a moment ago, the fact that this Bill is now before the Senate well over 12 months after the Press releases indicating those guidelines came out has illustrated what pitfalls there are in governments persisting in this odd form of legislation.

One of the problems facing the industry is that it is in a considerable state of uncertainty as a result of this. We have had letters from the Institute of Actuaries and we have been contacted by the Australian Mutual Provident Society (AMP) and individuals representing major companies, all of whom want to see that this legislation goes through quickly. They admit that there has been a great deal of effective consultation with the industry. They admit that, in the main, they are happy with the legislation. They are anxious that it not be delayed any further.

The industry itself wants regulations suppor-ting broad legislation. It argues that superannuation is a fast moving area today and that legislation would have grave difficulties keeping pace with the good and frequent changes that it foresees. The Institute of Actuaries expressed, in a quite long letter, its concern that regulations be the mode of operation in the main. It said that there are two main reasons for the Institute's belief that a regulatory approach is appropriate. The first is the range of plan designs and structures, and the second is in regard to pace of change. The letter points out, in part, that the variety of plans in existence is huge and that the task of drafting legislation to set out standards that will satisfactorily address that variety is commensurately large. The letter continues:

There is no doubt that, even with the best advice possible from the industry, some plans that are reasonable per se in all respects, albeit unusual in design, will be subject to unintended effects of any legislated standards. While legislated changes could cope with such problems, clearly it will always be much more difficult to achieve necessary or desirable change in a timely fashion through this route, as opposed to changing regulations.

Of course, we use the regulatory process in many other areas in this place, such as setting up a variety of changes involved in medical benefit schedules and medical practice. On the question of change of pace, the Institute says that it expects that the pace of change will continue to be high for the next few years. It has suggested further changes and hopes that these will occur as the economy and practical realities allow. Other changes no doubt will become desirable in reaction to particular events on the industrial front, particularly in the Australian Conciliation and Arbitration Commission. The Institute said that ordering change by altering regulations is likely to be much more timely than what is possible by legislative change and therefore would be welcomed by most trustees. Therefore, from the Institute's point of view, it is much more appropriate that the proposed occupational superannuation standards be regulated rather than legislated. The former approach would be more likely to allow plans to react in timely fashion to emerging trends and needs.

The Institute believes that the Government's proposed course is appropriate and, to take a fully legislative approach would not be in the best interests of plan members because it would fail to recognise adequately the dynamic nature and wide range of superannuation, and the need to avoid the adverse effects of an inflexible mode of control. So there is considerable support for what the Government is doing. That is hardly surprising, given the amount of consultation that went on. Generally, all parties inside and outside the Parliament welcome the contents of the legislation. By and large this includes the use of regulations, at least as far as the industry is concerned. I repeat that by the same token we deplore the practice of not only legislating by Press release but allowing many months, and in this case well over a year, to elapse before presenting to the Parliament a Bill for debate. In the last couple of weeks we have received a number of letters from people in the industry, indicating increasing agitation in their hearts and minds with regard to these untoward delays. The AMP Society, over the signature of its Manager of Public Affairs, Mr Brown, in its latest letter to us, said in part:
Above all else, we want legislation as soon as is possible.
The Life Insurance Federation of Australia has written to us saying:
I wish to confirm that the . . . Federation . . . believes that it is critical that the above legislation be passed by the Senate without further delay.
It points out quite rightly:
The industry is already experiencing significant difficulties because the legislation is not operative.

That letter appeared over the signature of its Executive Director, David Purchase. On those grounds it is a major responsibility of the Senate to deal expeditiously with this legislation and to accept that the industry wants regulatory control in the way that is planned in this legislation, that the Bills have come forward, albeit somewhat tardily, only following intensive discussions with the industry and that the control is in the best interests of all concerned-the industry and the people who invest. The fact that these delays have occurred has caused considerable concern to all parties. We therefore will be endorsing the requests made by the industry that the Bills have a speedy passage and we will not act to support anything moved in this chamber that is likely to delay that passage.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Parer Sen W.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —When looking at retirement incomes, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987 are some of the most important pieces of legislation to come before this Parliament in recent years. There are, for instance, something over 280,000 funds operating today in Australia. A lot of them are commonly called mum and dad type funds. Superannuation is simply nothing more or less than a contribution by employees and/or employers and self-employed people during their working lives for retirement. There are a number of schemes but basically they fall into two categories. One, of course, is the benefit promised type scheme. This is a scheme whereby, maybe in most cases, employees and employers make contributions into a fund and they are guaranteed a certain return at the end based on the final average salary. Where these schemes exist there is a vested interest by the employers to ensure that the type of investment they make is the best type, otherwise they will find themselves in an unfunded situation and they will have to make up the difference.

SPEECH.PARA: The second type of scheme, which has become more prominent in recent times, particularly with the emergence of the Australian Council of Trade Unions and the trade union movement schemes, is the contribution-type scheme. Under this scheme the return on retirement to an employee who has contributed is simply based on the performance of the investment of those funds. It is of interest to note that in recent days that these people, the employees, would suffer most from the collapse of the share market because the return on the funds would be reduced substantially. There is no way of knowing, until one comes to retirement, just what the pay-out will be under a contribution-type scheme.

The schemes are taxed or are not taxed in various ways and I think it is worth drawing the chamber's attention to these. Contributions by employers are tax deductions but these amounts are taxed when received by the employee as part of a benefit. Contributions by employees are not allowable deductions but are exempt from tax when returned to the employee as part of the benefit. Investment income is not taxed when received by the fund but this income is taxed when passed on to the employee as part of the benefit. Basically, that is a brief summary of the superannuation schemes we have in Australia today.

The legislation, regrettably, is deficient in two major areas. I recognise that, as pointed out by Senator Haines, the industry would like this legislation to go through in the shortest possible time because it has been waiting a long time for it to be brought forward. But it is deficient in two major areas: firstly, it relies for its date of implementation on Press releases, which introduces an element of retrospectivity; secondly, it should contain standards, which is what everyone has been waiting for, but it does not include any standards at all. It is legislation with Claytons standards.

In regard to retrospectivity, I think the attention of the chamber should be drawn to the report of the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills of 27 May 1987. I note, for instance, that Senator Haines is a member of that Committee. The report states:

Although clause 2 provides for the Bill to come into operation on a date to be fixed by Proclamation, clause 4 would apply the Bill, in effect, from 1 July 1986 so that superannuation funds and approved deposit funds would be required to comply with the conditions established by the Bill from that date in order to gain concessional taxation treatment. Sub-clauses 4 (3) and (4) would also permit regulations setting operating standards for funds to be given retrospective effect to a day not earlier than 1 July 1986.
The report goes on to state:

It appears that the basis of this retrospectivity is to be found in press releases which the Treasurer made on 11 June, 30 July and 22 December 1986. Once again the Committee has occasion to draw to the attention of Senators the practice of the Treasurer of treating his press releases as de facto changes to the law by introducing legislation backdated to the day on which he first announced the proposal to change the law.

The practice of `legislation by press release' carries with it the assumption that citizens should arrange their affairs in accordance with announcements made by the Executive rather than in accordance with laws made by Parliament. The Committee questions how persons can be expected to comply with the law when its terms are not publicly available but may only be ascertained from a reading of Ministerial press releases and when the Minister concerned issues further press releases modifying or adding to the terms of the original press release.
No wonder confusion reigns within the industry and it is so enthusiastic to get at least something through. The Committee goes on:
. . . condemns in the strongest terms the practice of `legislation by Press release'.

I think it is worth referring to the list of Press releases surrounding occupational superannuation. On 16 December 1985 the Treasurer (Mr Keating) issued a Press release which was headed `Guidelines for the Implementation of the Proposed Productivity Decision and Draft Operational Standards for Superannuation Schemes'. The basis of that was to point out the payment of the proposed productivity award in the form of superannuation-the famous 3 per cent. Attachment A to that Press release carries guidelines for the implementation of the proposed decision and draft operational standards for superannuation schemes. It has quite a number of pages to it. Attachment B spells out in some detail provisions in relation to vesting, provisions in relation to preservation and portability, the security of benefits, and-I shall come back to that later-in house asset restrictions which have caused a lot of concern among the smaller schemes, because the Government has consistently stated throughout that the assets should be restricted to some 5 per cent of fund assets. This is of concern to the smaller funds which may, for instance, purchase a building which may represent 85 or 90 per cent of the assets. In that Press release it was stated under the heading `Timing of Introduction of Standards':
It is the Government's aim to introduce legislation in respect of certain of the standards in the 1986 Autumn Sittings of Parliament.

In the Press release dated 16 December 1985 it was stated that the intention of the Government was to introduce standards in the autumn of 1986. We are now in the spring of 1987 and still do not have those standards. That is the concern of the Opposition. In June 1986 a further Press release was issued by the Treasurer in relation to operational standards for occupational superannuation funds. The basis of that was that the Government had completed a review of the draft of operational standards against the background of submissions. Attachment 1 outlines the implementation of the so-called operational standards. The Press release also referred to the creation of the new position of the Occupational Superannuation Commissioner, about which we have no problems. It goes on to say:
When fully operational, by mid 1987--

It can, I suppose, be claimed that if it had not been for the election that may have been the case. This goes back to 1985 and we still have no standards whatsoever. Again, this is an example of why we object to legislation by Press release. Part of this Press release states:
All new funds, regardless of size-
and bear in mind this was, to repeat the date, somewhere in June 1986-
are required to inform the Occupational Superannuation Commissioner-
who, I might say, still does not exist-
no later than 1 October 1986, if established between 16 December 1985 and 1 July 1986 and on establishment if established after 1 July 1986.
It goes on, in regard to investment standards:
Investments of superannuation funds are to be directed towards achieving maximum returns to members consistent with the sound management of fund assets.
I do not disagree with that: I think the most important aspect of any superannuation fund is that the trustees have the absolute obligation to do that.

In regard to the Bill, I am concerned about the clause that allows the Commissioner under regulation to decide just how fund assets will be invested. For instance, it is not beyond the bounds of possibility that the Government will decide to issue to the Commissioner an instruction that he should be looking at Australia Reconstructed and that maybe 20 per cent of all funds should be offered as soft loans to people who get the nod of approval from the Australian Council of Trade Unions. The Press release continued:

The placing of a general limit (say 5 per cent) on the assets of a fund which may be invested in any single company, asset or person, will be given further consideration in consultation with relevant interest groups.

We still do not know where that stands. The Press release then referred to the details regarding the Occupational Superannuation Commissioner. Again, we had another Press release from Mr Keating on 22 December 1986, which was headed:
Operational standards for occupational superannuation funds, and tax deductibility of superannuation contributions by unsupported employees.

It referred to the tax deductibility of super-annuation payments by unsupported employees in 23fb type funds. As I mentioned earlier, our great concern is with legislation by Press release. We have seen this undertaken ad nauseam in many other areas but particularly in the taxation area. We now see it in the superannuation area. The problem arises from not having standards spelt out even in the Bill. I think it is worth referring to a Press release put out by the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia Ltd (ASFA) just last week. The President of that Association, Mr Alan Hauserman, made very clear in that Press release the concerns expressed by the Association at its national conference. The Press release stated:

Mr Hauserman restated the Association's opposition to the process of `Legislation by Press Release' which bypasses the Parliamentary process. Press releases are not detailed enough to clarify the action required to comply with proposed standards.
It continued:

Mr Hauserman also voiced ASFA's concern that the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill in its present form gives the Government almost unlimited powers to make regulations affecting superannuation funds.
The Press release stated that Mr Hauserman believes:
the Bill should be modified to define the regulatory powers of the Government more precisely.
It continued:
. . . also urges the Government to release forthwith the draft Regulations, so that these can be considered by Parliament and the public in conjunction with the Bill.

That same conference was addressed by Mr Ray Stevens, a Director of Mercer Campbell Cook and Knight. This company is probably one of the most prestigious consultants and actuaries in the field of superannuation. Mr Stevens stated:

Instead of the last two years being the best in history for our retirement income provision, they have probably been the most disastrous on record for those of us dedicated to efficient and adequate superannuation for the community. Fund administrators and their advisers have never been so busy, but they have been mostly running around in circles with little to show for all the activity. Members of funds have probably never been so confused.
He continued:

The reason is . . . ham-fisted Government interference . . . the Government needed to maintain an image of promoting wage restraint. On the other hand the Government and the ACTU needed a wage increase or a substitute for a wage increase to maintain their accord. The result was the productivity deal-a deal on superannuation involving two parties which knew very little about superannuation.
They were caught like the meat in the sandwich. Regrettably, so were the members of the funds. He pointed out:

The productivity deal was without logic, first because it sought to require employers to provide extra superannuation benefits regardless of the level of benefits already provided, and second because it imposed restrictions on the extra benefits which made it difficult to integrate them with existing benefits.
Out of this disaster came the Occupational Superannuation Commissioner's Interim Group, or-
as Mr Stevens called it-
the birth of the Octopus.
He referred to the Treasurer's actions and his approach to superannuation as akin to those of a drunken duck shooter. He continued:
Hastily conceived ideas have been introduced with immediate effect by the issue of hastily drafted press releases.
I referred to those earlier. He continued:

. . . the delay in giving the Group proper legal status means it has had to operate for an unacceptably long period without staff who have superannuation experience. Both Government and the industry . . . accept that if formal establishment of a Commissioner's office proceeds the key personnel will have to be recruited or seconded from the private sector. Until this happens the lack of appropriate knowledge and experience will continue to create confusion and frustration.

Mr Stevens made a point of referring to the lack of communication abilities of people within the Interim Group. As an example he takes an extract from the Interim Group's information circular No. 2, which states:

To the extent that entitlements to benefits (including withdrawal benefits) are normally calculated by the fund on the basis of an employee's contributions, `employee-financed benefits' refers to those contributions accumulated with interest at a rate appropriate to the net earnings of the fund.

Just after that circular came out, Mercer Campbell Cook and Knight was asked to write an article which included an explanation of what this meant. The company checked with the Interim Group, which confirmed that the meaning was the same as it had given to the company when an ASFA delegation discussed the draft of the circular. After the magazine had gone to the printers the company was embarrassed to learn that the Interim Group had changed its mind. However, by good fortune the Interim Group changed it back to the original meaning by the time the magazine was released. Mr Stevens stated:
To me the most annoying aspect is not their lack of ability in English expression, but their failure to alter the draft after its shortcomings had been pointed out.

He stated that it would be disturbing to think what would happen if sections such as that ever became the basis for a dispute in the courts. Another problem raised by Mercer Campbell Cook and Knight arises out of the self-assessment process. The Interim Group in its information circulars emphasises that these are provided only as guidance for trustees. It states:
The onus is on trustees to ensure that their schemes comply with the preservation standards.
Mr Stevens stated that there have been:
particular cases where the Interim Group has not even be prepared to follow its own guidelines.
One can imagine this unsatisfactory and confusing situation. Mr Stevens continued:

Where the Interim Group's interpretation of a Press Release differs from that of the trustees, can the trustees act on their interpretation and be confident this will not lead to problems with the Tax Office?

In addition we have situations where the Interim Group has changed its mind on the meaning of a Press Release, sometimes more than once. On what basis do trustees certify that they have complied with all relevant requirements during that period?

The intervention by the Government in the trustee arrangements is also something I would like to address. According to the actuaries and consultants with whom I have spoken, it is just not possible to set down a single arrangement which is suitable for every type of fund and every industry situation. The initial Press release from the Interim Group attempted to lay down two arrangements. It did so in one paragraph of 11 lines. Subsequent Press releases and information circulars devoted nearly five pages to clarification of the original statement of 11 lines. There have been discussions with the Interim Group by the people in the industry. But at no stage has anyone in the Government or the group stopped to ask whether all this was really necessary.

The Treasurer (Mr Keating) kicked off his second reading speech-and again I think this is relevant-by stating that in his Press releases of 11 June, 30 July and 22 September 1986 he announced various operating standards which superannuation funds and approved deposit funds will be required to meet in order to be eligible for relevant taxation concessions. Having done that, one would have expected that we would have seen the standards in this legislation. But we have not seen the standards. I must say that I am concerned that Senator Haines has stated that she is not prepared to support any moves by anyone that might enable this Bill to be looked at fairly carefully to ensure that when it is passed, it will be passed in a fashion that will be workable.

In summary, I would like to point out the problems we had with these Bills. Firstly, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill allows the government of the day, whatever government that may be, unlimited power to make regulations on any aspect of superannuation without prior notice being given to the community and without prior reference to Parliament. It appears that there is an error in clause 16 (4) of the Bill in that line 37 states that the Commissioner is `deemed to have confirmed the decision'. Under the present draft, the Commissioner is `deemed to have confirmed the decision'. Under the present draft, the Commissioner is deemed to have confirmed a decision to revoke a fund's tax status if he does not respond within 21 days of a request for review. This alteration gives the Commissioner more time to respond, but treats a lack of action as revocation of earlier decisions rather than confirmation. Therefore, lack of action is treated as revocation of an earlier decision rather than confirmation of a decision. So, simply, there is an error in that clause.

While the responsible use of regulations in a complex and changing area like superannuation is appropriate-no one objects to that-the history of this Government's approach has been anything but responsible. That is a major concern for the industry. Press releases have announced major changes with immediate effect. Any consultation with experts in the field has taken place after, not before, the announcements. The only body that appears to have been consulted prior to each announcement is the Australian Council of Trade Unions which has only recently taken any interest in superannuation and could hardly be considered as experts.

TALK.START.PARA: —Experts in tax avoidance.

—Thank you, Senator Stone. In fact, as the honourable senator knows, in discussions we had only last week or the week before in this place, we saw the Government aiding and abetting the very tax avoidance systems in respect of which it was so very critical of so many others. Our aim is to ensure that this Government properly considers and develops its proposals before they are implemented, that Parliament is consulted instead of being bypassed and that the community has notice of the Government's intention to change the rules in a major way.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Watson Sen J.O.W.

TALK.START.PARA: —The Senate has before it a package of three Government Bills which we are debating cognately. They are the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987. Although these three Bills supposedly represent the fruit of nearly four years of investigation and consultation by the Government, they are really no more than a very broad framework of the Government's intentions. Unfortunately, within this framework there are genuine causes for concern. In a recent Press release my colleague Senator Stone reminded us of some of these concerns. He said in that Press release:

SPEECH.PARA: The legislation will fundamentally and profoundly affect the future development of the occupational superannuation industry in this country, as well as the civil rights and the financial interests both of the fund trustees and of the enormous body of fund contributors.
He went on to say:

Yet, it does not even attempt to set out the basic principles and standards on which that vast array of regulatory powers and authority it would confer on the Treasurer and the new Commissioner would be based.

They are strong words indeed. But the facts are that this framework, this bits and pieces legislation and the matters that are before us today are vague. They are incomplete in their content and, regrettably, they rely far too heavily on regulations for substance. In fact, we have a standards Bill before the Senate today and we are being asked to consider the standards which it purports to set out. But this chamber is abrogating its legislative responsibility be leaving the setting of those standards to the bureaucrats by way of regulation.

Superannuation really should be of a long term nature because it affects people's security and contracts span many years. Therefore, there is no room for uncertainty in this Bill. The broad thrust of standards that will apply to superannuation funds should have a permanency about them and be enshrined in legislation as such. I submit to the Senate that these standards should not be subject to the dictates of the day to day whims of bureaucrats or even the temporary aspirations of indulgent Treasurers. I believe that all honourable senators should agree with me when I say that superannuation schemes are a very important component of the financial affairs of most Australians and they should be treated as such by this Government and by this Parliament. I think it is disgraceful that the Australian Democrats have walked away from this responsibility in this chamber today.

There is an obvious need for superannuation, for its proper funding and for adequate safeguards to protect those who are insured. For too long, unfortunately, governments have not adequately planned funding for social security pensions. Government benefits for the aged and for infirm retirees have largely been met from Commonwealth taxation. However, given the aging nature of the population, there is a limitation to the capacity of governments and young taxpayers to continue meeting such a growing commitment. Increasingly, the amounts that aged pensioners receive from government are found to be inadequate to meet their everyday needs and commitments. In fact, a person's retirement pension should be funded over the whole of his life. This is a fundamental principle that we have ignored for too long. Superannuation schemes must be encouraged. But they must also have the confidence of the investors. For these reasons, the legislation concerning the operation of superannuation funds really should be explicit. The contributors must have confidence that the conditions attaching to these funds will not change over the period during which these people will be associated with a fund. Yet, what has this Government done? It had done nothing concrete to enshrine this security until it presented to the Senate this very inadequate piece of legislation, despite the fact that the report of the task force investigating the matter was tabled in the Parliament in 1983.

Let me comment briefly on the bad phenomenon of what we call `legislation by Press release'. In line with the habit of the Treasurer (Mr Keating) of late to dole out proposed legislation piecemeal through the Press, we have seen three separate Press releases relating to this legislation since December last year.

TALK.START.PARA: —Each one correcting the mistake of its predecessors.

—As Senator Stone reminds me, each one correcting the mistake of its predecessors. How can the industry have confidence? It is no wonder that the interim groups keep changing their mind as to rules affecting funds. How can the public and fund managers be expected to comply with the law, especially in this complex area of superannuation and taxation, when it seems that the legislation is not yet publicly available, has not been mentioned in the Parliament, and information can be gleaned only by monitoring ministerial Press releases or by carefully reading certain technical newsletters?

SPEECH.PARA: The Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills on more than one occasion has criticised the Treasurer's practice of treating his Press releases as de facto changes to law. The Committee has condemned this practice. Members of this chamber-the Australian Democrats, the Australian Labor Party, the Liberal Party of Australia and the National Party of Australia-all agree that the practice of legislation by Press release is bad and carries with it the assumption that citizens should arrange their affairs in accordance with announcements made by the Executive rather than in accordance with the laws made by Parliament. The Government has been condemned by its own senators and by this chamber.

The legislation also introduces the concept of retrospectivity. As a consequence of this legislation by Press release, the Bills will, in effect, involve retrospective taxation. While clause 2 of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill provides for the Bill to come into operation on a date set by proclamation, according to Treasurer Keating's announcement it will take effect from 1 July 1986. Who are we to believe? The Government should stand condemned for the confusion in the public mind that surrounds the application of these Bills. I believe that the emphasis on regulation is far too great. Perhaps the most disturbing aspect of this package of Bills is the great emphasis it places on regulation as opposed to legislation. In other words, the bureaucrats will decide what they believe to be best for the industry, rather than this fully informed Parliament legislating on the matter. I submit that we are abrogating our responsibility as a parliament. We are walking away from our responsibilities, not only to the contributors, but to the people of Australia. This practice is happening all too often.

Clause 7 of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill outlines an extensive list of operating standards for superannuation funds that will be subject to regulation. I submit that clause 7 should contain the detailed operating standards written into the clause. Why are they not there? The clause should provide for this, but the Government has walked away from that responsibility. It is a disgrace on the part of the Government, and it does not help the superannuation industry. Governments used to follow this practice. If one looks at section 23f of the Income Tax Assessment Act one will see that there are a lot of definitions and requirements to be met. But this standards Bill does not contain any definite standards. It will be left to the bureaucrats in future to determine, at their whim, what they feel the regulations should be, on a day to day, ad hoc basis. There will be regulations regarding the disclosure of information to members. That is fair enough. I submit that these issues are so important that they should be enshrined in a concrete fashion in this legislation.

Clause 8 outlines the regulations that will apply to approved deposit funds. Approved deposit funds are currently in a sort of no-man's area because they are new and fairly novel. There has been no legislation until now to govern the operation of these approved deposit funds. It is true that the industry is saying, `Yes, we want some guidance from government. We want some legislation'. But the Democrats say, `Well give them any sort of legislation, just so that we can say we have passed occupational superannuation legislation'. In the process they are saying, `We'll let not only the details but also the principles be determined by bureaucrats'. Let me remind the Senate of the open-ended nature of this legislation, because the funds themselves have to pay an open-ended cost for this bureaucratic service which is being imposed by Government.

We are reliably told that these regulations have almost been drafted and are almost complete. If they have been drafted, why are these standards not incorporated in this Bill? Why have they not, preferably, been included in the Bill as legislation? The Government does not have the decency to submit the regulations with the Bill which is before us today. The Government stands condemned in two areas: it has not included the standards in the legislation as such, and it has not submitted them as a separate part of the legislation. What is the Government afraid of? What does it have to hide? This extensive use of delegated legislation is such a disturbing trend that this Parliament should make a stand to prevent its extension. As duly elected senators and members of parliament, we should be wary of abrogating too much of our responsibility, a responsibility that the Australian people have given to us. Having been given that responsibility, we are walking away from it and placing that responsibility in the hands of bureaucrats. As my colleague Senator Parer said, some of these people in the Interim Group keep changing their minds as to what they want from the industry.

While delegated legislation is appropriate under some circumstances, many of the issues that are the subject of regulation in this package of Bills could be, and should be, more appropriately addressed by this Parliament and should be the subject of debate in this chamber. I acknowledge that, for some reason, the President of the Institute of Actuaries of Australia has, in the past, supported this line or regulation. I am surprised that no government member has said that.

TALK.START.PARA: —Their President does.

—We know that the President does, but if one rings members of the industry, one will find that they express some surprise about this approach. It is certainly not a unanimous view. I wonder whether this decision was made at a meeting of a fully constituted council, because the Government certainly picked this up and said, `Because of this, we are legislating in this particular way'. I have not found, in my extensive involvement with superannuation funds, anyone who is not concerned about this over regulatory approach.

SPEECH.PARA: Superannuation funds have all too often been the vehicle for tax avoidance. If one leaves things to regulation, obviously one leaves open the opportunity for a wide variety of schemes to be put forward. It is rather strange to see a reduction in the Tax Commissioner's powers, given the fact that superannuation funds have been vehicles for tax avoidance and that, in other areas of legislation, the Government is actually strengthening the role of the Commissioner of Taxation. For some reason this Bill will take powers away from the Commissioner of Taxation. In fact, all the non-taxing areas will be taken away from the Tax Commissioner. Responsibility for the conditions relating to these funds will be handed over to the new Insurance Commissioner. In fact I can see a situation where there will be a conflict between what the Taxation Commissioner wants of funds by way of conditions in future and what the Insurance Commissioner deems best. Who will be stuck in the middle? It will be the trustees of the insurance funds. This is an awful situation in which to place insurance fund trustees. In other words, the situation could arise increasingly where there is conflict between what the Commissioner of Insurance wants and what the Taxation Commissioner wants. Given the draconian cost that can be attached by a Commissioner of Taxation to non-compliance, I warn the insurance industry to watch out. The overseeing and supervisory role of the Commissioner of Taxation is being taken away in respect of the non-revenue requirements. Therefore, I submit that the attempts to consolidate the powers of the Commissioner of Taxation in some areas are being reversed in this superannuation legislation.

As for the powers of the Insurance Commissioner, it is my belief that the great discretionary powers reserved in him are far too large. As an example, I draw the attention of the Senate to clause 13 of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill. This clause allows for special circumstances in which funds may be excused from meeting all conditions of operation. This is an extraordinary provision. Are they going to have different standards for trade union superannuation funds as opposed to employer-type funds? The Commissioner has got that power. He is an officer of the Government and can be directed. It is disgraceful that one can have different standards where the Commissioner has this discretion to excuse funds from meeting all requirements. There is no excuse under the conditions of the taxation legislation, so why should this discretionary power be given to the new Commissioner of Insurance to allow him to allow some funds or classes of funds the opportunity of being excused from meeting all the conditions? This is abhorrent. The question is this: are operating standards to be adhered to or are they not? If we go to the trouble of creating legislation which can then be overridden at the discretion of this new Commissioner for Insurance, surely this gives him far too much power. It is a dangerous precedent and we should not allow it to get off the ground in this or any other Bill before Parliament.

I must mention the incomplete nature of the Bill. The problem with this package of Bills does not stop with the list I have mentioned. Not only do they lack substance and abrogate too much responsibility, but the fundamentals of the Bills are quite unclear. The Scrutiny of Bills Committee has had cause to criticise the Bill for lack of detail. Senator Haines agreed to that principle as a member of that Committee, but this morning she said that she would not agree to our amendment to refer this to a Senate select committee so that it can investigate and report on those aspects which are unclear. What does she want? She wants two bob each way-a big name for herself on the Scrutiny of Bills Committee and then to line up with the Government to allow this package a safe passage because the Government and the so-called industry want this Bill. I submit that they do not want the Bill in this incomplete form.

Clause 3 of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill was given particular attention. The definitions of two vital terms, `approved trustee' and `approved rules', rely on regulations, the details of which have not been disclosed to the Senate for a full explanation. How disgraceful! The Committee said that the vagueness of these definitions contrasted markedly with the corresponding definition of the Income Tax Assessment Act. I would like to take the Senate through a comparison, but we do not have the time. Why has the Government been so long in considering the content of the Bills but then presented them in such a vague and incomplete form? The vagueness of these Bills leaves them wide open to manipulation. There is a danger that the vagueness of these Bills opens the possibility of manipulation and, given the enormous amount of money held in superannuation funds, it is only right for us to expect adequate protection to be afforded to these investors.

The framework of clause 7 of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill does not satisfy me, because fundamental safeguards are required. My colleagues in the House of Representatives were of the view that protection was needed against coercive tactics by powerful trade unions, and this opens up another area of potential criticism. In his second reading speech, the Minister told us:
In developing this legislation, the Government has been anxious to establish a regulatory system incorporating the principles of self-assessment.

What does that mean? The whole onus will be on the trustees to ensure that the funds satisfy the operating standards. I question whether this principle is a good one to apply to the standards required for funds that control such huge amounts of money, money which is essentially earmarked for people's future retirement benefit. The Government's primary objective should be to ensure the security of investments that are held on behalf of people through trustees, to ensure that they are kept going to protect them in their latter years.

Another fundamental issue is the independence of the Commonwealth Actuary, and I believe that his office is under threat. It is important that we should make this point in the Senate chamber. The independence of the Commonwealth Actuary is threatened by the provisions in the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill. The reason is that the office of the Commonwealth Actuary is to be brought under the control of a new Insurance Commissioner. I submit that the effect of this would be similar to placing the office of the Commonwealth Auditor-General under the Department of Finance, because he will lose his independence. This is a major criticism. Given his widespread responsibilities, Parliament should not allow this, and the select committee I am proposing should investigate this matter.

What about the financial burden? As a final point, I would like to note that there has been quite a lot of disagreement at industry level as to whether the costs associated with superannuation funds should be borne by the industry, as the Government proposes. It has been estimated that the total industry contribution initially was about $6m, but it is the open-ended nature of the cost of having to service this bureaucracy that is open to question. I would suggest to the Government that it is no less bound to produce an effective form of legislation by virtue of the fact that the money to finance the proposal comes from outside the Government coffers.

Because of all these deficiencies, and the vagueness and inconsistencies and the need to protect the future investments of millions of Australians, the Senate should send these Bills off to a committee. It has taken the Government almost four years to get to this current unsatisfactory situation and, despite the cry from the industry for some legislation to support the plethora of Press releases, this legislation has to go to a committee for review. I deplore the fact that there is not one Democrat senator in this place to listen to the debate, given the importance of this legislation to the people of Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —And their total hypocrisy about suspending civil liberties.

—I agree, Senator Stone. The scrutiny by a Senate committee will enable a wide range of input both from the industry and those who will be affected by this legislation. It can then report in an informed manner to the Senate on a matter of great national importance. On behalf of the Opposition, I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out all words after ``That'', insert:

``(1) Notwithstanding its recognition of the desirability of legislation being introduced expeditiously to regulate occupational superannuation in Australia, the Senate notes that the proposed legislation makes undue use of delegated legislation to achieve its objectives and notes further that this is contrary to its longstanding objection to making the rights and liberties of Australian citizens, including their right to join union superannuation funds or any other funds of their choice, unduly dependent upon action which an executive body may or may not take, at its discretion.

(2) The Bills be referred to a select committee, to be called the Select Committee on Occupational Superannuation, for inquiry and report, without limiting the generality of the reference, on the following matters:
(a) whether the legislation adequately sets out objective principles, standards and rules governing the use of regulations, particularly as they might affect-
the investment powers of fund trustees,
the degree of direction or limitation provided by the legislation, and the
longstanding principles in respect of retrospectivity;
(b) the practicality and appropriateness of the provisions set out in the legislation for review of decisions of the Commissioner;
(c) the extent to which the legislation derogates from the proper authority of Parliament by placing undue reliance upon regulations.
(3) The Committee report on or before 17 November 1987.
(4) The provisions relating to the membership, powers and procedures of the Committee be contained in a subsequent resolution.''.

If that amendment is successful, I will move subsequently a motion relating to the composition and membership of that committee. I believe it is important that the Senate agree to this amendment. I think it is significant that there will not be an undue delay. The committee is to report by 17 November. It has taken four years to get to this unsatisfactory state. What is happening to some of the funds at present because of the tremendous crash on the stock exchange is another reason why we have to take care and why this has to be done properly. I appeal to all honourable senators to support this amendment and the foreshadowed motion.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise on behalf of the Opposition to support and second the amendment moved by Senator Watson.
—We did away with seconding about four years ago.

—I thank Senator Ray for his advice. The amendment seeks to refer the package of Bills before the Senate-the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987-to a Senate select committee for examination and report within a period of no more than four weeks-by 17 November.

SPEECH.PARA: The Bills that we are debating are very important Bills indeed. They relate to fundamental changes proposed in the administration and organisation of the superannuation industry. The main Bill is the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, the purpose of which is to establish the conditions and the supervisory requirements which superannuation funds and approved deposit funds (ADFs) must meet in order to be eligible for concessional taxation treatment under the Income Tax Assessment Act. The Bill provides for these supervisory functions to be performed by a newly-created office-the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner. There are accompanying Bills to establish the office of Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner.

As I said, this is a very important matter indeed. The superannuation industry is a huge industry. It is an industry that is vital to every Australian. The vast majority of Australians-this is becoming increasingly so as the years go by-are reliant and dependent on superannuation for their income support in their retirement years. Therefore, what we are debating today really touches every Australian. It is absolutely essential that what this Parliament does in the area of superannuation be subject to the most careful scrutiny on behalf of the people of Australia-the superannuation contributors, the future superannuants, and the existing superannuants of this nation.

In the last 24 or 48 hours we have seen gyrations on the stock markets of the world which have important implications for superannuation funds, as Senator Watson just mentioned, because of the investment that superannuation funds have in the stock market. If nothing else, the events of the last 48 hours should have alerted us to the need for the most careful scrutiny of any matters pertaining to the superannuation institutions and, for that matter, to other financial institutions in this country.

This legislation has been a long time coming about, particularly given the size of the industry, to which I have referred in some degree. To give an idea of the size of the industry, a report released just last week by the Association of Superannuation Funds of Australia Ltd showed-this only takes us to 1985-that the Australian superannuation industry now controls over $50 billion in funds. That is an enormous amount of money. In the past two years that figure has grown significantly following the introduction of many new types of superannuation schemes and the increasing involvement of industry and union superannuation schemes which, in turn, have attracted thousands of new contributors. We are talking about an industry which has something like 280,000 individual superannuation funds. We are not talking about small beer; we are talking about something that is fundamental to the investment climate and to the standard of living of every Australian.

One extraordinary aspect of the present situation is, as I said, that the matter has been so long coming to the Parliament. Of even more concern is the fact that the legislation that we are now looking at is legislation which eventually struggled into the Parliament after almost 18 months of government by a series of Press releases by the Government. Press releases were put out purporting to define what the new legislation and the new rules were going to be, each subsequent Press release differing from the one before. The legislation that we are looking at now is, in turn, different from that.

As Senator Stone said when opening this debate on behalf of the Opposition last week-other speakers have referred to it today, particularly Senator Parer and Senator Watson-the confusion surrounding the legislation because of the process of attempted government by Press release is a matter of very great concern. But it goes further than that. It goes to the whole basis of what parliament is all about. What we are seeing here is a government that is increasingly, through its arrogance and its abrogation of the role of the proper parliamentary process, bypassing the Parliament and bypassing the elected representatives of the people of Australia by dictating and directing Government actions outside this Parliament. I think I am right in saying that most of the Press releases that were put out on this subject in the last 18 months were put out when the Parliament was sitting. Despite the fact that the Parliament was sitting it was ignored by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) who, by acting in this way, really just confirms the arrogance that he has displayed in virtually every action that he has taken as Treasurer of this country. It is an arrogance that the Australian people are becoming increasingly to resent and to be extraordinarily angry about. So we have a first major difficulty in the fact that the legislation has come about as a result of vague, waffling Press releases over a lengthy period, and that has bred a lot of confusion.

The second main issue of great concern to the Opposition is that the main purpose of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill is to allow for the prescribing, by means of regulations, of operating standards for compliance by superannuation funds and ADFs in order to be eligible for the relevant taxation concessions under the Income Tax Assessment Act. What that means is that the Government proposes to set the standards for this industry outside the ambit of the Parliament. Far from this Bill being an occupational superannuation standards Bill, as its name purports, there is not a standard in it. That is the Opposition's basic objection to this Bill. We support the need for change and improvement in the superannuation industry. Let there be no doubt at all about that. We agree with the Government that changes need to be made. The end objectives of the Government and the coalition in this matter are broadly bipartisan.

Where we differ very widely from the Government is the means of achieving these objectives. It may be that, in the end, the means that the Government proposes are means with which we could agree, but our problem is that we do not know the means because the Government has not set out the standards; that is, the means to achieve this end result. That is a quite extraordinary way of going about legislation, of going about effective and responsible government. Government by delegated legislation, which is what we are really talking about in this Bill, is an abrogation of government; it is an abrogation and a bypassing of the parliamentary process. Apart from anything else, I believe that that provides grounds for very great concern and strong opposition to the way in which the Government is going about this matter.

As I have said, the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill relates to a fundamentally important industry. Therefore, there is a need for considerable care in looking at the details. As I have said, the basic standards are not there. Even the Bill itself gives some very considerable grounds for concern. For example, clause 22 of the Bill-this is the point to which I have been referring-enables the Governor-General to prescribe regulations from time to time. Obviously, that clause will be very fully utilised. If the Bill becomes law it will herald the commencement of a process of legislation by regulation. This Bill is only the start of a series of new superannuation laws in this country. This is not the be all and end all; it is the starting point of a whole series of new laws that will have to flow from it. As a result of this Bill, we are no further progressed in terms of interpreting the Government's myriad technical proposals over the past two years. In fact, it could well be suggested that we have gone backwards. We have not advanced the cause of the industry.

TALK.START.PARA: —We have got much more uncertainty.

—As Senator Stone points out quite rightly, we have added confusion upon confusion, concern upon concern and disruption upon disruption. No industry can operate successfully in that situation. We have gone backwards for the reasons I have just mentioned. Prior to the legislation coming into force, a body called the Office of the Superannuation Commissioner has been producing interim group information circulars. To my knowledge, it has produced three of those, apparently with an air of a certain amount of authority. If one reads the information circulars, one finds that they bear great differences from what appears to be being proposed in the legislation. We ought to be able to assume that they may be treated as indicative of the way in which the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner, when his office is established, may think when he has had time to prescribe the regulations in the legislation, but it is a very uncertain and confusing situation.

SPEECH.PARA: The key clause of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill is probably clause 7. It gives the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner the power to prescribe standards in respect of almost anything to do with the operation of superannuation funds. The clause states:
The standards that may be prescribed include, but are not limited to-
those are the key words-
standards relating to the following matters:

A range of matters are listed which are fundamental to superannuation. There is the question of vesting, the preservation of benefits and the portability of benefits. None of the matters described in clause 7 have been expanded upon, except in a very limited fashion through the interim group circulars of the Office of the Superannuation Commissioner to which I have referred. Those circulars have very doubtful authority. We will have to wait until we see the further standards before we know their relevance or validity.

I mentioned the words `vesting', `preservation' and `portability' as contained in clause 7. As I understand it, this is the first time that those words have appeared in superannuation legislation. I think I am correct in saying that. They are very specific technical terms. Those terms often mean different things to different people. For example, the word `vesting' will usually be defined quite differently depending on whether one is speaking to an actuary or a lawyer. We do not know from the Bill what definition the Government has in mind for the use of the word `vesting'. As I understand it, we will have to wait on that until the regulations are introduced. That is an absolutely and totally unsatisfactory situation.

Clause 7 (2) (h) allows the Commissioner to prescribe standards in relation to `the investment of assets of superannuation funds'. That is an enormous area, an area of the greatest possible interest to every Australian. It is the subject of contentious debate at the moment, and has been for some time, as part of the whole area of the role of unions in superannuation funds. It is an important part of the Australian Council of Trade Unions document Australia Reconstructed, about which there have been very varying views from all sides of the political spectrum. There must be a much greater clarity or interpretation of clause 7 (2) (h) before one can come to grips with what it is about.

One could go on in a similar vein about the Bill. But the point which I come back to and which the Opposition has come back to time and again is that we in this chamber cannot look sensibly and responsibly at this legislation because the guts of it are not there. The guts of the legislation are to be found in the regulations which are to be prescribed. The regulations are not before us. As I understand it, and as Senator Stone mentioned in this chamber recently, it would appear from comments made by officers of the Department of the Treasury in the recent Estimates committee hearing that the drafting of regulations is very well advanced. If that is the case, why will the Government not bring forward those regulations to enable us to look at them in the context of the legislation? If that were done, we would be on much clearer ground as to what we are talking about when discussing this legislation. There appears to be no likelihood that the Government will do that but it is one of the reasons why we want to refer this package of Bills to a select committee so that, hopefully, these matters can be looked at quietly, deliberately and responsibly in a professional context in what is a very complex issue-so complex that it is simply not possible for this chamber, as such, to look at it even if it had the material. We need a committee to look at the issue and advise this chamber. That is why we are seeking the referral of the legislation to a Senate select committee.

We appreciate fully the wishes of the industry-and it is our wish and the Government's wish-that the matter be resolved quickly and expeditiously. It has dragged on far too long. That is the fault of this Government. There is no doubt about that. The Government has allowed this matter to drift for years without bringing in legislation. Now it wants to rush legislation through the Parliament. We are not prepared to agree to that. We stopped the Government doing so in May. It tried to rush the legislation through this place in the dying days of the last Parliament. We objected and refused to allow that to happen. We had expected that when the Government came back with its legislation in the new Parliament it would at least have advanced its thinking at least so far as taking this Parliament into its confidence on where the whole thing was going. But as far as I can detect there has not been one additional word of explanation from what was the case when the last Parliament was dissolved.

We appreciate the need for an early resolution of this matter. That is why, in our motion, we have put a very tight time limit on the committee's deliberations. We are suggesting that the committee report on or before 17 November. That is only four weeks from now and that delay will not affect in any detrimental way the course of the industry. It would be time very well spent. I am absolutely amazed at the attitude of the Australian Democrats in this matter, particularly the attitude of Senator Haines today in this chamber. Senator Haines was a member of the Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills which recommended that further detailed consideration be given to these matters. Now Senator Haines, on behalf of the Democrats, refuses to allow the matter to be subject to the very scrutiny that she was a party to saying should happen. Perhaps we should not be too surprised. The inconsistency of the Democrats is not something that has suddenly surfaced on 21 October 1987. It has been endemic and with us since the day the Democrats were formed. But it is very regrettable that they should have taken this attitude on a matter which is of such fundamental importance to all Australians.

If we, as parliamentarians, really believe that we have a role in safeguarding and looking after the interests of Australians, there is no area that I can think of in which that role needs to be played more than with this legislation. It is probably wishful thinking to hope that the Democrats might change their minds before we vote, but I urge them to do so in the interests of the constituency of each and every member of this Parliament-the Australian people. I am pleased to support Senator Watson's motion. I commend it to the Senate for urgent and sympathetic consideration by all parties.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the amendment moved by Senator Watson to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill. I do so because, as has been said by previous speakers on this side of the House, with the notable exception of Senator Haines, this package of legislation before us today is, I seriously suggest, a disgrace to the parliamentary process. This is not legislation regarding some minor question; it will fundamentally and profoundly affect the future development of the occupational superannuation industry in this country. In the course of doing that, it has the capacity to affect the civil rights and financial interests both of the fund trustees who have the responsibility for managing or supervising the funds-I think Senator Short mentioned that there are 280,000 separate funds-and the enormous body of fund contributors.

SPEECH.PARA: In passing, I should declare my interest in this matter. During my brief time in the private sector I-and particularly my wife-became a potential beneficiary of a superannuation fund contributed to by my employers during that time. Therefore, I have a personal interest in what happens with the superannuation industry. Of course, I have that interest in common with millions of other Australians. This legislation was submitted to the Parliament initially in May this year. That was almost 18 months after the Treasurer (Mr Keating) had made his first Press statement on the matter.
