At that time, due to the devoted work of my colleague Senator Short and others on this side of the chamber, and with the support at that time of the Australian Democrats, the Senate rejected the Government's then attempt to rush through this legislation before the double dissolution of the Parliament.

One might have thought that under those circumstances the Government would have taken advantage of the respite which had been forced upon it-if we put it that way-or that it had obtained, to look again at the drafting of the legislation to seek to overcome at least its worst deficiencies and inadequacies. But the Government has simply resubmitted the legislation in its quite unsatisfactory previous form. As Senator Watson and Senator Short said-and Senator Parer may also have said-this procedure on the Government's part is breathtaking in its arrogance; at least it would be breathtaking if we had not become so accustomed, not only in this place but throughout the country, to the arrogance of this Government, particularly the arrogance of the Minister formally responsible for this legislation, the Treasurer of the Commonwealth of Australia.

The Government's arrogance is all the more notable because the deficiencies of the legislation in its previous and still current form were previously pointed out by the Senate Standing Committee for the Scrutiny of Bills. That Committee, which includes senators from both sides of the chamber, condemned in the strongest terms the Government's practice of what the Committee rightly termed `legislation by Press release' as a method of changing the law.

Let us look at one or two specific things which that Scrutiny of Bills Committee said. Senator Haines was, at that time, a member of that Committee. In relation to clause 3, sub-clause (1) of the Bill, which contains definitions of `approved rules' and `approved trustees', the Scrutiny of Bills Committee said:
The lack of detail in these definitions contrasts markedly with the corresponding definitions in sub-section 27a (1) of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936 which set out the approved rules-

these rules were set out in that Act of the Parliament when Acts of the Parliament were being drawn up by governments which were not disposed to evade the Parliament as this Government continually does-
rather than leaving them to be prescribed by regulations and which detail certain approved trustees-
that is, the provisions of the Income Tax Assessment Act 1936-
while leaving scope for the content of that definition to be expanded by regulation.

Honourable senators on this side of the chamber are well aware that, particularly in an area as complex as that of superannuation, a quite extensive use of regulations may be necessary. The fact that we are drawing attention to and objecting to is that this Bill does not proceed on that basis, which, as Senator Short has said, is common ground; it proceeds on the basis of drawing up what purports to be a framework of standards. Of the three Bills before us, I am specifically referring to the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill. It contains no standards and leaves not merely regulations to be made to expand these matters but also regulations to be made to put the matters there in the first place.

Let us have a look at another segment of the comments of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee last May when these same Bills came before that Committee. In relation to clause 4 of the Bill, the Committee said:
Although clause 2 provides for the Bill to come into operation on a day to be fixed by Proclamation, clause 4 would apply the Bill, in effect, from 1 July 1986-
that is almost 16 months ago-
so that superannuation funds and approved deposit funds would be required to comply with the conditions established by the Bill from that date in order to gain concessional taxation treatment.
The Committee went on to say:

It appears that the basis of this retrospectivity is to be found in press releases which the Treasurer made on 11 June, 30 July and 22 December 1986. Once again the Committee has occasion to draw to the attention of Senators the practice of the Treasurer of treating his press releases as de facto changes to the law . . .

An Opposition group of senators did not make these comments; it was the Scrutiny of Bills Committee-a committee jointly constituted of senators from both sides of this chamber-which, in carrying out its absolutely proper functions, drew attention, as I have said, to the practice of the Treasurer of treating his Press releases as `de facto changes to the law by introducing legislation backdated to the day on which he first announced the proposal to change the law'. This is not the first time. The report then referred to another report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee in 1986:
. . . it appears that the Treasurer found it necessary in this case to modify or add to the terms of his initial announcement . . .
By those dulcet terms, the Committee actually meant that the Treasurer found it necessary to rectify his former errors. The Committee report continued:

. . . so that the de facto legislation may be said to have been amended before it was introduced into the Parliament. The practice of `legislation by Press release' carries with it the assumption that citizens should arrange their affairs in accordance with announcements made by the Executive rather than in accordance with the laws made by Parliament. The Committee questions how persons can be expected to comply with the law when its terms are not publicly available but may only be ascertained from a reading of Ministerial press releases and when the Minister concerned issues further press releases modifying or adding to the terms of the original press release.
The Committee continued:

The Committee condemns in the strongest terms the practice of `legislation by press release'. When, in November 1985, the Committee requested the Treasurer's comments on the fact that, in almost four years of existence, it had never received a response to a comment made by it on a Bill for which the Treasurer had been responsible, the Treasurer responded that, due to the considerable time pressures continuously experienced by his staff and the limited number of officials engaged in the legislation area, a practice of not responding had been adopted.
A practice of not responding to the reports of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee of the Senate had been adopted.

TALK.START.PARA: —He is above the Parliament.
—The Treasurer is above the Parliament. The Committee concluded:

SPEECH.PARA: The Committee is aware-
of course, Mr Acting Deputy President, we are all aware-
of the burdens which the Government's programme of taxation reform has imposed on the Taxation Office.
Whether it should properly be described as taxation reform may be another matter. The Committee report continued:

It is also aware, however, of the burden which that same programme has imposed on those who are obliged to comply with the taxation laws and, in particular, those who are called upon to advise on the legislation in a professional capacity.
The Committee might have added the burden imposed by these processes on the members of this Senate and of this Parliament more generally. The report continued:
The task of such persons is made doubly difficult by the frequent recourse to the practice of `legislation by press release' as a method of changing the law.

At the outset of the debate this morning Senator Haines spoke on the original Bill; she did not speak to this amendment. Senator Haines, who as Leader of the Australian Democrats carries a heavy responsibility in these matters in this chamber these days, acknowledged, as we all do, the great difficulties imposed upon the industry. I will come back to a definition of that term `the industry' in a moment because it is significant to define it a little more closely as Senator Watson suggested. Senator Haines acknowledged the difficulties created for the industry by the inordinate delays which the Treasurer's inefficiency, if not worse, has imposed upon it. In a passing phrase, what one might call a throw-away line, Senator Haines referred to the undesirability of government by Press release. I may be wrong but I do not believe that I heard Senator Haines refer at any point in her remarks to the report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee. If she did so refer, of course I would retract what I now say, but I do not believe that I heard her refer to the report of the Scrutiny of Bills Committee, of which she had previously been a distinguished member, which report I referred to at some length in the earlier part of my remarks.

As I have said, notwithstanding her prominent part in that Committee's comments to the Senate some five months ago, Senator Haines told us at some length-I should say almost repetitively, but I do not wish to be unkind-that the industry, this term of art, wants the Bills now without delay. She told us that she had had discussions with the AMP Society, with some other major life insurance companies and with the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, or its representatives, and that the industry, as so defined, wants the Bills and that as a consequence-although Senator Haines did not put it this way-all these entirely admirable views that she and her colleagues on the then Scrutiny of Bills Committee had put forward only five months ago could be thrown into the discard.

What does the superannuation industry actually consist of? It is certainly true that major life offices such as those that I have mentioned and their representative body, the Life Insurance Federation of Australia, do represent a significant component of the superannuation industry. It may not be without relevance that that is the particular component of the industry which holds out to itself-I think with justice, to date at least-the greatest prospect of attracting the commissions for the management of the new union-based superannuation funds. One would not want to pursue too far speculations which that connection arouses because one would be--

TALK.START.PARA: —You wouldn't want to ignore it, either.

—As Senator Watson reminds me, I certainly would not want to ignore it, either. But let us be quite clear: this is not the industry; the industry is much more extensive than the interests of some large life offices with which it now seems the Australian Democrats too have allied themselves. We are used to the performance of the present Government in its relationships with big business, big corporations, but I had been labouring under what now appears to be the totally false impression that that was not the constituency of the Australian Democrats. So I found this experience very edu-cational indeed. Of course, the 280,000 funds are not for the most part managed by these major corporate bodies; they are managed by private trustees with the advice of consultants. Perhaps they do not have the same easy access to the offices of Ministers as does the AMP Society.
—One or two of them do.

—Yes, perhaps one or two of them do. Let us be quite clear as to who wants this. Nobody can claim that the industry wants this. It may or it may not. All my understandings are that the smaller funds and bodies, such as consultants to those funds and other bodies such as the Law Institute of Victoria which have in their own professional capacity dealings with such funds and their trustees, are much less anxious to rush into the final form of legislation on this matter and that they would very much prefer to have these matters looked at again, certainly not in the drawn out process but expeditiously, with a view to tightening up the drafting in these Bills and filling in the black holes that the Bills presently contain.

SPEECH.PARA: In that latter connection, let me mention some views from the Superannuation Committee of the Law Institute of Victoria which have conveyed to me and, I know, also to Senator Haines, as well as to some other senators in this place. The Law Institute Superannuation Committee has expressed in the most serious terms its concerns about the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill. It has said that it:

believes that, as a matter of principle, substantive law which affects the rights of so many Australians should be enacted and not introduced by regulations. The Ins-titute considers the adoption of regulations to be an unsatisfactory method of introducing and, presumably changing the new controls sought to be imposed in respect of superannuation funds.
Secondly, the Institute has expressed the view that the appeals procedure contained in this Bill is totally unsatisfactory.

Because of constraints upon my time, let me turn to that latter question first. This is the kind of question which we believe should be reviewed before a select committee of this Senate with a view to amending the sections of the Bill which are deficient in these respects. The Institute says that it considers the provisions set out in the Bill for the review of decisions of the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner to be unworkable-not merely defective, not merely undesirable in law in terms of natural justice and matters of this kind which normally in this place Senator Haines is the first person to spring to her feet to claim affiliation with, but unworkable. The Ins-titute says that it considers-I totally agree-that the 21 days notice which is laid down in the relevant provision of the Bill is simply insufficient for trustees to prepare an objection to a decision of the Commissioner. Under this Bill the Commissioner has power to make or break the operations of a fund and the trustees of that fund, under this Bill, are given 21 days to lodge with the Commissioner a reasoned objection-not merely an objection but an objection which is accompanied by reasons. The Law Institute of Victoria puts the view:
In most cases Trustees will be relying on professional advisers to advise them of an effect of a decision of the Commissioner . . .
The Law Institute Superannuation Committee says:

. . . it is considered that the period of 21 days is far too short to permit the Trustees to be properly advised as to the course they should adopt and to respond to the Commissioner particularly as the nature of the objections must state reasons for seeking the review.

The Institute suggests-it seems to me entirely reasonable, and it would be one of the suggestions that could be examined by the select committee which we are seeking-that the comparable provisions in the Income Tax Assessment Act, namely, for a 60-day period of objection, should be similarly incorporated into this Bill as being much more appropriate; not merely more appropriate in terms of giving people a chance to make their objection but also more workable because one of the other clauses of this Bill has the effect that, if no such objection is proffered, the Commissioner's decision stands.

Let me come to another provision which is linked with this one. Again, it is a provision which I think would benefit from serious scrutiny by a select committee of this place and, I would hope, reconsideration by the Government of what seem to be entirely reasonable propositions. The obverse of the 21-day objection provision is the 21-day confirmation or revocation provision which is available to the Commissioner. Having received an objection, the Commissioner then has 21 days in which to deal with it. If he does nothing, if he simply makes no finding, his decision is confirmed. That is why Senator Parer in his remarks earlier said that he believed that the Bill must be defective in this respect; he thought the Bill must mean revoked in that case. I would like to think that Senator Parer was correct in his assumption but I am afraid that he is not. I am afraid that this is what the Government intends. It intends that the new Commissioner shall have this draconian power simply by doing nothing to have his original decision given the force of law. This can happen not only by direction, but also by indirection. It can happen simply as a result of the file getting lost. I would hate to suggest that anywhere in the Treasury-or some outrider of the Treasury-a file might get lost. Nevertheless, these things do happen.

To come to my conclusion, let me say more generally that what we have in this Bill-this is a point on which Senator Watson so effectively remarked-is a process of government not by statute but by regulation. Indeed, in this case, it is government seeking to do by way of regulation what so far has been done by Press release, involving in that process a total vacuum in terms of the knowledge of what this legislation, if passed, will produce and what its effects will be on the millions of people in Australia to whom it will apply. We are asked to put the trust of the Parliament in the hands of the new bureaucracy to be created by these Bills and to believe that at no time will ministerial influence be brought to bear upon it, although some other influence will perhaps be brought to bear on the Minister from certain quarters in this society which, given the close relationship between this Government and the trade unions, do not need much elaboration.

TALK.START.PARA: —Bureaucracy which the funds have to pay for.

—Senator Watson reminds me that this is bureaucracy which the funds themselves have to pay for. Indeed, one of the amusing-here I am being ironic-provisions in this Bill which industry is so anxious to have and is breaking its neck to have passed without delay is that concerning the function of the Governor-General, that is to say, the Executive. Clause 22 of the Bill states:

SPEECH.PARA: The Governor-General may make regulations, not inconsistent with this Act, prescribing matters:
and, in particular, prescribing fees payable in respect of any matter under this Act.

I strongly support the amendment moved by Senator Watson for the referral of these three Bills to a Senate select committee to report to this chamber on or before, but not later than, 17 November-that is less than four weeks from today-with a view to expeditiously handling the Bills in an amended form, as I would hope the Government might agree to do, to effect their passage into legislation before the Senate rises. That is certainly our objective. To have the industry, in the form of the so-called large life offices, using its undoubted influence-which, I should say, it has sought to use on the Opposition too, but without success-in order to speed up, as it put it, this process by less than a month when these matters have been hanging around for up to 18 months, is extraordinary. I support the amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do not intend to delay for very long the processing of the Occupational Superannuation Standards Bill 1987, the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner Bill 1987 and the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner (Consequential Provisions) Bill 1987. However, I have to make a few points. Firstly, the Opposition is putting up a fundamentally inconsistent argument. On the one hand, it is complaining that because of the long gestation of these Bills, interrupted, of course, by the Federal election campaign, that is fostering uncertainty in the community, the industry and among actual or potential beneficiaries of superannuation schemes. On the other hand, and, of course, totally inconsistent with that argument, the Opposition is simultaneously arguing that there should be a further delay resulting from our referring this Bill to a Senate committee. I am informed-I did not hear it myself-that the Australian Democrats will be not supporting the Opposition's amendment. Therefore, the Bill will pass through the second reading stage to the committee stage.

SPEECH.PARA: The second point I make is that there is a fundamental misrepresentation in the Opposition's argument. The misrepresentation that I heard Senator Short make was that the delegation to regulation in this legislation of matters covering the details of specific superannuation schemes is an abrogation of the authority of Parliament, and so on. That, of course, is a fundamental misrepresentation, as I am sure both Senator Stone and Senator Short would acknowledge privately. Regulations have to be approved explicitly or implicitly by both houses of Parliament before they can become law.

TALK.START.PARA: —They cannot be amended.

—They can effectively be amended. If the honourable senator wants to go down that track I will remind him of the act of capricious sabotage perpetrated in the Senate last May over the northern prawn fishery. A little lobby group had got on to the Queensland National Party rednecks-the Queensland National Party runs along with every redneck idea-and the supine, spineless Liberal Party behaved in the way it has behaved for decades and refused to stand up to any of the foolish and outrageous demands of the National Party. The National Party tail again wagged the Liberal Party dog, and got it wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: It put up an equally illogical argument, misrepresenting the facts as well, that the Government had sought to write into the relevant regulation a clause which ensured that the objective, which was to reduce the excess fishing capacity in the Gulf of Carpentaria, would actually be achieved, if the voluntary surrender and buy-back scheme had not succeeded, on a certain date, through an across the board cut in the entitlements of all those remaining in the industry.

The Opposition misrepresented the facts, saying that that across the board cut was a confiscation of property without compensation. Of course, that was a gross misrepresentation of a beneficial entitlement, a privilege granted to those people, that is, a licence to fish. It then compounded that misrepresentation of fact with the illogical argument that the voluntary buy-back scheme would work anyway-in which case, of course, there was no justification either for its objection to the across the board cut, which was envisaged some years down the track if the voluntary buy-back scheme did not--

TALK.START.PARA: —How about talking about the Bill?

—I know that Senator Stone in recent years has had a cerebral decline of significant magnitude, no doubt due to his recent association with the rednecks of the Queensland National Party. However, in spite of that significant cerebral decline, I am sure that Senator Stone has not deteriorated to the point where he cannot see the fundamental illogic in the argument put up by the Opposition in regard to the northern prawn fishery. There was a de facto amendment of regulations in the Senate-an amendment which exposes the industry to the risk that the adjustments that every sensible person knows must take place may not happen, and which exposes the taxpayer to demands, some years down the track, for further Commonwealth Government money to bail the industry out of the troubles which it has got into because of the capricious sabotage of regulations by the Opposition in the Senate.
—What are you talking about?

—I suggest to Senator Stone that he read the Hansard of the time if he is actually interested in the matter. The fundamental misrepresentation by the Opposition is that this is an abrogation or an undermining or erosion of the power of Parliament to allow for some of the rules to be set in regulations instead of in legislation. That, of course, is quite wrong.

SPEECH.PARA: There is, in addition, a policy reason for moving in that direction which I think is set out very succinctly in a letter received by the Treasurer (Mr Keating) on 24 July this year from the Institute of Actuaries of Australia-hardly, I note for the record, a body which is noted for Trotskyist tendencies, anarchistic tendencies or, indeed, any sort of revolutionary tendencies at all. I would have thought that it would be regarded as a body which is sensibly conservative. I make that distinction, `sensibly conservative', of course, in order to separate it from the sort of misdefined conservatism, or so-called conservatism, of the Queensland National Party. Mr Pollard, the President, said in this letter, among other things:

There is no doubt that, even with the best advice possible from the industry, some plans that are reasonable per se in all respects, albeit unusual in design, will be subject to unintended effects of any legislative standards. While legislated changes could cope with such problems, clearly it will always be much more difficult to achieve necessary or desirable change in a timely fashion through this route, as opposed to changing regulations.
He goes on to make a number of similar points, one of which I think is worth reading. He said:

In many instances plan trustees are likely to find the terms of their deeds at odds with conditions imposed upon or accepted by plan sponsors, and which place trustees in an invidious position. While Government announcements can indicate how such problems will eventually be solved (e.g. by legislative change), this is no substitute for the clear legal authority trustees need in order to meet changing circumstances.
He then said:
Therefore, from the Institute view it is much more appropriate that the proposed occupational superannuation standards be regulated rather than legislated.

So, apart from the gross misrepresentation of fact by the Opposition, there are sound policy reasons for proceeding in the way the Government proposes to proceed. Moreover, apart from the difficulty of foreseeing every possible contingency-I think Mr Pollard used the term `unintended consequence'-when putting legislation up, a Bill which tried to cover all of those which were foreseen at the time even and accurately identified would obviously be very much longer and more cumbersome than the one which is before us. What I have said would have indicated very clearly that the Government will be opposing the amendment moved by the Opposition. I understand that the Australian Democrats have also signified their intention to oppose the amendment. The Opposition has forecast that it will move a number of other amendments at the committee stage and I will deal with them at that time.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Harradine Sen B.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Acting Deputy President, I think I am in order in moving an amendment to the amendment moved by Senator Watson. I move:

SPEECH.PARA: Leave out paragraph (1) of Senator Watson's amendment.

Senator Watson's amendment would then simply provide for leaving out all words after `That' and inserting the words that the Bills be referred to a select committee. I believe that paragraph (1) of Senator Watson's amendment is not necessary for the purpose of referring the matter to a committee. I think Senator Watson would agree with me that paragraph (1) adds really nothing to the reference of this matter to a committee.

TALK.START.PARA: —The seriousness of the issue is the reason why it should go to it.
—The honourable senator outlined that when he spoke about referring the Bills to a committee. I would be able to support the reference of the Bills to a committee on that basis.
—The question is: That the amendment moved by Senator Harradine be agreed to.
—The question now is: That Senator Watson's amendment be agreed to.

SPEECH.PARA: Original question resolved in the affirmative.

PROCTEXT.PARA: OCCUPATIONAL SUPERANNUATION STANDARDS BILL 1987
Clauses 1 and 2-by leave-taken together, and agreed to.
Clause 3 (Interpretation).

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (1) Page 3, subclause 3 (1), definition of ``superannuation fund'', line 33, at end of definition, add the following words and paragraph:
``, but does not include:
(c) a fund established as a result of an employer or employers being threatened, intimidated or coerced by a trade union or trade unions;''.

The purpose of this amendment, which, as will be evident, differs considerably-in a qualitative sense, if you like-from the other amendments which I shall move to subsequent clauses of the Bill, is to highlight in the legislation what the Opposition foresees is likely to be a major problem with the operations of a significant section of the superannuation fund industry in the months and, more particularly, years ahead. I think the nature of this problem is evident enough without spelling it out at undue length. I shall therefore not weary the Committee by doing so.

We have already seen the operations and activities of some segments of the trade union movement in this area of superannuation arrangements which have flowed from-and are part of, if you like-the national wage case processes last year. While I do not wish for one moment to suggest that there is anything in the least wrong with employees receiving improved superannuation benefits-on the contrary, it is common ground on both sides of this chamber that that is wholly desirable in appropriately regulated circumstances-nevertheless, every thoughtful and knowledgeable person who has some understanding of these matters and of the way in which they are presently being conducted in the industrial relations field in this country knows that considerable elements of pressure, intimidation, threat and coercion are being applied, I repeat, by some elements of the trade union movement to employers in this area. The purpose of the proposed amendment to the subclause is to provide in the legislation for a ground in the courts of the land against such action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I presume that this is just a ritualistic amendment, and the Government will oppose it. Among other things, it leaves hanging in the air the question of how the Insurance and Superannuation Commissioner could objectively determine those funds which had been established in the way in which the amendment alleges they have been established-that is, as a result of intimidation, coercion and so on by the trade unions. On those grounds alone-on the grounds of operational difficulty-I think the amendment does not deserve to be supported. That confirms my suspicion that it is just a ritualistic amendment.

SPEECH.PARA: Amendment negatived.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

TALKER.NAME: Senator STONE
TALKER.ROLE: Leader of the National Party of Australia)

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: (2) Pages 3 and 4, subclause 3 (1), definition of ``year of income'', leave out the definition, insert the following definition:

`` `year of income', in relation to a fund, means a period that is a year of income in relation to the fund for the purposes of the Tax Act, but excludes such a period the whole or a part of which occurred before the commencement of this Act.''.

This does not require lengthy explanation. The purpose of this amendment is to deal with a question which has been the subject of remarks at some length this morning-not merely by me, but other speakers on this side of the chamber-namely, the objectionable nature of the retrospectivity provisions of this legislation, based upon the fact that the Treasurer (Mr Keating), having issued various Press releases on the matter, has failed to bring legislation before the Parliament to give effect to those Press releases until now. This amendment, if accepted, would simply wipe out those retrospective provisions of the Bill and would have the effect of making the standards which are to be made by the Bill under whatever process-by regulation now-first apply in respect of the year commencing July 1 next.

TALK.START.PARA: —Given the Australian Democrats' past abhorrence for retrospectivity, I urge the Democrats to support this amendment.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —One should concede that there is a bit more substance to this amendment. It deserves to be taken a little more seriously than the previous one. That having been said, the Government, of course, will not accept it because we believe that the expectations of the last 15 or 18 months should be confirmed and not abandoned. On the broader question of retrospectivity, there is nothing unique about this. It has been the practice for many years. I think that for as long as I have been in the Parliament it has been the practice with regard to taxation laws for amendments which affect the revenue base-and some other things, probably, sometimes-to be effective from the date on which the government of the day has announced them. That was the practice of the previous Government and it is the practice of this Government. There is no great breach of principle involved in extending it to the standards and superannuation fund.

SPEECH.PARA: Question put:
That the amendment (Senator Stone's) be agreed to.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer and the Minister for Industrial Relations. Does the Minister recall that yesterday I asked him whether the Government would reconsider its submission to the national wage case hearing in light of the dramatic developments on the stock market and the very bad current account figures for September, and that in reply the Minister described such a suggestion as `patently stupid'? Is it a fact that the Government today cited the stock market collapse as the reason for postponing the national wage case? —One patently stupid question is now being followed by another patently stupid question. —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Primary Industries and Energy. Has the Minister's attention been drawn to an article in the West Australian newspaper of 3 October reporting the Leader of the Western Australian branch of the National Party who was censuring the National Farmers Federation (NFF) for its poor campaigning performance during the July Federal election? What rural policies did the NFF promote which did not find favour with the rural electorate? Does the Government find difficulty in dealing with the NFF as a peak industry organisation which is so out of touch with the people it purports to represent? Finally, does Senator Walsh feel uncomfortable about sharing his views on the NFF's performance at the last election with the Leader of the National Party in Western Australia?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —In relation to the last part of the question, I always feel a little bit uncomfortable when I find that anybody in the National Party agrees with any view that I hold; indeed, I see that as a prima facie reason not for mindlessly changing one's view but for at least reassessing it.

ANSWER.PARA: In the case of Mr Cowan, however, what really should be borne in mind is that Mr Cowan was looking for a scapegoat for the disastrous National Party performance during the recent election campaign. His attack on the NFF, which in a different context might be well merited, should be seen in the correct context; that is, that Mr Cowan, along with the National Party in Western Australia in general, was one of the Bjelke-Petersen toadies, one of the enthusiasts in the Joh for PM campaign. Since that collapsed disastrously for the National Party and for the coalition-although it was a good thing for Australia that it did-Mr Cowan is, of course, looking for a scapegoat or some camouflage to distract attention from the fact that he was one of the gung ho supporters of the ridiculous Joh for PM campaign, along with the National Party in Western Australia. Indeed, there was hardly a more loyal toady anywhere around the country than Mr Cowan and the Western Australian branch of the National Party.

In respect of the earlier part of the question, particularly what rural policies promoted by the NFF were not favoured in the rural electorate, I do not think one can answer that with any certainty, but there is a high probability that the high profile campaign conducted by the National Farmers Federation against the fringe benefits tax and the capital gains tax was recognised by people in the rural community for what it really was; that is, a campaign run on behalf of people such as directors of Elders-IXL and a campaign which, had it succeeded, would have been detrimental to the constituency which the National Farmers Federation claimed to represent. I cite in particular the fringe benefits tax. When the statistics finally came out, they showed that some 5,000 farmers were affected at all-that is, less than 3 per cent of farmers were affected by the fringe benefits tax at all-and the average tax paid by those 5,000 people was only $1,000. The median tax paid by that 5,000 I would expect to be considerably less than $1,000.

However, it is very difficult to avoid the conclusion that the National Farmers Federation was certainly not representing the interests of the people it purported to represent, and less certainly one can say that that was recognised by the rural community in general and reflected in the fact that in all but three, I think it was, of 22 seats that the National Farmers Federation had targeted there was, in fact, a two-party preferred swing to the Labor Party.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Is the Minister aware that the highly respected economic commentator, Allan Wood, of Syntec Economic Services Pty Ltd, said on the Australian Broadcasting Corporation AM program this morning that the crash in world stock markets has made the Government's economic strategy irrelevant? Does he agree with Mr Wood that `We now have to go to a strategy of much more rapid adjustment in order to try and minimise the impact of this very severe external market crash upon us'?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —I think I explained to Senator Stone's satisfaction the ways in which a global collapse in share prices could adversely affect the Australian economy, while adding that there was at that stage, and so far as I am aware at this stage also, no evidence that either of those things was, in fact, happening. I did hear Mr Wood this morning and I was surprised to hear him say the things that he said. In particular, Mr Wood suggested that the decline in share prices would affect the revenue which would otherwise have been collected by the capital gains tax in this financial year.
—He did not mention capital gains tax.

—I think he did. I will check that out. That was regardless of what ultimate effect variations in share prices might have on capital gains tax-induced, or near capital gains tax-induced, revenue, because revenue will be collected under a couple of other sections of the Income Tax Assessment Act. Because of the existence of an explicit capital gains tax, it will not affect the revenue this year. Any effects on revenue will be lagged by one year. The Treasurer remarked this morning in an interview, a transcript of which I have seen, that Syntec had been giving some pretty bad advice recently and that anybody who was taking Syntec's advice-- Senator Stone-Play the ball, not the man.

—Hang on. Do not be so impatient; I will draw the honourable senator's attention to a few facts. I think that even he would have to admit that the Syntec forecast turned out to be dramatically wrong-indeed, about as wrong as the forecast which he made at the same time turned out to be. Syntec's record in recent times has not been particularly good. I refer to the Syntec Business Outlook No. 168, which was published on 1 September last year. The Budget forecast for gross domestic product growth was 2.25 per cent. The Syntec forecast was one per cent; that is, less than half the growth rate which had been forecast in the Budget. The outcome was 2 per cent-marginally below, it is true, the Government's 1986 Budget forecast, but double the growth rate predicted by Syntec.

ANSWER.PARA: In the same issue, Syntec predicted a Budget deficit of $4.3 billion, as against the $3.5 billion which had been forecast and the $2.7 billion actual outcome. In other words, once again, the Syntec forecast of the Budget deficit at that time was almost double the actual Budget deficit outcome. Syntec also predicted a trade weighted index of 45 as against the Budget forecast of 52 and a financial year outcome of 53.8. Following the last Budget, Syntec's record was not, to say the least, particularly good. Whether Mr Wood's views on the likely fallout of the big decline in share prices around the globe is correct or otherwise is something that remains to be seen.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Stone Sen J.O.

QUESTION.PARA: We now have to go to a strategy of much more rapid adjustment in order to try and minimise the impact . . .
Will the Minister now respond to that question?

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Wood expressed a view that some other people hold. The fact that Mr Wood has committed himself personally to that view is a matter which I do not regard as particularly relevant.
