Notwithstanding that, I cannot guarantee to get a response, because I do not represent the Minister here, but I do not think there would be any trouble in getting one from the relevant Minister as to the decisions made by the Department of Community Services and Health in regard to its responsibility.

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. Given the fact that the paper entitled Advisory Structures and the Administration of the Department of Employment, Education and Training, which was circulated last week by the Minister, was silent with regard to the Government's intentions on the national language policy, and given the fact that the Government campaigned strongly in the last election on a promise to implement a national policy on languages, I ask the Minister: How is the Government going to implement its policy and promise? Which Government body or department will be responsible for the relevant programs? What expertise will it draw on, and who will be responsible for providing ongoing advice to the Government on this matter?

—It is certainly the case that the announcement of the national language policy during the last election campaign was a major element of our new commitments in the education area. The Government has every intention of proceeding with the implementation of that policy as announced. The Government will allocate $15.1m in 1987-88-and that will grow to $28.65m in 1988-89 and $27.3m in 1989-90-for the implementation of the national language policy. At this stage, it is expected that all programs in the national language policy package will be in place by the commencement of the 1988 academic year. Consultations will commence soon with State and Territory education authorities on aspects of the policy which are of direct relevance to them, once the details of the program components have been finalised. I remind the Senate that the national language policy is a balanced policy which addresses both domestic and external needs. It includes $5.3m in 1987-88, growing to $13.5m in 1988-89, to double the English as a second language new arrivals component from six to 12 months and funding for the ESL general support component will be at least maintained in real terms.
—Mr President, I draw the Minister's attention to the last part of my question, which was: Who will be responsible for providing ongoing advice to the Government on this matter?

—The Government has a range of advisers available to it currently through the Schools Commission and the Department of Employment, Education and Training. As a result of the restructuring of the advisory sources available to the Government, there may be some change in that. When final decisions are made on that matter I will let Senator Macklin know.

—Can the Minister representing the Attorney-General comment on media reports which indicate that the Australian Federal Police (AFP) recently seized a large number of illegal videotapes from a warehouse in Canberra?

—I understand that officers of the AFP Gaming and Vice Squad carried out a raid on certain Australian Capital Territory video shops on Friday, 9 October, and perhaps early in the hours of Saturday, 10 October, and seized a substantial number of videotapes, certainly from a storage garage in Fyshwick. Perhaps as many as 2,500 pornographic videotapes were seized during that raid. I understand that the raids were undertaken as a result of a complaint from the censorship section of the Attorney-General's Department. The tapes were thought to be in breach of the Classification of Publications Ordinance 1983 in that they may have been offered for sale or hire without classification by censorship authorities. The Special Crime Squad detectives are continuing their investigations. As charges may be laid soon and prosecutions undertaken, it is not appropriate to make any further comment on the particular raids, but it might be pointed out that this is the first case involving videotapes to be considered for prosecution under the Classification of Publications Ordinance as amended in 1984. If prosecution does occur in relation to a large number of the videos and a conviction is recorded, the penalties under that ordinance could run into hundreds of thousands of dollars.

—My question is addressed to the Minister for Finance and follows the question asked by Senator Stone. The Minister for Finance, in his answer to Senator Stone, said that some people agreed with Mr Wood that there is a need for a more rapid adjustment of the Australian economy. Is the Minister one of those people?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —The simplistic notion which not surprisingly, I suppose, dominates the psyches of members of the Opposition is that one has only to write a prescription which is technically correct and the outcome will flow automatically. Apart from this being a less than totally scientific exercise about what may or may not technically be correct, judgments have to be made, by people who have responsibility for making policy, about what is achievable. While in that wholly abstract and, may I suggest, unreal world where most members of the Opposition dwell--
—For heaven's sake, you are boring.

—The honourable senator does not have to stay to listen. Most of us would be relieved if she left. In that hypothetical gross abstraction from reality, a person could write a formula which, as long as he believed it would happen, would produce a better outcome. But judgments have to be made about what is achievable. I know that that conflicts with the ideological prejudices that dominate the Opposition. The Government has made a judgment about both the direction in which change should be headed and the rate at which that change is achievable, as distinct from the Opposition which, at least during the recent election campaign-and if it has changed its mind on this matter I welcome that change-tried to peddle the supply side voodoo notion or nostrum, as Ross Gittins called it a couple of days ago, that living standards could be enhanced through snake oil remedies and policies of incentivation and all that sort of thing and that everybody could enhance his living standards via taxation cuts. Those opposite left gaping holes, of course, as to how they would cover the consequential blowout in the Budget deficit if their taxation cuts were actually put into effect. I mentioned Mr Gittins. In last Monday's Sydney Morning Herald, of Mr Howard's behaviour during the recent election campaign, Mr Gittins said:

ANSWER.PARA: Overnight, the Treasury-trained former Treasurer began spouting supply-side nostrums.

That is a bit of alliteration which is probably worthy of John Norton with a wet towel over his head. Nevertheless, that sums up succinctly the sheer irresponsibility and opportunism of the Opposition Leader during the recent election campaign. Still speaking of Mr Howard, Mr Gittins went on:
The apostle of fiscal responsibility was proposing to cut taxes first and find the spending cuts later.

To that criticism of Mr Howard, Mr Gittins might well have added that the former apostle of fiscal responsibility, that is, the former Secretary to the Treasury who now sits in this Parliament, was even worse. John Howard had a credibility gap of about $4 billion in his last Budget but Senator Stone still has a credibility gap of $18 billion.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I take a point of order. The Minister clearly is debating the question. I suspect that he has now finished his answer, so I will ask a supplementary question.
—I would love to read some more of Gittins's article.

—I thank the Minister for indicating that he agrees that there is a theoretical need for more rapid adjustment and that it is obviously a matter of judgment as to whether a faster rate of adjustment is possible. I ask the Minister: What is his judgment as to the present rate of adjustment and is it his judgment that a faster rate of adjustment in Australia is possible?

—I know that a number of people on the Opposition side suffer from delusions of grandeur to the point where they believe they are infallible. I hope that I remain exempt from that affliction. I will not say what in my judgment should or should not be done. Apart from anything else, a Government decision has been made and all the members of the Government are bound by that. But one does not have to have delusions of grandeur to the point of embracing the doctrine of personal infallibility to see the essential and enormous qualitative difference between what this Government is doing-it is making adjustments at a significant rate in the direction in which the country and its economy must go-and the snake oil policies and supply side voodoo nostrums being peddled by the Opposition. The impending Budget deficit of those opposite is even bigger than the one Mr Howard left us with in 1983.

—My question is directed to the Minister representing the Treasurer. Has he seen a column in the Sydney Morning Herald of Monday, 12 October 1987, by a leading tax commentator, suggesting that a future Federal government which removed the fringe benefits tax, substantiation requirements and the capital gains tax would start at least $2 billion in the red? Is this an accurate assessment of the fiscal consequences if those reforms were dismantled?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —Any figure as nicely rounded with nine zeros as is $2,000,000,000 obviously is less than absolutely precise, although if we were to knock off $5 so that we did not have as many zeros the figure would be even more suspect because it would imply a degree of precision which, in this sort of context, could not reasonably be expected. With that caveat, I think that the estimate of Mr Burrell, the journalist concerned, of $2 billion is an acceptable estimate, if not a precisely accurate one. It is, of course, very substantially above the conservative estimates which had been assumed by the Government when putting together last year's Budget. In the period following such things it is very common for the Australian Taxation Office to make conservative estimates of incremental revenue received as a result of changes to taxation law. All that extra revenue of around $2 billion is attributable to the imposition of the capital gains tax (CGT), the fringe benefits tax and substantiation requirements.

ANSWER.PARA: I indicated earlier that the final impact upon revenue of the CGT is not limited to the direct revenue collected under the capital gains tax provisions of the legislation; the increase in revenue under a couple of other provisions of the legislation is induced by the existence of a capital gains tax. Effectively, the existence of a capital gains tax puts a net under the whole income tax system and closes off the opportunities for tax avoidance which were so blatantly exploited during the late 1970s and early 1980s and so scandalously disregarded by the Treasurer of the day. Mr Burrell also noted in the article that the Opposition has problems on two fronts; achieving an acceptable deficit figure if it maintains its determination to abolish these tax measures, and also as being soft on tax avoidance-reinforcing its sabotage of the Australia Card. The article canvasses the possibility that the Liberals might address those problems by returning to a proposal for an 8 per cent retail tax. It will be very interesting, to say the least, to see whether Mr Peacock's views prevail, or whether Senator Stone's views, as expressed last weekend, prevail. If I may say so, that is another remarkable about-face by Senator Stone since he started keeping bad company. Mr Burrell concluded-and I think this is worth reading:

It would be a measure of Mr Peacock's authority as shadow Treasurer to take up the consumption tax idea and prevail. But in the end, political reality will counsel otherwise. The sheer size of the revenue gap and the political difficulties faced in filling it means it would be easier simply to leave the Government's tax reforms in place and endure the embarrassment of a backdown.

If Mr Burrell is correct in saying that the Opposition ultimately will become sufficiently responsible, in a fiscal sense, to leave the Government's tax reform in place, that should be welcomed by all responsible and informed Australians.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Finance to today's reported comments by the Treasurer that the stock market crash on Wall Street is due in large measure to financial markets changing their minds about the United States economy because of its chronic trade deficit and the recent rise in United States interest rates. Does the Minister share this view? If so, why should the Australian wipe-out not also be viewed as a long overdue, but essentially rational response to Australia's chronic and gargantuan foreign debt, the September record current account deficit and prime lending rates and long term government bond yields which are significantly higher than those of all of our major trading partners?

—As I indicated earlier, I have not had the time yet to read the full transcript of what the Treasurer had to say. But if it has been more or less accurately interpreted by Senator Alston, which is perhaps an heroic assumption that one is not entitled to make, I see no reason to disagree with the proposition that there has been a reassessment of the American economy, part of which was the fact that there had been a sustained stock market boom in the United States. All sustained stock market booms in history-with `boom' being defined as a level of prices for shares which is not sustainable by long term probable earnings or by asset values-will ultimately be followed by a decline in share prices, sometimes a small decline, sometimes, after a very prolonged and inflated boom such as we have gone through in the last few years, a pretty rapid decline such as the one that has happened in the last few days. I suppose at the end of that one can only say: so what? Share prices were too high and they have come down. So what?

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Perhaps the Minister is hard of hearing but what I put to him was not that there had simply been an inevitable correction on the United States stock market, rather that the markets had taken the view that the state of the American economy was inherently unhealthy because of large trade deficits and increasing interest rates. If that is a correct view, why should that same view not be taken of the Australian economy and the reaction of Australian markets to all of those fundamental problems that beset the Australian economy?

—I apologise, Mr President. I was certainly remiss in not taking up that part of the question and I welcome the opportunity to do it now. Senator Alston's basic proposition is that the Australian economy and Australia's economic management are essentially identical to those in the United States. Senator Alston must have been in a time warp for the last five years because that would have been a fair comment to make of what happened when John Howard was Treasurer and he brought in that irresponsible Budget in 1982 which lumbered this Government with a prospective Budget deficit of nearly $10 billion and what has been happening under the Reagan Administration for the last five years. If Senator Alston could emerge from his five-year time warp he would realise that an essential difference between economic management in Australia and economic management in the United States is that we have a fiscally responsible government which has brought in a balanced Budget and the Reagan Administration continues to run enormous Budget deficits, I think, of the order of $200 billion or $220 billion a year, and as of this time has shown no indication of cleaning it up. In other words, the Reagan Administration is behaving in exactly the same way as the Fraser-Howard Administration behaved towards the end of its term. If its record during the recent election campaign is any indication, it would reimpose that on Australia should it get the opportunity to do so.

—I refer the Minister for Transport and Communications to the reports referring to the heavy demand for seats by international travellers to Australia. I ask the Minister: Firstly, what action has been taken, or is being taken, to cope with the current heavy demand? Secondly, what steps have been taken to provide international airline passengers inbound seats to Australia to cover that demand?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Evans Sen The Hon G.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —Every year at this time, with the onset of our spring and summer, the seasonal level of inbound traffic causes problems for passengers and airlines alike. This year the problem has been exacerbated due to the rapid growth in inbound traffic levels, which has been greater than anticipated. Given this pattern of peaks and troughs, airlines have traditionally responded to peaks in the level of demand by scheduling additional, or so-called supplementary, services over the peak periods. This is possible with the relevant government approvals under the various bilateral air service agreements to which Australia is a party. Scheduling of supplementary flights has happened this year as well with Qantas Airways Ltd having committed an additional 43 supplementary services over the period October 1987 to February 1988, with a further 19 proposed. This makes a total of 62 compared with 52 for the same period last year. In addition, my Department has approved a further 53 supplementary services by foreign carriers, with another 12 under consideration and further applications from foreign carriers are also expected.

ANSWER.PARA: I should say that charter flights are particularly well suited to deal with periods of seasonal peaks and special events and the new charter guidelines which I announced in the aviation statement on 7 October could certainly encourage such charter operations. As regards additional scheduled capacity, which is important for the longer term as supplementaries are only something one does in a short term way, negotiations are currently under way, either at government or airline level, with seven countries, namely, Thailand, Hong Kong, Canada, the United States of America, Malaysia, Singapore and the Netherlands. Qantas, for its part, is re-examining its services in the light of the heavier than anticipated inbound tourism flows with a view to identifying whether additional short term leasing capacity is required. The company has advised me that it is looking at leasing a B747 Jumbo and a B767 for up to six months.

Finally, the question nevertheless arises as to whether scheduled capacity will be adequate to deal with the expected boost of tourism in 1988. My Department will be discussing with Tourism Australia, the former Australian Tourist Commission, likely levels of demand from major markets for 1988 with a view to pinpointing problem areas and the action that will be necessary to overcome them.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Vanstone Sen A.E.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Justice to Senator Crowley's question of him yesterday about the judgment of Justice Murray in the Family Court of South Australia from which she quoted an extract. Has the Minister yet studied the whole judgment of Justice Murray? If so, I ask whether he has noted the evidence given by the wife about her plans for the future in the following terms:

QUESTION.PARA: She states that if she cannot get part time work she will stay full time at home. In her oral evidence in chief she told me that she now intends to start a family forthwith and has made arrangements to have an IUD removed within the next two weeks. She says that she now wishes to become a full time mother and stay at home, but nevertheless wishes to complete her examinations and continue her part time work until September next.

That is, this September. Is it not clear that Justice Murray's judgment was influenced by the wife's evidence to this effect and that Senator Crowley's selective quotation from the judgment is an unfair and inappropriate interpretation of it? In these circumstances, will the Attorney-General, without delay, repudiate Senator Crowley's suggestion that Justice Murray should be removed from office?

TALK.START.PARA: —At no stage did I suggest that the judge concerned ought to be removed from office. In fact, I deliberately refrained from doing so and I have no intention of adding further to the answer I gave yesterday.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. Will the Minister explain to the Senate why yesterday he was prepared to offer a comment in the form of an opinion on the basis of a section of the judgment? Having had the judgment provided to him, he is now not prepared to comment further on allegations made that a judge should be removed on the basis of one judgment.
—I have not had an opportunity to read the full judgment or the transcript to which Senator Vanstone has referred.

—I refer the Minister representing the Treasurer to the high numbers of transactions on world stock exchanges this week and the consequent media hysteria about possible effects on economic activity. Is the Minister aware that Australia was experiencing an economic slump with rising unemployment as early as 1928, some 12 to 18 months ahead of the Wall Street crash in October 1929? Are the linkages between financial markets and the real economy overstated? What policy measures do governments now have in the era since World War II at their disposal to stabilise economic activity over the course of business cycles?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Walsh Sen The Hon P.A.

TALK.START.PARA: —On balance, the evidence very heavily is in the direction that Senator Maguire indicated; that is, that the stock market crash of 1929 was more a symptom of what was wrong with, if not the world economy, a large section of the world economy than a cause of it. Particularly for some European countries the boom of 1928-29 may have contributed substantially to the economic problems of Europe, and particularly of Germany, because capital-in the days when just about all of the world was on the gold standard-had been flowing out of Europe for speculation in Wall Street. It could reasonably be argued that in the era before October 1929 that was an aggravation at least, if not a cause, of the economic problems which afflicted most of Western Europe: the cause of the problem was the boom itself rather than the collapse which inevitably succeeded it.

ANSWER.PARA: Since I have been asked this question I should perhaps take the opportunity to correct a tentative opinion which I gave yesterday in response to Senator Stone's query of what happened to the British economy after the bursting of the South Sea bubble in 1720. I said that I thought it had been followed by a fairly prolonged recession. That was the conventional wisdom of a number of general historians, but there seems to be agreement among modern economic historians that the financial crisis associated with the bursting of the South Sea bubble was largely quarantined to the markets for public debt and quasi-public debt instruments and, of course, to those persons who were heavily involved in speculation, gambling or whatever one likes to call it, and that the crisis did not overflow into the general financial system and did not engender a major recession in the real economy, as distinct from the casino economy of stock exchanges from time to time. In particular, I refer to an article published last year in the Economic History Review and written by Julian Hoppit, which, among other things, says:
When the Bubble burst in August 1720 the price of assets in public credit plummeted and notable heads rolled, ensuring the place of the Bubble in the common folklore of English economic history.
He went on to cite the very major decline in the shares of some prominent companies, including the East India Company, and in the Bank of England itself. He continued:

The crisis of the national debt was catastrophic. But it is too easy to assume that when the Bubble burst that the whole of trade and industry was afflicted by a similar fit and languished in the depths of depression. Given the extent of the collapse, what is surprising is how few businesses seem to have been pushed to the wall. The number of bankrupts to be found in 1720 and 1721 . . . suggest that there is only limited validity to the claim that `There was a very marked contraction of business after the South Sea Bubble burst'.

I table from that article a couple of pages which show in similar vein that a more disciplined examination of the economic history, as distinct from the social history, shows that the economic fallout from the bursting of the South Sea bubble on the real economy was in fact rather limited.

TALK.START.PARA: —I direct my question to the Minister Assisting the Minister for Community Services and Health. I refer the Minister to the May economic statement decision to remove certain treatments of skin cancers and warts from the medical benefits schedule. I ask the Minister: Is it a fact that this has resulted in items 3330, 3331, 3332, 3338, 3342 and 3346 being removed? Did these numbers include treatment for the removal of venereal warts which have now been implicated as a precursor to cervical cancer and have consequently been declared a `notifiable disease' by the Department? How can the treatment of a notifiable disease be treated as not rebatable under Medicare and why has the Government failed to respond to advice from the medical profession regarding this clear anomaly?

—I have some information available here to answer Senator Patterson's questions, but I do not have all the detail with respect to particular items in the Medicare benefits schedule. I will get those from Dr Neal Blewett and provide them to her as soon as possible. It is the case that the removal of keratoses and warts was affected by the May decision. The reason was that the removal of keratoses and warts was originally difficult, time consuming and done by specialists. Changed technology has meant that the majority of removals are now done rapidly and painlessly by general practitioners within a consultation. The old fee was for a procedure; the new fee is the appropriate consultation fee only. A separate item to cover removal of large numbers of difficult warts, anal and genital, is to be considered for inclusion in the schedule. Items for removal of skin cancers have not changed. That is the information I have available and, as I said, I will get more detailed information from Dr Blewett for Senator Patterson.

—I refer the Minister representing the Minister for Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs to my question without notice on 7 October inquiring about details of a reported shortfall in key mining personnel, especially in the gold mining industry, and possible Government action in the Department to overcome the problem. I now refer the Minister to a further article in the Brisbane Courier-Mail on 20 October which reports that Queensland and interstate mining companies have joined the Chamber of Mines of Western Australia (Inc.) in recruiting mining personnel overseas. I ask the Minister to provide details of the number of migrants who have entered Australia or who have approval of entry pending to meet this reported shortfall and particularly to report on the exact number of approvals of people who are of South African origin.

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Reynolds Sen The Hon M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I do recall Senator McKiernan's question of a couple of weeks back. I have some further information for him about this matter. The Department is currently negotiating a local arrangement for group nomination of 50 senior skilled personnel with the Chamber of Mines in Western Australia subject to the industry documenting domestic recruitment effort and training. This is seen as an interim arrangement only, as the Department is seeking to secure an industry based arrangement to meet shortfalls of skilled personnel nationally. This industry-wide arrangement is currently the subject of consultations between the Department and the Australian Mining Industry Council. Special negotiated arrangements are available to industries where occupational skills are in short supply in the domestic labour market. These arrangements allow streamlined processing of employer nominations at the Australian end in return for an industry commitment to the recruitment and training of Australian residents.

ANSWER.PARA: The Department, in consultation with the Department of Employment, Education and Training, recognises the following skills as being in short supply: geologists, metallurgists, mining engineers and senior managerial personnel. The newspaper articles also mention that most applicants recruited are likely to come from South Africa, Britain and Canada and that delay could occur at the overseas end. This is entirely consistent with the Government's policies of encouraging global recruitment. Global processing priorities give family and humanitarian entry the highest priority and this, of course, applies across all countries. I will refer the second part of the question to Minister Young for his precise answer on the figures.

TALK.START.PARA: —I again ask whether the Minister will table the document from which she was reading.
—Will the Minister table the document?
—Yes, Mr President.
—The Minister will table the document.

QUESTION.SPEAKER: Short Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I refer the Minister for Home Affairs to the platform of the Australian Labor Party as approved by the Thirty-seventh National Conference in July 1986. Chapter five, section B, paragraph 17 of the platform, under the heading `Constitutional Reform' and the sub-heading `National Symbols', states that Labor will seek:

QUESTION.PARA: In the context of the preparations for Bicentennial celebrations, to initiate and support moves to establish with popular acceptance an Australian flag, national day and national anthem which will more distinctly reflect our national independence and identity.

As the commencement of the Bicentennial is now less than three months away, I ask the Minister: What steps has the Government taken since July 1986 to implement that part of the party platform? What additional steps does it propose to take?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Ray Sen The Hon R.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —It is rather a pity that Senator Short failed to read the preamble to the platform, which is the most crucial three or four paragraphs. I shall read it for his benefit. It states:

ANSWER.PARA: Conference recognises that the Platform of the Party represents short and long term aspirations of the ALP.
The programme for each 3 years of Labor government will continue to be drawn from the Platform.
Therefore, Conference requests that the FPLP will in preparing the program for the next three years-
(a) continue to give priority to economic recovery, a fair distribution of the benefits of economic growth and the improvements in the welfare and standards of living of Australian people; and
(b) Implement other platforms and policies according to a time scale to be determined having regard to the above overall priorities of the Party.

That sums up our attitude to the platform. There are 280 pages odd in our platform. The priorities overall in that platform will be determined by the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party. Coming to the specific part of the honourable senator's question, at this stage no steps have been taken to implement that proposal. Given the other priorities around, it may not even come up with the priority list in this three years of government. Therefore, Senator Short will not be able to go around the country patriotically bleating and stirring up all the emotions he would like to. He will not be able to run a redneck campaign on how we are not really monarchists or anything else. I am sorry to disappoint him but at this stage there are no particular plans on the drawing board. That is not to say that there will never be such plans, but I certainly think that there are higher priorities than that item in the platform. If the honourable senator asks me to table the document from which I am quoting I will refuse, because I will need it in a later debate.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I thank the Minister for his answer. Whilst I accept that normally there is a certain degree of flexibility in the Party's platform, this item relates specifically to preparations for the Bicentennial celebrations which, obviously, have a fixed time limit. Am I to take it from the Minister's answer that the Government will be taking no notice at all of that part of the platform?

—I repeat that the priorities for any Government activity are determined by the Federal Parliamentary Labor Party, with reference to that policy. It is quite clear that no government could implement over a three-year period 280 pages of platform changes. It is up to us to determine those priorities. It is a right given to us by the Australian Labor Party Conference-carried last time without a dissenting voice.

QUESTION.BLOCK.TITLE: ENGLISH AS A SECOND LANGUAGE PROGRAM

TALK.START.PARA: —My question is directed to the Minister representing the Minister for Employment, Education and Training. I ask: Since the Government's decision a year ago to dismantle the English as a second language in schools program, can the Minister assure honourable senators that each individual State and Territory is giving as great or greater priority to English as a second language as it was given under the previous ESL program? Has the Minister received representations from ethnic organisations requesting the reinstatement of the ESL program? What funds has the Commonwealth Government made available to the Western Australian Government to maintain the ESL program or to fund the multicultural support unit in the Western Australian Department of Education? What steps will the Government take to ensure that the States maintain the English as a second language program as a high priority?

—The honourable senator is ill-advised in that there was never any decision to dismantle the ESL program. What happened was that there was a reduction in one aspect of the ESL program in the year before last. If the honourable senator had been listening to the answer to the question on the national language policy she would have learnt not only that the ESL program is not being dismantled but also that the new arrivals element of that program-the most important element from the point of view of establishing language competence at the outset-is to be doubled in the next financial year, with further increases in the following two years, and that the restored level of the ESL general support program is to be maintained in real terms. As to the questions about specific allocations for Western Australia, I do not have figures for Western Australia's share of the greatly increased funds with me. I will seek those for the honourable senator from Mr Dawkins.

—Mr President, I ask a supplementary question. I refer to the last part of my question in which I asked what steps the Government will take to ensure that the States maintain the English as a second language program as a high priority. The ESL program relates to programs in schools. The additional funds for the new arrivals program refers to adult migrant education, which is quite apart from English as a second language program in schools.

—I must correct a comment made by the honourable senator in her supplementary question. The new arrivals element of the ESL program is for school age children. It is not a part of the adult migrant education program, which is a separate program administered through the Department of Immigration, Local Government and Ethnic Affairs. All Commonwealth education programs funded under the special purpose programs are funded with a very high accountability requirement. Obviously, all funds allocated to the States under the ESL program-be they the new arrivals element or the general support element-will be properly accounted for in agreements with those States. All States add to those funds according to their own priorities, but I am not aware of any withdrawal of or reduction in funds in the ESL area by the States. In fact, I think in the case of New South Wales and South Australia there have been increases in those elements.

—Is the Minister representing the Minister for Veterans' Affairs aware that the New South Wales Department of Housing regards money received by veterans in the form of a disability pension as income in assessing rent levels for veterans in State-owned housing, while Federal authorities such as the Australian Taxation Office regard such payments as compensation? Is the Minister aware also that an 85-year-old veteran is being threatened with eviction from his house due to this anomalous interpretation of the pension? Can the Minister explain whether this approach is justified and whether the Federal Government supports such treatment of returned servicemen and servicewomen?

—I am certainly not aware of the circumstances described by Senator Brownhill. I certainly believe that the situation he describes sounds very much like an anomaly. I will ask Mr Humphreys, as Minister, to investigate the matter and to take it up with his counterpart in New South Wales.

—My question is addressed to the Minister representing the Minister for the Arts, Sport, the Environment, Tourism and Territories. I draw the Minister's attention to recent Press speculation about the number of tourists visiting Australia. I particularly draw his attention to a small article in today's Age entitled `Travel Boom'. In that article it was suggested that tourists from Japan alone could number 600,000 by 1995 and possibly one million by the end of the century. Does the Government believe that these projected figures are possible? Will the Government seek to encourage more employment of Japanese speaking persons in the tourist industry as well as the provision of signs, et cetera at major tourist attractions in Japanese and other languages?

ANSWER.SPEAKER: Richardson Sen The Hon G.F.

TALK.START.PARA: —I have seen that article in the Age and the estimate of 600,000 would seem to be a reasonable estimate for Japanese tourists by 1995. It is worth noting that the figures for August of this year look like they are almost double those for last August. The figures for August this year have gone up to 20,000. So the number of tourists coming from Japan is rising at a staggering rate. At the moment the growth rate is something like 25 per cent per annum. Given that tourism throughout the rest of the world is pretty static, that is an extraordinary figure. This year we will receive 195,000 Japanese tourists. That figure is up 34 per cent on 1986. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Discussion of Matter of Public Importance

INTERJECT.SPEAKER: The PRESIDENT

TALK.START.PARA: —I inform the Senate that, at 8.30 a.m. today, two senators submitted letters in accordance with standing order 64. INTERJECT.PARA: Pursuant to standing order 64, I propose that the following mater of public importance be submitted to the Senate for discussion:

The refusal of the Government to admit that the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap has an offensive role in a nuclear war fighting scenario plus surveillance functions other than monitoring and verification of arms control agreements, and the need for the Government to now give one year's notice of termination to the Government of the United States in accordance with, and in respect of, the Agreement relating to the base.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That so much of the Standing Orders be suspended as would prevent Senator Chaney moving a motion for votes to take place at the end of the discussion of the matter of public importance on the matter of public importance as if it were a statement of urgency in a motion of urgency and on a motion of urgency submitted by Senator Tambling.

Mr President, if I may speak at no great length on that motion to suspend Standing Orders: as you have already indicated to the Senate, both the Opposition and Senator Vallentine sought to bring matters before the Senate-the Opposition in the form of an urgency motion and Senator Vallentine in the form of a matter of public importance. Coincidentally, the subject matter of both matters being brought forward was basically the same. Senator Vallentine was expressing the views which you have just read to the Senate. The important element of that is the suggestion that the Government should give one year's notice of termination to the Government of the United States of America in accordance with and in respect of the agreement relating to the Pine Gap joint facility.

Of course, the proposition which the Opposition was seeking to put forward was the complete opposite of that. It is the concern of the Opposition that we should not have a debate in this place which reflects an opinion which is not the opinion of the Senate. It would be impossible in the course of a matter of public importance to establish precisely what is the opinion of the Senate. By bringing forward an urgency motion, it is possible to get an expression of the view of the Senate. Given that the matter of public importance and the urgency motion go to matters which are fundamentally important to Australia, namely to the defence of this country, to the maintenance of our alliance with the United States and to the maintenance of joint defence facilities which, in the view of the Opposition, and in the official view of the Government, go the promotion of peace and disarmament, we believe that there should be a clear expression of view by this Senate. For that reason, if the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders is carried, I propose to move:

That, at the conclusion of the discussion of the matter of public importance, whether or not the time for the discussion has expired, the President shall read to the Senate the following matter of urgency submitted to the President by Senator Tambling:
That, in the opinion of the Senate, the following is a matter of urgency:

The need for the Senate to express its support for the maintenance of Australia's alliance with the United States and to reaffirm the basis for the operation of the joint defence facilities in Australia in light of recent demonstrations at Pine Gap.
and then put the following questions:
That the statement of Senator Vallentine's matter of public importance be agreed to.
That the motion of urgency submitted by Senator Tambling be agreed to.

Mr President, if that procedure is followed, the Senate will have an opportunity to vote and to express a view on the expressions of view which are brought forward by Senator Vallentine and on the motion of urgency which has been submitted by Senator Tambling. We believe that it is important that the Senate should have that opportunity and, hence, this motion for the suspension of Standing Orders.

We are in a situation where we must consider the fundamental questions of our relationship with the United States and whether we should maintain these bases. Whether one is looking at the view of the Joint Parliamentary Committee on Foreign Affairs, Defence and Trade, whether one is looking at the views expressed by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) or whether one is looking at the views expressed by John Howard on behalf of the Opposition, it is common ground that these facilities are essential to maintaining the capacity of the Western alliance and scrutinising what is happening in the nuclear area. The facilities are an essential part of deterrence as they are an essential part of monitoring any agreements for the reduction of nuclear arms.

This matter is very important. One should not underestimate the significance of this debate. There is a fundamental divide between the great mass of Australians who support the cause of peace and nuclear disarmament, but who believe that both peace and nuclear disarmament require in the short and immediate term the maintenance of effective deterrence. They believe that in the longer term the capacity to achieve genuine disarmament and, hence, genuine peace should be on a phased, mutual and verified basis. These are the simple conditions which are supported by the Government, by the Opposition and by the great mass of the people of Australia.

A significant minority-certainly significant in terms of the amount of publicity they can attract-advance propositions which we believe are dangerous for Australia and for peace and which we do not believe can pass unchallenged. We believe that some people who are elected to this Parliament-the nuclear disarmament senators and the Australian Democrat senators-are expressing views which we believe are utterly destructive of our national interest. We certainly believe that it is essential that there should be a very clear statement from the Parliament. That need is further compounded by the fact that within the Australian Labor Party there is a significant minority which is agitating for change. In fact, as Senator Tambling will indicate later, supporters of the present Government- members of this Parliament-were part of the agitation at Alice Springs, and were seeking changes which we would classify as attempts to weaken the Western alliance, changes which are clearly contrary to the policies of the Government that they support.

It is the wish of the Opposition that there should be no long delay. In moving the motion for the suspension of Standing Orders, we do not seek to pre-empt the debate on the matters of substance that are before the Senate. For that reason I do not intend to extend my remarks on this matter, which we regard as fundamental, and to which we seek to achieve the maximum possible positive response from the Government. We think it is very important that it should be clearly understood in the United States, as it should be clearly understood in the Soviet Union-as, indeed, it should be clearly understood in all parts of the world-that we have a clear and definite view as to where the interests of our country lie and where the best hopes for peace and for the security of the world lie.

I have moved a motion for the suspension of Standing Orders. I believe it will enable the debate to proceed completely in accord with the procedures which would have been followed with respect to the matter of public importance. In other words, the matter of public importance will still be led off by Senator Vallentine. There will be the same number of speakers and a full two hours will be available for the debate. The important difference is that at the end of the debate we will have a clear expression of view from the Senate which will prevent those who hold a unilateralist view from promoting that as being the substantial view of this Parliament. This is a procedural move which is aimed at ensuring that there is no confusion in the community, whether within or outside Australia, about what views are held in this Parliament about where the best interests of Australia lie.

I commend this motion to the Senate. I hope that it will be accepted without debate, which would delay the debate on the substantial matters which will be before us: the matter of public importance brought forward by Senator Vallentine and the motion of urgency which will be moved by Senator Tambling. I believe that it is in our national interest that we should follow this procedure.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I begin my remarks on Pine Gap, I have to challenge Senator Chaney's statement that a significant minority of Australians, other than the Government or the Opposition, hold certain views. There are many Government members who are very embarrassed by their Government's lack of resolve on these questions. I will elaborate on members of the Government later in my remarks.

SPEECH.PARA: I must also challenge Senator Chaney on his use of the term `unilateralist', which he uses repeatedly. It is totally unfounded and inaccurate, and he knows it. People in the peace movement are arguing for multilateral, verifiable disarmament-just as Senator Chaney is. He will not accept that proposition because he does not want to acknowledge that we are not talking about unilateral disarmament. It would be absolute nonsense to do so. We are talking about mutually verifiable, multilateral disarmament. I want that to be heard by the community in Australia. It is most important that that be understood. What we are doing by challenging the Australian Government's involvement with the United States (US) is saying that we should have some influence with our great friend and ally in areas in which we are meant to have some influence. That is not to say that Australia is not actively involved in multilateral disarmament negotiations at the conference on disarmament in Geneva, and in New York. Pressure must be put on all the super-powers to disarm their nuclear weapons. The peace movement in Australia holds that position very strongly. I totally refute and reject Senator Chaney's allegations that there is an element of unilateralism in what we are suggesting.

Pine Gap is a United States spy base. There are three roles which Pine Gap undertakes, only one of which our Government will acknowledge. It acknowledges that Pine Gap is useful in monitoring and verification. That is no doubt a statement with which the Opposition would agree. I remind the Senate that the arms control agreements which Pine Gap is meant to monitor were not even in place when the Pine Gap base was first established in the late 1960s. Arms control agreements such as the SALT agreements and the anti-ballistic missile treaties were not even in place then. They are very much an afterthought, and are benign justifications for this spy base's existence on Australian soil. Pine Gap was established as a spy base to serve the interests of the United States Government. That is its main role. It was its main role in the 1960s, and it remains its main role to this day. So let not that role-the only one that the Government admits to-be used to justify the existence of that base on Australian soil.

There are other ways in which we must organise international and independent monitoring and verification of arms control agreements. We have now a situation similar to that of giving the umpire's whistle to the captain of one of the football teams engaged in a game. We are allowing the United States to use Australia soil to do its own monitoring and verification of its so-called enemy. Incidentally, this makes the Soviet Union an Australian enemy as well. There is no need for that situation to have developed. Australia should be engaged in international, independent monitoring of arms control and disarmament agreements. Many proposals have been put forward by countries such as Sweden, Mexico and India which are not directly associated with either of the two super-power blocs and which have offered the technical skills necessary to establish an independent international disarmament monitoring agency. That is what Australia should be doing: it should be working with the countries that are not part of either one super-power bloc or the other. Independent monitoring is the only kind of monitoring that is effective and worth while.

It is most important that we look at the two other roles of the Pine Gap facility. It has two very important roles. It is a ground control station for the US signals intelligence satellites. Its first role is to receive and transmit information from satellites, as well as from technological and human operatives in the field. Most significantly, Pine Gap controls the Rhyolite satellites stationed in pairs in geostationary orbits. These Rhyolite satellite systems intercept electronic signals, including national and international telephone and radio communications. They suck up, like a vacuum cleaner, a wide range of communications from throughout the world and beam them back to Pine Gap for transmission to the United States of America. This information includes military, commercial, political and domestic information from both allied and non-allied countries. The information which is sent back to the United States is not controlled by the Australian Government. We have no control over that flow of information; nor do we have any control over the use to which that information is put.

This brings me to the second very important role of the Pine Gap facility, a role to which our Government will not admit. The information which is gathered is used to site potential targets in the Soviet Union and wherever else the United States sees fit, not only for the purposes of nuclear war fighting, but also to engage in low intensity conflict, as the United States does in other parts of the world. By intercepting radar signals, the United States is able to map the location of targets, such as the Soviet early warning, air defence, anti-ballistic missile systems, air bases, satellite tracking and control stations, and ships at sea. This information is used to plan attack strategies for fighting nuclear or conventional war.

Those roles, the gathering of the information and the use to which that information is put, are in the control of the United States military command. Australia has no control over either the gathering of that information or the use to which that information is put. Those two functions are the main functions of that Pine Gap spy base. It is there to serve the interests of the United States Government and it is not in the interests of the Australian Government and the Australian people to have it there. In fact, in the Prime Minister's speech of 6 June 1984, the Australian Government finally admitted officially what everybody has known for a very long time-that that base and other United States bases on Australian soil are Soviet nuclear targets. That is the first time it was publicly admitted. It is very obvious that, if these bases are used to gather information that is useful to the United States in targeting Soviet nuclear weapons, those bases will be nuclear targets from the Soviet point of view. Our Government has admitted that, but has said that the benefits outweigh the risks. What benefits, for goodness sake, is it talking about? The benefits of being nuclear targets! It is an outrageous statement for the Government to dare to make, but it made it and needs to be challenged on that strongly.

Only a couple of weeks ago, Kim Beazley reiterated on ABC radio that the population centres near these bases were very small. It is like saying to the people of Alice Springs, near Pine Gap, to the people of Exmouth, near North West Cape and to the people of Woomera and Port Augusta, near the Nurrungar facility, that they are expendable and do not matter, that their government does not care about their survival and that it is quite prepared to allow them to be direct nuclear targets in the case of an international nuclear exchange. The Australian Government does not care about its own people. How can Senator Chaney get up and say that, in the interests of Australia, we need these bases here? What a load of absolute codswallop.

The secrecy surrounding the bases is another major problem. I will quote the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade when he was the Leader of the Opposition in 1981. Mr Hayden and the then Deputy Leader of the Opposition, Lionel Bowen, went on a grand tour of four of the 11 facilities, all of which are essential to the United States military command in Australia. They went to Pine Gap, Nurrungar, North West Cape and Smithfield. In part, this is what Bill Hayden had to say about the secrecy surrounding the operation of these bases. This is from the Sydney Morning Herald of 19 March 1981:
The Opposition Leader, Mr Hayden, called yesterday for a removal of secrecy from Pine Gap, the United States strategic base in central Australia and a public declaration of its function.

Hear, hear! I would support him in that call. It is funny that that has not happened since the Labor Party got into government. The article said that, although the then Leader of the Opposition had assurances that Pine Gap was not part of a weapons system-and I will come back to that later-he said that `the general purposes for which these sorts of bases have been established should be declared to the public'. The general purposes for which these bases have been established are the gathering of information and the use of that information for targeting the Soviet Union with nuclear weapons, not monitoring and verification-the establishment of that base had nothing to do with that. The article continues:
Mr Hayden put the onus for secrecy squarely on the shoulders of the Australian Government rather than the United States.
Again I find myself agreeing with Mr Hayden. The article continues:
`There is a pretty clear obsessive preoccupation with secrecy,' he said. `The ground rules for secrecy rest very much with the Australian authorities.'
Mr Hayden said that he believed that there was a `strong case' for a revision of secrecy classifications surrounding Pine Gap.

That is very interesting stuff from Mr Hayden when Leader of the Opposition. It is a pity that he has not followed it through. On 9 March 1977, still when he was Leader of the Opposition, Mr Hayden asked the Prime Minister, in a question upon notice, whether it was a fact that under the UKUSA agreement, the National Security Agency operated electronic intercept stations in Australia. Mr Fraser replied:

The policy of Australian governments has been not to provide information that might confirm or deny speculation about this subject. This remains the policy. I therefore do not propose to answer the honourable member's question.

Earlier this year, just to test out our Government, which prides itself on being much more open than former conservative governments, I asked exactly the same question in this place of the present Government. Do you know what? Surprise, surprise, I got exactly the same answer-in other words, `we are not going to tell you anything'. That is a deplorable situation.

Further to that, I must remind the Senate and the people of Australia that answers to parliamentary questions on the subject of United States bases in Australia have been dealt with in the most insulting way recently. Questions that I have asked about North West Cape or Pine Gap or questions that Senator Coulter has asked about Nurrungar have been replied to in the most insulting terms, quoting the Prime Minister's statement of 6 June 1984 which told us absolutely nothing that was not generally known except that the bases were a nuclear target-the first official confirmation of that fact. We have to take Mr Hayden to task and remind him of his concern about the secrecy surrounding these bases, which still exists.

Not only has Kim Beazley talked about the people of Alice Springs, North West Cape and Woomera being expendable-they happen to be nuclear targets-but the Government has no civil defence plans in place in case nuclear weapons do start to fly. I believe that the Defence Department is working on such civil defence plans, but what a waste of energy that is. The best way to protect the people of Alice Springs, Exmouth and Woomera, and the people of the world, is to make sure that nuclear weapons are dismantled, East and West. That is what the peace movement in Australia is calling for. We are not interested in this ridiculous nonsense about serving the interests of Australia by having such bases on Australian soil, or even serving the interests of the Western alliance. We need to think beyond that kind of bloc mentality. If we continue to think in terms of East versus West, sooner or later those nuclear weapons and other weapons of mass destruction will be used by accident, if not by design. We must work very hard to get rid of those weapons. That is the agenda of the peace movement in Australia. I believe that our Government is allowing Australian soil to be used in the most immoral way, by one super-power plotting and planning against the other. It is immoral that we allow our soil to be used for these purposes.

I want now to talk about the Nuremberg principles, which were invoked by the people who conducted a peaceful week of educational and process activities in the vicinity of Pine Gap. The Nuremberg principles were successfully invoked and I would like to remind the Senate about the sixth principle, which clearly lists crimes punishable under international law. They are crimes against peace, planning, preparation, initiation or waging of war of aggression. I am shortening this so that I can get to the notice of eviction in the next few minutes. The principle includes the participation in a common plan or conspiracy for the accomplishment of any of the acts just mentioned. That is exactly what the Australian Government is involved in-the participation in a common plan or conspiracy for the accomplishment of the planning and preparation for the waging of war. That is what that base at Pine Gap is all about. It goes on further to list war crimes and crimes against humanity.

There could be no greater crime against humanity than the potential use of nuclear weapons against human beings, and these nuclear weapons are targeted indiscriminately at people in the Soviet Union through the information collected and beamed back to the United States through that base at Pine Gap. It is outrageous that the Government then has the gall to tell us that the benefits of our involvement with this alliance outweigh the risk. The risk to humanity is total.

The second Nuremberg principle, which was successfully invoked by people at the peaceful and non-violent week of action in Alice Springs and Pine Gap, was principle No. 4. This relates to the notion of individual responsibility. These Nuremberg principles arose out of the war crimes tribunals after the Second World War when nazi criminals tried to plead an abdication of individual responsibility in sending millions of Jews to the extermination camps. They said, `We were merely following orders'. That line of defence was shown to be totally inadequate and morally unjustified. Under principle 4, individuals are obliged to act if they see that their Government is engaged in activities which are against the common good or engaged in crimes punishable under international law-the crimes that I have just listed such as conspiring with, planning or participating in the common plan to wage war against humanity.

Seeing that our Government is allowing Australian soil to be used for such diabolical and immoral acts, many Australians have considered that they have a moral obligation to break domestic law, the law of trespass against the Commonwealth of Australia on land which should be available to all Australians. That base should not be there under any circumstances whatsoever. It is serving no Australian purpose and, I believe, no purpose for world peace either.

Many people were prepared to go to the gates of Pine Gap. We were denied access to the commanding officer of the base. We wanted to deliver a notice of eviction which will be circulated to all members of parliament in the next day or two, so that they will all be able to have a good look at it. It was directed to the Government of the United States of America and the Government of the Commonwealth of Australia by people of Australia. I know that there has been some criticism that we cannot be said to be speaking for all people of Australia, and that is true; but we are speaking for hundreds of thousands of Australians who feel that it is immoral for the Australian Government to allow Australian soil to be used by the United States Government to target citizens in the Soviet Union with nuclear weapons. So people decided that they would be prepared to commit civil disobedience when they were denied access to that facility to present their notice of eviction. I seek leave to incorporate the notice of eviction, which is a couple of pages long, in Hansard.
Leave granted.
The notice of eviction read as follows-

On behalf of the People of Australia we hereby order you to quit this place following the expiry on this day of one year's notice given on the nineteenth of October 1986 pursuant to the Agreement dated the nineteenth of October 1977 between the governments of the United States of America and the Commonwealth of Australia:
That whereas,

The land comprising the Joint Defence Space Research Facility at Pine Gap and its neighbourhood has been declared a Prohibited Area under the Defence (Special Undertakings) Act 1952, thus depriving the traditional Aboriginal owners and custodians of this land of their rights pertaining to their ownership, use and enjoyment of this land, and preventing them from carrying out their customary obligations to maintain and conserve this land, and preserve the welfare of the traditional owners and custodians, their families and all people who enter this land;
And whereas,

The declaration of Pine Gap and its neighbourhood as a Prohibited Area has deprived us, the Australian People, of our legal rights to use and enjoy this land, and has infringed our civil liberties by imposing harsh and oppressive restrictions on our freedom of movement, action and speech on this land;
And whereas,

The presence of this Facility has exposed the residents of the town of Alice Springs and its environs to the imminent threat of nuclear attack, as acknowledged by the Australian, United States and Soviet Union governments, and that such an attack would result in the immediate death of hundreds, and the lingering death of thousands, of Alice Springs residents;
And whereas,

The involvement of the Pine Gap Facility in spying on internal Australian electromagnetic communications, the refusal of the United States government to divulge the actual role and extent of Pine Gap's operations, and the complicity of the Australian government in maintaining the extreme secrecy of the Facility, have resulted in the deception of the Australian People;
And whereas,

The use of the Pine Gap Facility to spy on Australia, nations in the Pacific region and other countries, and to prepare for nuclear war between foreign powers to be conducted on Australian soil, constitutes a serious breach of the sovereignty and independence of this nation and of neighbouring states;
And whereas,

The facility at Pine Gap is used to support the destabilising and warfighting foreign policies of the government of the United States of America which have directly caused the further escalation of the nuclear arms race, the growth of hostility between the superpowers and the increased probability of the outbreak of nuclear war;
And that whereas.

For the above and other reasons, the presence of the Facility at Pine Gap threatens the liberty, peace and survival of the Aboriginal owners and custodians of this land, the residents of Alice Springs, the People of Australia and world humanity;

We, the people of Australia, hereby serve this Notice of Eviction on the governments of the United States of America and the Commonwealth of Australia, in consequence of which the government of the United States of America will be required to quit this place forthwith;
And that forthwith.

All United States and Australian personnel are required to cease working in, and to quit, Pine Gap and its neighbourhood, including all employees of the National Reconnaissance Office, the National Security Agency, the Central Intelligence Agency, the Australian Security Intelligence Organization, the Australian Protective Service and other United States or Australian government security, intelligence, military or defence agencies, and including all employees of private companies contracted by the United States or Australian governments to provide technical, administrative, support or other services to the operations of the Facility;
And that forthwith.

The governments of the United States of America and the Commonwealth of Australia are required to remove from Pine Gap all United States and Australian government property relating to Signals Intelligence, Communications Intelligence, Electronic Intelligence and any other operations carried out at the Facility, and including all electronic, telemetric, electrical and mechanical equipment, all buildings and facilities used to accommodate, operate, service and maintain equipment and personnel, all computers, all antennae, all radomes, all security devices, all gates and all fences.
And that forthwith.
The governments of the United States of America and the Commonwealth of Australia close Pine Gap.
Signed on behalf of the People of Australia, on the this eighteenth day of October 1987.

TALK.START.PARA: —Thank you, Mr Acting Deputy President. I believe that we should turn to the notions that the United States Government actually has about its flexible options. As I was preparing to talk about these flexible options, finally delineated carefully by President Carter in Presidential Decision No. 59 in 1979, I found Mr Hayden speaking very clearly about this matter, so I thought I would quote Mr Hayden. Rather than have it in my words, we can have it in his. In a speech that he made to the National Press Club on 14 April 1981, he stated:

SPEECH.PARA: This process culminated in Presidential Decision No. 59, signed by President Carter nine months ago. This decision, and associated planning documents, encompasses a most elaborate framework of strategic options, ranging from very limited nuclear strikes, through counterforce strikes, to full-scale nuclear war.
At the heart of the new strategy is the belief that technology allows nuclear war to be managed like any other, to be graduated and manipulated. Most of all, it contemplates victory.
It is a strategy that reverts to the frightening belief that nuclear weapons are just like any other weapons, to be used as instruments of policy, as and when necessary.
These elaborate scenarios, with their flawed view that wars are winnable if the right nuclear weapons are at hand, means that the arms race is wide open to the newest and the latest.
In reality, what is happening is that political leaders are rapidly being pressured into succumbing to these economic, military-and about all-technological forces which have taken charge of events.

They are the words of the present Foreign Minister, Bill Hayden, going back to 1981. What he said was absolutely correct. When we consider the flexible options that are open to the United States military command and, no doubt, the equivalent open to the planners in the Kremlin-I am not wanting to suggest that there is any lack of criticism of their options either, but we happen to be associated much more closely with the American system-we need to look at the weapons systems which have been developed by the United States. The Trident II weapons systems will be on line next year. Orders to use the Trident II weapons systems and the MX missile systems could be passed through the base at North West Cape. They are not deterrent weapons systems. The degree of accuracy which they employ is necessary for only one purpose and that is a first strike purpose. Again, to quote Bill Hayden, he has said repeatedly that if the bases on Australian soil could be seen to have any first strike application, we would have to review our commitment to them. Firstly, I take honourable senators to page 610. It is headed `D, Joint Defence Facilities'. Paragraph 30 states:

The joint facilities in Australia make an important contribution to effective deterrence and the avoidance of conflict, and have helped materially to make possible the progress which has been made in the past towards arms control and disarmament by enabling-
(a) surveillance for the verification of treaties, agreements and understandings on disarmament and arms control; and
(b) provision of early warning of threats to allies.

31 While recognising that the major joint facilities may themselves constitute nuclear targets, their continuing presence contributes an essential element to a stable global nuclear balance, and without the capacity for surveillance and early warning which they and similar facilities provide, further progress towards arms control and disarmament will be jeopardised rather than enhanced. The joint facilities may therefore remain so long as they continue to fulfil these functions.
Labor will-

32 Require that control over the management of all defence and defence-related facilities and installations in Australia be either held exclusively by Australia or shared in such a way that Australian concurrence is required in management decisions.

33 Require that the operations of these facilities and installations are conducted only with the government's full knowledge and concurrence; and in particular that the facilities will not be operated so as to support the use of armed force except with the specific prior agreement of the government.
34 Require that agreements relating to the establishment or operation in Australia of joint defence facilities shall have non-terminable periods no longer than ten years.

35 Ensure that Australian personnel with appropriate skills are fully involved in all aspects of the operations of all defence and defence-related facilities and that Australian personnel with parliamentary or other official responsibilities that involve the facilities have access to them.

36 Require that the general purpose and functions of each of the facilities shall be made known to the Australian public, together with such additional details about the operations conducted there as can be provided without detriment to the effectiveness of those operations.

37 Require that the government has access to all information derived from the operations of those facilities, and that it is advised of the purposes to which the information is put by the other government or governments involved.

38 Ensure that the facilities are not used to collect information in Australia and are operated in accordance with Australia's concern to avoid actions detrimental to the interests of friendly countries.

Senator Schacht, who is sitting behind me, was one of the authors of that document. He would also be able to tell us, when people make reference to the fact that perhaps a minority in my own Party do not fully support that policy, that at the Party's last national conference that policy went through without a division, a vote or a count being held. The rather graphic debates that the Labor Party may have had in the 1960s and 1970s and almost into the early 1980s have disappeared, and there is virtually no consistent fighting in the Labor Party about that policy. That is a policy which we took to the people in 1983, 1984 and 1987. We did not try to hide our policy and we were supported in it. The coalition did not try to hide its policy either. I repeat that 89 per cent of Senate voters responded to our policy.

The Prime Minister's statement on 6 June 1984 and the defence White Paper of March 1987 set out in greater detail than had any previous Government the general purpose of the facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar. The Prime Minister in his statement said that the joint facilities at Pine Gap and Nurrungar contribute to arms control, verification and early warning, as well as to the effective deterrence of war. As the Prime Minister has said, all functions and activities require, and have, the full knowledge and concurrence of the Australian Government. We monitor them closely and are satisfied that the operations of the facilities in no way derogate from our sovereignty, nor are the facilities operated against our national interests. The Government will neither confirm nor deny that the facilities are used for any particular purpose beyond those referred to by the Prime Minister in his statement to Parliament on 6 June 1984, other than to state flatly and clearly that they are not used to spy against this country.

The Government does not accept a characterisation of United States strategic policy in terms of offensive first strike or nuclear war fighting. United States leaders, including President Reagan and Secretary of Defense Weinberger, have emphasised repeatedly that the US strategy is defensive and that a pre-emptive or first strike by the US has been ruled out. More generally, the Government does not believe that either super-power could contemplate a successful first strike against the other. Acquisition of the theoretical first strike capability would require the ability to attack simultaneously all targets, including hardened missile silos, with sufficient reliability, accuracy, survivability, penetrability and destructive power to provide nearly 100 per cent certainty that they would be destroyed. It would also require confidence in achieving complete surprise and the ability to destroy the other side's means of retaliating, including retaliation with bombers, mobile intercontinental ballistic missiles and the difficult-to-detect strategic ballistic missile submarines. It is most unlikely that these conditions could be satisfied in the foreseeable future by either super-power.

The terms of our agreement with the United States governing the operation of the joint defence facilities at Pine Gap provide that, as of 19 October 1987, either party to the agreement may terminate the agreement by giving one year's notice in writing. In the absence of such action, the agreement continues in force and there is no requirement for it to be renegotiated or amended.

As the Prime Minister made clear in June 1984 in his comprehensive statement to the House on the role and functions of the joint defence facilities, and as the Government also made clear in its policy information paper on the defence of Australia, tabled in the House on 19 March 1987, the joint facility at Pine Gap serves Australian as well as US interests. More particularly, the contribution of the joint defence facilities to world stability is obviously of direct and immediate benefit to our prospects for a peaceful existence. Were Australia to cease our co-operation in the joint defence facilities, there would only be adverse consequences for international security and a higher risk of global war. This would serve neither Australia's interests nor those of the international community generally. For these reasons, the Government does not propose to terminate our joint defence agreement with the United States.

I want to move to a specific issue, and that is the question of serving an eviction notice, leases, et cetera. None of the facilities is subject to a lease which requires renewal. Rather, each is the subject of an agreement which provides for a non-terminable period. When the non-terminable period expires the agreement continues in force unless either side gives due notice of termination, in which case the agreement terminates at the completion of the notice period. One year's notice is required for Pine Gap and Nurrungar, and, as of 1 January 1988, six months notice could be given for North West Cape.

In conclusion, I would like to make the point I made at the start of my remarks. I happen to have a different world view from that of Senator Vallentine and probably most of the Australian Democrats in this chamber.
