SPEECH.PARA: In looking at the presence in Australia of the joint defence-related facilities, such as those at Pine Gap, it is important to go back to basics. In the long and often very emotive debate about these facilities that has gone on in Australia for 20-odd years, it has been easy for people on either side of the argument to lose sight of the very fundamental issue, and that issue is the preservation of the peace of the world. The proliferation since 1945 of nuclear weapons in the hands of the United States, the Soviet Union, Britain, France and China has increased the cost of any future global war to a prohibitive level. Quite simply, we as a race can no longer afford the price of world war because that now means world nuclear war. The policy of the Opposition for years has been that such a war must be prevented. The question has been: how to achieve this goal without sacrificing essential national security interests.

Whilst it might upset some people to be reminded of this matter, it is true that the Western community of nations has seen an aggressive and often brutal Soviet Union gobble up half of Europe and keep it under heel with naked force. Examples are Hungary in 1956, Czechoslovakia in 1968 and, more recently, the invasion of Afghanistan. So how to preserve peace without handing the world over to the Soviets has been the problem. The only answer that has worked so far has been the policy of mutual deterrence between the super-powers. The arsenals of each side are such that the Soviets are deterred from embarking on any campaign of massive conquest. On balance, the Soviets need not fear that the Americans will attack them or their vital interests.

The policy of mutual deterrence has been criticised on various grounds. The most common is that it keeps the people of the world under the constant threat of nuclear war. This is true; but however unpalatable it might be, the fact remains that world peace has been secured by the deterrence policy. No other alternative is available at present which is generally agreed to work as well as deterrence. We must support deterrence for one very simple reason: it works, and nothing else has been devised that works. The facilities in Australia are part of the system of deterrence. To remove them would weaken deterrence. Therefore, they must stay and our arguments, therefore, are based on logic. We need deterrence to work if we are to keep the threat of nuclear conflict at bay. The joint facilities support deterrence. Therefore they should remain. In fact, it is thoroughly irresponsible to argue otherwise. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the editorial which appeared in yesterday's Australian. I quote:

The joint defence facilities are an integral part of the US-Australia relationship. Those political parties and candidates who would have the bases removed have never won a majority in any House of any Australian parliament, nor indeed anything like a majority. The three principal Australian political parties-Labor, Liberal and National-all support the joint facilities.
Further on it says:

The majority of Australians support the presence of the joint facilities for good reasons. They make an important contribution to the process of arms control through their role in technical verification of Soviet compliance with arms control agreements.

Let us look at some of the policies at which those opposed to the bases occasionally have us look. I draw the attention of honourable senators to the 1987 election policy statement of the Australian Democrats. I take two points out of that. The first is, `No nuclear weapons in Australia' and the second is, `Removal of any foreign bases that contribute to nuclear war'. This is the policy of a party that knows it will never have the problem of governing. It is a policy of a losers party.

It infuriates me that many of the contributors to the debate on nuclear weapons carry on as if the nuclear policies and armaments of the Union of Soviet Socialist Republics simply did not exist.

TALK.START.PARA: —We don't want to be the target.

—I refer Senator Powell to Hansard. I keep very accurate notes of what people say and that is what was said. The bases at Pine Gap and Nurrungar are without question the two most important joint facilities in Australia. Pine Gap in particular performs the essential role of being the eyes and ears of Australia and the United States in the Indian Ocean, South East Asia, south Asia, China and the southern portion of the USSR. That is particularly important because it is the southern portion of the USSR where most of the Soviet nuclear missile tests are conducted. Pine Gap is the ground station for the Rhyolite series of satellites and the ones which followed which hang in stationary orbit over Borneo monitoring signals intelligence.

SPEECH.PARA: This monitoring is the most important source of data available to ensure that the Soviet Union does not cheat on nuclear arms agreements. The satellites are actually capable of monitoring Soviet missile tests telemetry, providing information on the performance of new Soviet missile systems, although that is not all they are capable of. Pine Gap plays not only a central-and there appears to be general agreement on this among even the prominent critics of the bases in Australia-but also an irreplaceable role in monitoring Soviet missile testing. Senator Vallentine, if she can explain how any degree of nuclear disarmament, however small, can be achieved without providing for verification, had better explain it in better detail than she has so far. There is a very recent publication by a prominent contributor to this debate not know for his support of American and Australian joint facilities in Australia, Professor Desmond Ball. The book is entitled A Base for Debate. On page 13 of the preface to that book, Professor Ball, having made the case for closing down Nurrungar-I point out that we are discussing the base at Pine Gap today-stated:

On the other hand, in the case of the CIA's SIGINT satellite ground station at Pine Gap, the verification of arms control arrangements has made the operation both necessary and virtuous. Signals intelligence collected at Pine Gap is used by various U.S. agencies for different purposes, some of which undeniably enhance the war-fighting aspects of the US strategic posture, but much of which is essential to the verification of the Anti-Ballistic Missile Treaty, the SALT constraints on strategic offensive nuclear forces, and the other arms control agreements. Moreover, technological trends suggest that Pine Gap's unique capabilities will become even more critical to the success of any future arms control and disarmament efforts. It is simply not possible to seriously support arms control and disarmament and at the same time argue for the closure of Pine Gap.

TALK.START.PARA: —When was the book written?

—I suggest that Senator Sanders is not very close to the debate. He would know if he had followed the debate that the book was published in 1987 with a whole host of attendant publicity, obviously all of which went over his head. The first part of the matter of public importance states:

SPEECH.PARA: The refusal of the Government to admit that the Joint Defence Space Research Facility . . . has an offensive role in a nuclear warfighting scenario . . .

Of course, that assertion is based on the theory of a first strike capability. Senator Vallentine is nodding assent to that, so I assume that that is a correct interpretation of what she is saying. If only such a thing were possible. If we could even suggest in this day and age that there was a capacity for a first strike, we might be able to take the next logical step and suggest that there would be some survivors of a nuclear war. I do not believe in either theory. I do not think that anyone who has paid serious attention to this debate-I certainly have-could put forward such nonsense.

TALK.START.PARA: —You don't think there is a first strike capability?

—If the honourable senator directs his mind to the debate he will realise that there is of course a first strike capability. It is the strategic theory which is not feasible. What we have-this is accepted by anyone who has paid any attention to the debate-is the old strategic situation, which we went through a period of rejecting, of mutually assured destruction, or MAD. That is precisely the situation we now have. Despite a period of about 10 years when the major powers tried to kid everyone, their own citizens in particular, that such a strategy was not in place, we still have MAD. It is a great acronym.

SPEECH.PARA: I point out to Senator Sanders that we have fleets of undetectable nuclear armed submarines of frightening capacity which exist purely for their retaliation capacity. First strike is not a strategy which either the USA or the Soviet Union would pursue any longer. Such a strategy relies, firstly, on total surprise being achieved and, secondly, the capacity, along with total surprise, to knock out, in the space of no longer than 30 minutes, every substantive nuclear capacity of the enemy, including deep silos, bomber fleets, the mobile intercontinental ballistic missiles and the fleets of nuclear submarines carrying multiheaded warheads. It is a nonsensical proposition. It simply is not accepted by any person who seriously follows this debate.

I might add that Senator Sanders, in terms of his previous puerile contributions to this debate-I hope that the substantive speech he delivers is a bit better than his interjections-interjected, in response to a claim that Pine Gap was a joint facility and not a United States base, that it was obviously not a joint facility because we cannot walk through it. What a nonsensical, childish contribution to the debate. How can Senator Sanders honestly expect anyone to take him seriously if that is the level of his contribution? As I said in response, Senator Sanders should try to walk free and unhindered through the Pentagon and see how far he gets. Is the fact that one gets stopped at the door proof positive that the Pentagon is run by the Soviet Union? I would not think so. That was a stupid contribution to the debate. The fact is that the officer in charge of the Pine Gap base is Australian.

TALK.START.PARA: —Yes, I have met him.

—I have met him too. The reality is that he is Australian. The facility director is American. They run the facility jointly and neither one is subordinate to the other. Of course, that is a little fact that Senator Sanders would have no trouble in ignoring. The personnel who run the bases are divided about half and half; there are about 250 Australian personnel and about 250 American personnel. It has been well established by people such as the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade, Bill Hayden, and many others that Australians have complete access to all the operational areas of the base. It is in truth a joint facility, whether Senator Sanders wants to accept that fact or not.

SPEECH.PARA: The issue around which this debate revolves is not the question of whether Pine Gap should be closed down because, in terms of pursuing a multilateral verifiable disarmament program, no one ever has an explanation for what we do after we close down Pine Gap, what the next step is. The issue on which this debate really centres is whether Australia continues to be an aligned or a non-aligned country. That is the key point of the debate. The issue is not whether we close down Pine Gap. I am pleased to see that Senator Vallentine agrees with that statement as well. It is a fact that the substantive debate is concerned with whether Australia should be an aligned or a non-aligned country. If we accept that Australia should be aligned, certain obligations must go with that alliance. I will read briefly from the Government's policy document in regard to that matter. The very substantive statement introduced into the Parliament by the Minister for Defence, Kim Beazley, entitled The Defence of Australia, states in paragraph 1.13 on page 3, in regard to Australia and the United States:

Australia is part of the Western community of nations. Australia therefore supports the ability of the United States to retain an effective strategic balance with the Soviet Union. A redistribution of power in favour of the Soviet Union in the central balance, or an extension of Soviet influence in our region at the expense of the United States, would be a matter of fundamental concern to Australia and would be contrary to our national interests.

One either agrees with that statement or one does not. I fundamentally agree with it. I think that an expansion of Soviet power in our area-it is very active indeed in the Indian Ocean-would be contrary to Australia's national interests. Therefore, I support the American alliance. If we support the alliance, as I do, with all the misgivings that I have-just as any citizen of an independent country would have-we must realise that there are certain obligations attached to it. Part of these obligations is the continued operation of the joint facilities. The fact is, whether or not Senator Sanders or Senator Vallentine want to acknowledge it-implicit in Senator Vallentine's matter of public importance is an acceptance of it in any case-that Pine Gap plays an essential role in monitoring the missile testing of the Soviet Union and, indeed, China. Pine Gap plays a central role and, in the view of Professor Ball, an irreplaceable role, in terms of monitoring and safeguarding any nuc- lear disarmament agreement. If Senator Vallentine or, indeed, Senator Sanders or anyone else can put to me a tenable proposition-one that applies in the real world, not in fantasy land-that would allow for a reduction in nuclear arms without being able to verify that the parties to it are adhering to the agreement, I will be prepared to listen. Certainly, no honourable senator has been able to do so to this point in the debate. I support the proposition put by the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) so succinctly in the House of Representatives on 6 June 1984 when he made his major statement on this matter. I support the position expressed by Senator Robert Ray today in leading the debate for the Government; that is, that the proper role, the proper policy and the proper decision for this Government in the national interests of this country are to support the American alliance and the continued operations of those joint facilities.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Teague Sen B.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I support the motion put forward by the coalition in the following terms:

SPEECH.PARA: The need for the Senate to express its support for the maintenance of Australia's alliance with the United States and to reaffirm the basis for the operation of joint defence facilities in Australia in light of recent demonstrations at Pine Gap.

I commend also Senator Collins and Senator Robert Ray for their speeches on behalf of the Government. I note with considerable satisfaction the adoption by the Government over the last four years of the main bases of the coalition's approach to foreign affairs and defence over the last 40 years. In fact, there was a bipartisan commitment by the two major political parties in Australia when the Australian-American alliance commenced in the days of Curtin and Chifley. That same bipartisan approach continues in regard to the joint facilities. Despite the policies of the Australian Labor Party (ALP) in opposition, despite the Socialist Left members of the present Government, the majority has prevailed and this is reflected in the views that we heard from Senator Ray and Senator Collins today. These facilities are joint Australian-American facilities. They are essential for the defence of Australia and for the maintenance of peace in the world.

The main issue that is before us today is Pine Gap. Pine Gap is a joint Australian-American facility some kilometres from Alice Springs. It consists of a series of white domes under which antennae receive signals from satellites. A large number of satellites have been launched to detect signals, including electronic signals and photographic material, from various parts of the world. The antennae at Pine Gap receive those signals for interpretation. This is an essential activity which cannot be carried out in any other part of the world. The base is located in the centre of Australia because of the clear reception and lack of interference from other electronic signals that are necessary in monitoring satellite surveillance.

It is also very well known what the Pine Gap facility broadly does. As I have said, it receives and monitors satellite signals and photographic material. This material is put together through a complex set of computers to give excellent intelligence for the benefit of the Australian-American alliance and for our own defence. Pine Gap is not an American base. Our American allies do not deploy troops on Australian soil. There is no armed fort at Alice Springs. There are some antennae which receive signals and computers which interpret those signals. This base is essential for the defence of Australia and it will continue.

The reality of this debate in the Senate is that all of the huffing and puffing, the climbing of fences or the getting arrested of people who support the two disarmament senators or the Democrats will not make one jot of difference to the maintenance of the Australian-American alliance or to the maintenance of the joint facilities that include not only most importantly Pine Gap but also Nurrungar in my own State of South Australia and North West Cape in Western Australia. These, and some other less important facilities, are consciously viewed by a majority of parliamentarians as an essential contribution to the maintenance of world peace and as an essential basis for Australia's own defence. So the reality is that this debate-this little bit of noise that has been created in the month of October-is a means of demonstrating the clamour for that few per cent of the vote that appears to be winnable by Australian Democrat senators, by nuclear disarmament senators, by the greens, which was a new party at the last election, by the Socialist Left of the Australian Labor Party, by the Socialist Workers Party-and Senator Vallentine, who sits on the other side of the chamber, knows about that Party-or by the Communist Party of Australia.

It is undeniable that the few per cent of Australian voters who support the views that have been put forward by Senator Vallentine today have to decide each election whether they will vote for a nuclear disarmament senator, a Democrat, a green, a communist, a socialist worker or the Socialist Left of the ALP if they stay with the Labor Party. That is what this debate is about. This debate will not have any impact whatsoever on the realities of Australia's defence, on the realities of the coalition's deterrence or on the ability to verify arms control agreements. It is purely a question of struggling around for those few per cent of Australians who will vote for one or other of those minority parties.

TALK.START.PARA: —You are cynical, aren't you?

—I am not cynical. I am deadly serious. I do not believe that a majority of Australians countenance for one second the views that were put forward here today by Senator Vallentine. Those views are rightly described as irresponsible, naive and counterproductive. Some people put forward the claim-and Senator Coulter may have been one of those who said this in the last election-that the bipartisan view between the Government and the Opposition that it is essential to have the American alliance and the joint facilities is some kind of conspiracy. In another decade it was called a conspiracy of the military-industrial complex, or some such thing. It is a lie to claim that some vested interest has swayed the minds of members of parliament against reason and knowledge. It is totally contrary to the truth.

SPEECH.PARA: I must say to the Senate that I think I am well known as a co-convenor of the parliamentary disarmament group. I am one of the co-convenors of the disarmament forum in this Parliament House in the International Year of Peace. I was Deputy Chairman of the Joint Standing Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence that wrote the report on disarmament and arms control that has been referred to by some speakers today. I was one of the authors of that 22-chapter report. I am proud to be associated with that most substantial report to this Parliament. I am not uninformed about maintaining peace and about the goals of disarmament. I say to honourable senators that the only disarmament that is sensibly supported, that ought to be supported, is mutual verifiable disarmament and not the naivety and irresponsibility that we heard today from the nuclear disarmament senator and from the Democrats.

Let me come to the question of unilateralism. Senator Vallentine said that she is not a unilateralist. She is using this rhetoric because she knows that unilateralism is a concept that is understood by many Australians and is totally rejected by them. So she does not want that tag placed on her. But in her speech today she called for one-sided disarmament-that is, for the breaking of the Australian-American alliance. She called for the ending of the joint facilities. If that is not one-sided, if that is not unilateral, what is? It is a nonsense and it is dangerous to put such views.

Such pacifist and soft-headed views were advanced in the 1930s against the Nazi threat in Germany. Let me put a most recent and very realistic example to the Senate. I refer to the recent agreement by Shultz and Shevardnadze to put together an agreement for the elimination of intermediate nuclear forces in Europe and, indeed, for the abandonment by the Soviet Union and the United States of all intermediate nuclear weapons. This was not the outcome of demonstrations by nuclear disarmament senators or greens. It was the outcome of a response by the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation forces to put in Europe an immediate deterrent to the deployment by the Soviet Union of SS20 missiles which were aimed at every capital in Western Europe. When the SS20s were deployed by the Soviet Union in the late 1970s to threaten the whole of western Europe, the Western nations came together and gained from the United States Pershing and cruise missiles and deployed them in their own countries in order to have a direct deterrent to the Soviet union ever using the SS20s. Because we have had eight years of that deployment since 1979, to the point where the deployment is nearly completed, we now have an agreement, based upon strength on the West's part, that the SS20s, the Pershing and cruise missiles, we trust, will be eliminated if President Reagan and General Secretary Gorbachev meet next month to sign the pencilled agreement that their Foreign Ministers have developed.

Let me turn to the Committee to which I referred, the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence, which undertook the most thorough survey of these questions that any parliament has recently had placed before it. In the last Parliament there were 28 members of the Joint Committee on Foreign Affairs and Defence. The Committee brought down a 22-chapter report entitled Disarmament and Arms Control. Chapter 15 is devoted entirely to the joint facilities in Australia. Page 472 reads:
The Committee supports the continued presence of the joint facilities in Australia.
Page 470 reads:
A decision to close down the facilities would not be supported by the Australian population at large.

The reasons for that conclusion are that the joint facilities are essential to gain intelligence, to give verification that will enable arms control agreements, and enable the alliance to have a deterrent that will stop the launching of nuclear missiles by any enemy of Australia. If we did not have a sufficient deterrence, if we did not have the means of verification, if we did not have the careful intelligence that is provided by the satellite receiving station at Pine Gap, we would be very significantly weakened. We would be laying ourselves open to not defending Australia responsibly and not contributing positively to the maintenance of world peace. The Committee concluded on page 468 that the joint facilities are essential for deterrence. It stated:

While the facilities may be making an increasing contribution to extended deterrence, it remains the case that Pine Gap and Nurrungar in particular continue to operate in support of basic deterrence-primarily through their intelligence collection and early warning functions-and that Pine Gap provides the United States with an important National Technical Means of verifying Soviet compliance with existing or projected arms control agreements.

One of the experts in this field in Australia is the Head of the Strategic and Defence Studies Centre at the Australian National University, Dr Des Ball. Five or 10 years ago he was the hero of many of the irresponsible members of the peace movement, who would quote him to gain the little information that they had about these facilities. He has stated:
There is no doubt that SALT (the Strategic Arms Limitation Treaty) was predicated on adequate and detailed verification facilities. You would not have had SALT . . .
That is, we would not have had the major arms control agreement unless we had those facilities.

TALK.START.PARA: —Order! The honourable senator's time has expired.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Sanders Sen N.K.

TALK.START.PARA: —What we have had here this afternoon is an illustration, once again, of the fact that there is no basic difference in this country between the Opposition and the Government. They are the `Li- borials'. There is one indivisible party which operates, not in the best interests of Australia, but in the best interests of our rich and powerful friend, the United States of America. We have seen a tremendous example-a reprehensible example, actually-of the cultural cringe. Australians sitting in this Parliament are afraid to take control of Australia's affairs. Why has this come to pass?

SPEECH.PARA: For many years Australia was a colony of Great Britain. Until World War II Australia was told to look to Great Britain as a rich and powerful friend-a friend which would protect our country in time of strife. Of course, Great Britain could not protect us in a time of strife, during World War II, so the Americans, in the Battle of the Coral Sea, came to our aid. The Australian people transferred their allegiance to the United States. But they did so uncritically, and I think it is time that we re-examined this allegiance and what it is doing to us. The most obvious case in which it is distorting our safety is in the case of the bases. No one in this place has argued that the bases are not a nuclear target. The Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) has admitted that the bases are a nuclear target. The argument seems to be that we will somehow buy something from the United States; that by exposing ourselves to nuclear war-and this is not a nuclear umbrella; it is a nuclear lightening rod, as Dr Jim Falk says-we will gain some protection. We will not.

As a former American, I am here to tell everyone that the Americans will do what is in America's best self-interest. They will not protect Australia in time of strife. If we get into a military situation with Indonesia or with any other conceivable enemy, the United States will not automatically come to our aid because we have some military facilities that belong to the United States. If it is in its interest to support us, it will. Look at the grain deals. Look at what is happening to our agricultural exports to the United States at the moment. We crawl to the Yanks and say, `Look, we have your bases, we allow your ships into our ports. Please give us access to your markets'. The Yanks say, `Go away, kid. You bother me'. That is the kind of reaction we can expect. What we are basically doing is signing a one-way agreement. We sign away our safety; we make ourselves nuclear targets; the United States makes no commitments to us at all.

I have been listening to this argument in the Senate this afternoon. I am gratified that both the Australian Labor Party and the Liberal Party-and the Opposition in general-have said, `These bases are essential to verification. That is their main role. That is why we like them here. That is why we allow them to exist. We feel they add to world peace because of verification'. Des Ball wrote a book which was published in 1977, as Senator Collins told us. However, this book was written before the most recent breakthroughs in the reduction of the intermediate range nuclear forces (INF). There is a whole new ball game out there.

The argument in this chamber today has been a Cold War argument, an old argument. I do not even agree with the basic concepts of verifications under this argument. Verification is not reliant solely on Pine Gap. If one is talking about verification, one is talking about optical satellites which are polar orbiting and which can release their data into any number of areas within the continental United States or territories of the United States. So, in any event Pine Gap is not the essential verification base and neither is Nurrungar. I will talk about the other bases in a moment. Under the recent agreements between Gorbachev and Reagan a whole new regime of verification is opening up. That regime is on-site verification. No amount of gee whiz gadgetry is the equal of a humanised, on the ground look at military and missile establishments in the Soviet Union, and in the United States, for that matter. This is happening. Part of the INF agreement includes on-site inspection and the destruction of nuclear weapons, under supervision of all the countries involved. This is a new development to which Des Ball had no access because it had not happened. No one in this chamber has mentioned it yet. In fact, it makes Pine Gap absolutely obsolete as a verification base. It makes it redundant and makes its only role, as one of the prime bases, to assess the weakness of Soviet communications systems for first strike.

Senator Collins, who represents a small population in the Northern Territory, presumes to speak for the US military establishment, which has always maintained that it had not only the first strike capability but a propensity for first strike. To a military planner, first strike is the only way to ensure the destruction of one's target. It is a `use it or lose it' concept, and that is what the MX missile is all about. It is a silo buster. It is for a first strike, and that is recorded over and over again in the literature. I am sorry that the honourable senator has not yet caught up with it.

The danger of this is that a first strike may be launched by misadventure, by miscalculation of military planners or by false alarms. Pine Gap is one of the many systems that takes in intelligence. They are all highly sophisticated and are becoming more highly automated. We are entering a new type of missile launching regime-launch on warning-in which the computers take over and there is no human interface at all. The statistics show that between 1977 and 1984 North American Air Defence admitted to six false alarms, four of which actually accounted for the deployment of nuclear forces. These all came about for a variety of reasons, one of which was erroneous information and on a computer simulation of a nuclear attack which was treated as the real thing until the mistake was discovered after six minutes. If we go into a launch on warning missile system, we will not have the six minute time scale to work with any more. Pine Gap is one of the systems which would input into a launch on warning system. Therefore, if we get into this aspect of our nuclear capability, we are contributing to World War III by the presence of facilities such as Nurrungar and Pine Gap. There is no argument here. The defence planners understand that.

The other thing about first strike-and I am sure that Senator Collins would have in his heart a soft spot for the strategic defence initiative (SDI) because he seems to enjoy all the other peace through strength-type arguments-is that SDI will work only if a first strike is launched ahead of time, because SDI cannot knock out all the possible Soviet missiles. It can knock out only a proportion of them. It will not function properly without first strike. First strike is a policy of the United States and of the military leaders of the United States, and Pine Gap adds to this first strike capability.

I found quite a bit of similarity between the thinking in this chamber and that in the North Atlantic Treaty Organisation (NATO) among the people to whom we talked recently when a parliamentary delegation went to NATO headquarters in Brussels. We talked to Mr Merrill Walters, who is the NATO Director for Nuclear Planning, and a US colonel named G. R. Akam. They told us that NATO's flexible response depended on nuclear weapons. Incredibly, their opinion was that a nuclear war could be limited and winnable. It was clear that they feared the outbreak of peace because it could take their toys away. I am afraid, from what I have heard in this chamber today, that some honourable senators also fear the outbreak of peace because then they would have to think about where their true allegiance should be. I put it to them that it should not be with the United States of America but with Australia. The way to cement that allegiance to Australia is to get rid of the US bases on our soil.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Schacht Sen C.C.

TALK.START.PARA: —I rise to oppose the matter proposed by Senator Vallentine. Earlier in the debate, Senator Robert Ray remarked on my contribution to the Australia Labor Party (ALP) policy on foreign affairs and defence. Until June this year, I had the great honour of being the chairperson of the ALP national executive platform committee on defence and foreign affairs for four years. That platform has been vigorously debated within the Party and reviewed on several occasions. Senator Robert Ray is correct to say that at the last national conference, in 1986 in Hobart, the policy included the arrangement on matters dealing with the joint facilities. It was passed on the voices, and there was not even a call for a division.

SPEECH.PARA: I accept that there is a range of opinion within the Labor Party and differences of opinion about foreign affairs. That has always been the position in the Labor Party and it has been vigorously debated and argued. However, that has not deterred the ALP from stating its commitment towards its arrangements with America. It should be pointed out that the Labor Party was in government in 1941-42, when John Curtin established defence arrangements with America at the time of the crisis over the war with Japan. The Labor Party has never voted at a national conference to change that arrangement. That has always been our position. Even in the debate in the early 1960s, when the North West Cape facility was established, the Party supported that decision. The Party has been consistent on its position and its arrangements with America.

I do not think people should see this as Australia being part of an American alliance. Australians have had to take a decision-and the ALP has taken that decision-that we are part of what is called the first world, politically, culturally, socially and economically. We have much in common with countries in North America and Western Europe and with our closest neighbour, New Zealand. We all have similar commitments to democracy and freedom of speech and religion. It is only natural that that is where Australia will see its arrangements in defence matters, alliances and so on. The Labor Party is not defensive about defending that position.

In the context of the time since the Second World War, that means we have had a position of America as the major power in the First World and the Western alliance and we have had particular arrangements. However, the Labor Party must emphasise that we have an independent foreign policy and, whether we are in opposition or in government, we have on many occasions indicated to the Americans that we have differences of opinion with them over particular matters. Unlike the National Party or the Liberal Party, we have indicated significant differences. At the moment, in foreign affairs, we have indicated to the Americans that we disagree with their policy over Central America, over the Kampuchean issue, over southern Africa and over the strategic defence initiative. We are disappointed that America has not signed the protocols on the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone Treaty, which was an initiative of the Federal Labor Government. It all indicates that, though we are a part of the so-called Western alliance or the alliances of the First World and have arrangements with America, that has not derogated from our commitment to our independent sovereignty and to having an independent foreign policy. I believe that the comments by Senator Sanders are misleading, and certainly not in the context of the Australian Labor Party's long history of creating an independent foreign policy. I accept the fact that Senator Saunders has not been a long time citizen of this country, but I urge him to read the history of the Australian Labor Party since 1891, and he will find, throughout all that history, a commitment to an independent foreign policy. The Hawke Labor Government is carrying on that grand tradition.

I shall quote the words of Bill Hayden in the Evatt Memorial Speech on 7 July 1983. Dr Evatt did more than anybody else in the history of Australia to establish an independent foreign policy attitude in Australia, which gave us great recognition, and as a result was the first President of the United Nations General Assembly. Bill Hayden said:

I remind you also that the alliance is not only an ultimate guarantee. It is a dynamic relationship between sovereign and equal partners who share the most fundamental values. It is not an association between an active great power and a passive smaller one as some people suggest. An arrangement of that sort would diminish its value to both sides.
He went on to say:
This Government, in its international relations, will clearly project an Australian national identity and accept a national responsibility.
In all areas of foreign affairs that has been a hallmark of the success of the present Government.

We come to the issue of nuclear disarmament. I accept the bona fides of the Australian Democrats, Senator Vallentine and Senator Wood and that they have an absolute commitment to nuclear disarmament; but I absolutely reject the moralising when they say that we in the Australian Labor Party do not have the same commitment because we do not support their policy regarding the joint facilities. I think that the Australian Labor Party has done more than most people in the community give it credit for. For example, one of the major initiatives of the Australian Labor Government in its four years in office is its work on achieving a comprehensive test ban treaty.

People say, `What is the value of the relationship we have with America? What value do we get out of it?'. I will give one specific example: Nobody in this place, none of the parties represented here, would disagree with the achievement of a comprehensive test ban treaty. Up until 1984 the Americans in the United States used their veto against any debate on the comprehensive test ban treaty. That was a Reagan Government position. We disagreed with it. We argued for a debate and we used our influence to get the Americans to go from a position of vetoing to abstaining in regard to that debate. That enabled the debate on the comprehensive test ban treaty to proceed to a more progressive position. That is a fundamental achievement of this Government in regard to nuclear disarmament. It may not please the glory seekers who want to throw themselves on the razor wire around Pine Gap or around the other joint facilities; but, fundamentally, it will have more effect in the world towards achieving nuclear disarmament than some of the people who carry banners.

I accept the right of Jo Vallentine to demonstrate publicly, even though it is in opposition to Government policy. I believe that everybody in this community has the right to demonstrate publicly, even if it causes inconvenience. I do not agree with Senator Tambling's remarks about the cost. What about the cost of the demonstration by the people in north Queensland against Senator Richardson recently because they opposed the Government policy on the preservation of the Daintree rainforest? That demonstration caused obvious public distress. Obviously, there was a cost to the authorities in that demonstration. I support the right of the north Queensland people who wanted to have that demonstration. I also support the right, although I disagree with the issue she is demonstrating over, of Senator Vallentine or other people to participate in such demonstrations. That is a fundamental principle which the Labor Party has always guaranteed in its own policy.

Another achievement of the Hawke Labor Government for which we have not been given credit and about which many people are disparaging-it again indicates the difference of opinion with America, to which people are always saying we are mendicants in regard to policy-is the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone. It is a great disappointment to me that Great Britain and America have refused to sign the protocols to that treaty. We have made our position known strongly to the Americans, namely, that we believe that they are not doing themselves any good in the South Pacific region by refusing to sign the protocols. We will continue to put that position. But the achievement of the South Pacific Nuclear Free Zone, which was a major achievement of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) and the Minister for Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden), should be one for which the Australian Democrats, Senator Vallentine and others should give us major credit.

The next position of Senator Vallentine and the Democrats, which I cannot support and which I wish to raise, is that they give the impression that they are unilateralists in nuclear disarmament. Senator Vallentine has tried to refute that today, but one cannot be other than a unilateralist if one expects Australia, in its relationships with America, the Western alliance or in the First World alliance, to take unilaterally or off its own bat decisions which affect the nuclear balance.

TALK.START.PARA: —They are not.

—It may be good for Senator Wood's heart to suggest that, but it will achieve nothing, just as I do not expect the Soviet Union unilaterally to disarm itself of nuclear weapons. The only way there will be a lasting nuclear disarmament accord in this world is for the super-powers with nuclear weapons to reach agreement to multilaterally, step by step, reduce nuclear weapons. We cannot expect either of the super-powers, off its own bat, to reduce weapons. Unfortunately, there is not the level of trust in the world for that to occur. Multilateral negotiations are the only way to go. That is why, thankfully, the super-powers are having success at the moment in the negotiations over intermediate nuclear weapons in Western Europe which may well lead to reductions in strategic nuclear weapons. That is a multilateral negotiation; it is not unilateral. There will only be success by multilateral negotiation.

SPEECH.PARA: I also point out to the Democrats and to Senator Vallentine that if we do achieve-as I hope we will some time in the next decade-the elimination of nuclear weapons, we should not stop there for disarmament; it also includes conventional weapons. There has to be negotiation to reduce the level of conventional weapons in this world, because that will still be a major source of instability. The only way we will reduce conventional weapons is, again, by multilateral discussions and debate, not by unilateral discussions. I urge the Democrats and Senator Vallentine to support multilateral discussions.

My time is expiring. I thank the Senate for the opportunity to speak in this debate. I am sure that this matter will come back for further debate at a later stage. I will enjoy entering the debate then.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —The motion before the chair is false and irresponsible. It misleads the Australian public on a matter of the greatest importance to them. It damages Australia's security and it therefore damages the security of the Western democracies because their security and our security are indivisible. If it were passed, it would create instability because it would undermine the very systems that are in place, keeping the world peaceful and secure at present. It would, therefore, increase the likelihood of nuclear war through misunderstanding. We get a great deal of passion from the proponents of this motion, but passion is not a guarantee of correctness or of accuracy. Both those qualities are sadly lacking from their argument.

SPEECH.PARA: I would like to say something about peace, to start with. Peace, sadly, is not a natural condition between the nations of the world. As the first 40 years of this century showed, it is something that is very hard to obtain. The fact that through the last 45 years of this century we have followed a policy of deterrence, which has given us peace and security and an absence of the huge carnage that we saw in two world wars speaks volumes in itself. The other thing about peace is that it has a qualitative element which is quite lacking from anything that the Australian Democrats or the unilateral nuclear disarmers put up. There can be the peace and freedom which the Western democracies enjoy and for which they are prepared to fight for their citizens; there can be the peace of the grave; and there can be the peace of a totalitarian regime where every sign of dissension is crushed by brute force.

Let us talk about peace with freedom, because that is what we enjoy in this country and it is what we share with the other Western democracies. It is not fashionable these days to talk about the Soviet threat in relation to our security, particularly in an age of Mr Gorbachev and his doctrine of glasnost. All of us hope that the Soviets are maturing in their international relations. We in the Western nations have given them the opportunity to mature because we have not exacerbated relationships in any way at all while we have followed a policy of deterrence which provides for our own security. But the threat remains, and we must take cognisance of history. We hope that the Soviets are changing, but until they do we must maintain our own security. We need to be cautious.

The Western democracies have followed a policy of deterrence. As Senator Collins said, in the 1960s it was a policy of mutually assured destruction. In the 1970s it went to the doctrine of flexible response and that largely came about through the technological advance in the weapons systems that were being used. It is absolutely wrong and misleading for Senator Vallentine to claim that at present the United States intercontinental ballistic missiles are targeted irresponsibly against the civilian population. That is absolutely untrue. The United States missile force is targeted specifically against the arsenals of the Soviet Union. It is targeted there because it is a second strike capability; it is not a primary strike weapon. It would be irresponsible to waste targeting opportunities against a civilian population.

I would like to deal with deterrence in relation to a first and second strike capability. Deterrence turns on having a second strike capability; it is not a primary strike weapon. The Western democracies have made it very clear by their actions that they are not interested in aggression in any way at all. But for a second strike capability to exist, the weapons have to be survivable. Deterrence turns on not only having weapons systems but also on having sophisticated intelligence gathering capabilities, of which Pine Gap is a part, sophisticated command and control and a system of checks and balances built into those command and control systems so no unauthorised or misapplication of the force is possible. Deterrence is not an end in itself, but it is a means to an end and that end is peace. That is the aim of all mankind. We must now, with the strength of destructive power of nuclear weapons, have a situation where war will not occur. The deterrence policies of the Western democracies have brought this about over the last 40 years. I make the point that deterrence must be judged against the record of history, not against the emotional outpourings of people such as Senator Vallentine.

I now turn to Pine Gap and its place in the deterrence picture. Its place is in the sophisticated intelligence gathering field. It tells us and the United States what the Soviets are doing in relation to the testing of weapons. It tells us whether weapons are being launched and thereby tells us, from an analysis of their flight paths, whether they are launched offensively against Western democracies. It is an essential part in what is known as national technical means of verification. Senator Sanders showed his technical ignorance once more by saying that surveillance is performed by optical satellites operating in polar orbits. I do not wish to go into a discussion of satellite technology because a large part of it is classified. Very few optical satellites are being used by the United States at present. The imaging satellites are electro-optical systems these days and nearly all are of the KH-11 series. The optical ones have disappeared over the years. Pine Gap receives information from satellites about what the Soviets are doing with their missile system.

It always seems strange to me that at disarmament conferences in Geneva or at the United Nations in New York everyone applauds national technical means of verification and the existence of satellites and ground stations to receive information because of the guarantees they bring for peace and security through the knowledge they impart, yet in Australia people such as Senator Vallentine and Senator Sanders see satellites as instruments of darkness. One of the intents behind the anti-ballistic missile treaty is linked with the protection of satellites because of the protection they bring by guaranteeing knowledge of what the other side is doing.
The system of deterrence that we follow is a difficult system. It is complex and it certainly has some inherent dangers, but, as adults, we cannot walk away from those dangers.

DEBATE.TITLE: UNITED NATIONS GENERAL ASSEMBLY: FORTY-FIRST SESSION

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Bolkus Sen N.

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

It was felt throughout the UN that Australia was playing a very positive role in pursuing our policy objectives in those areas. The major policy objective that we are pursuing was that of disarmament. I think it is fair to say that the Australian delegation had major successes not only in respect of our major priority, which was the comprehensive test ban treaty resolution-which of all resolutions moved in this area of the United Nations managed to obtain the highest vote-but also when it came to issues such as chemical test ban treaties and interim regimes on notification of nuclear tests.

Whether it was on human rights, the financial crisis of the United Nations, where we played a positive leadership role, or in participating to the limited extent that we were in the Security Council, that respect was evident time and time again.

The one area where we both thought Australia lacked in terms of our contribution was the second committee. As our report states, although we felt that Australia made a major contribution on the agricultural trade issue, in the area of Third World debt I think we were hampered by the differences of opinion held by officers in the Department of the Treasury and the Department of Foreign Affairs. Once again I place on record my recognition of, and my thanks for, the support that both Senator Hill and I obtained from Ambassador Woolcott and all his staff at the United Nations. I wish to note in passing that we thought that this trip, which is available to parliamentarians, was an extremely important one not only in terms of our appreciation of foreign affairs issues and the Foreign Affairs Department but also in terms of the Department's understanding of how politicians work. I note with regret that this has not been allowed to continue this year and I hope that, because of a wide range of positive factors that both Senator Hill and I thought came out of this trip, the parliamentary advisory aspect of such delegations will be continued in future years.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: MacGibbon Sen D.J.

TALK.START.PARA: —In following Senator Bolkus in speaking to this report of the Australian delegation to the United Nations General Assembly, the point I want to address is the failure of the Government to fund parliamentarians on such delegations. This facility has been granted to members of the Senate and the House of Representatives for quite a few years. I do not know when it started but I was one of the delegates in 1983 and, as a parliamentarian, I found it an extremely valuable experience and everyone I know who has been there has the same view. Undeniably, it is an expensive trip because it involves two parliamentarians being in New York, with the associated high rental costs, for a period of three months through the duration of the General Assembly. But it has considerable educational benefits. The parliamentarians actually work in the mission and, therefore, work in a branch of the Department of Foreign Affairs and Trade and they make a contribution to the understanding and the views that professional Foreign Affairs officers have. Conversely, the parliamentarians themselves learn how the Foreign Affairs Department works. The Department of Foreign Affairs is different from the usual run of departments in the Australian bureaucracy.
—It is unusual.

—I think it is unusual in many ways but, unlike the mindless paper shuffling that goes on in departments such as Treasury, the Department of Foreign Affairs has a much more complex operation. One simply does not understand what goes on until one works in the office beside the officers and one goes through about three inches of cables that continually come in through the day from posts all round the world. One also learns about the practice of diplomacy. Of course, most diplomacy is practised on a one on one basis. There are Australian posts in London, Bonn, Tokyo and so on, and the relationship between the Australian Embassy and the host country is essentially a one on one relationship. The Australian mission to the United Nations in New York is the only place where we practise multilateral diplomacy, where we are dealing simultaneously with all the nations that make up the United Nations; I forget how many there are but it is in excess of 160.

SPEECH.PARA: For someone who has an interest in foreign affairs, the educational value of this trip is enormous. The role of foreign affairs is very much downgraded in this Parliament. We see the consequence of that in some of the problems we have in our trade at present. Very few people in this Senate and hardly anyone in the House of Representatives understands how the United States Congress works and how the United States House of Representatives and the United States Senate go through their legislative practice. A greater understanding of foreign affairs not only contributes to the defence of the country, which we were talking about in the previous debate, but also makes a significant impact on our standard of living insofar as it affects our understanding of trade and other matters like that.

I have not been able to work out why this post has been cut. It used to come to the Senate once every three years. I have not been following it because the Senate had a turn last year when Senator Hill and Senator Bolkus went and we would not be due to nominate senators until three years have elapsed. But somewhere in the arcane workings of the Australian Labor Party the decision was taken to cut it. Apparently it was funded out of the Department of Foreign Affairs vote and not out of the usual parliamentary travel entitlements. But if it was cancelled in the Department of Foreign Affairs the decision to cancel could not have been taken without the knowledge and approval of the Minister of Foreign Affairs and Trade (Mr Hayden) and I imagine that it would not have been done without the approval of the Caucus. Anyway, when the Department of Foreign Affairs refused to fund it, it then came to the Presiding Officers-the President of the Senate and the Speaker of the House of Representatives-and they similarly refused to fund it. As far as I am aware, no statement has ever been made in public as to why the Presiding Officers declined to carry on with these posts. I think it is something that the Senate should inquire into in due course because I believe that they provided a very valuable function, both to the Parliament and to the Department of Foreign Affairs.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

When I looked back through my notes I found that I had spoken previously on the report of the Insurance Commissioner. I rise again to speak on much the same sorts of issues. I think we are inclined to believe that insurance is the safety net that covers everything and we do not need to worry too much about it. But insurance is now an extraordinarily large business. DEBATE.SUB1.TITLE: Report of Australian Science and Technology Council

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Coulter Sen J.R.

TALK.START.PARA: —I move:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Senate take note of the paper.

I note that the reference to the Australian Science and Technology Council was very much in terms of how Australia might increase its competitiveness through innovation and technological transformation. I rise to speak because I wish to make the point that I made in my maiden speech; namely, that it is wrong and inappropriate for Australia to continue to encourage competitiveness when what we need to do is encourage co-operation. In a world in which the economic pattern is part of the total environmental and biospheric pattern we can become more competitive and expand only at the expense of the natural environment. We are now in danger of destroying that very biosphere on which we depend. In this case we have given to a body a term of reference which has guided it to make recommendations which are perhaps contrary to the recommendations that a better informed government and a better informed body may have made. I note that Professor Slatyer, a biologist, chaired the body which examined this reference, but I note also that it contains many people from industry. Not surprisingly, it responded in this very conservative and rather anachronistic way to this inappropriate reference.

TALK.START.PARA: —Is that fair to Professor Slatyer?

—I am not casting any aspersions on Professor Slatyer. On the contrary, I think that Professor Slatyer, given a different reference, may well have come to different conclusions: it was inappropriate for the Government to have given him such a limited term of reference which prevented him from questioning that term of reference. The principal recommendations, which are on pages 4 and 5 of the report, begin by referring to greater national competitiveness requiring many individual companies to become more innovative and to develop different approaches. Clearly the Council was constrained by the terms of reference. I simply rise to make the point that I hope that in future this Parliament will give references which are more comprehensive and which will allow an alternative approach to the future which takes into account the limited nature of the natural environment to respond to further expansion of human industrial development.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chaney Sen The Hon F.M.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr Deputy President, the report on improving Australia's competitiveness through industrial research and development has a number of recommendations and I wish to touch on the recommendation which relates to investment in the work force by giving the work force a chance to invest in the enterprise. One of the recommendations is that the Government examine ways of simplifying present regulations to enable greater use of share option schemes and in particular allow employees to be taxed upon sale of shares rather than when options are exercised. On behalf of the Opposition I very much welcome that recommendation of the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC), because the Opposition has had as its policy for some time the encouragement of employee share ownership, not merely in the sort of high technology companies to which this report specifically refers but generally. Indeed, both last year and earlier this year in the course of the election campaign we argued that it would be very helpful to Australia's present situation if we could encourage employees to have a proprietary interest in the enterprise for which they work. As we said before that would achieve the three objectives of greater reward for effort, improved productivity and greater industrial harmony. ASTEC has brought forward the specific problem which is faced by high technology companies-that many of Australia's best research scientists have been attracted overseas by better conditions of employment. This is part of the brain drain that seems to have been going on for a great period in Australia.

SPEECH.PARA: The report usefully points out that in many overseas countries share options are provided in those companies which do not necessarily have the capacity to pay very large salaries initially, because they are just starting up, but are able to offer the prospect to employees of sharing in the wealth that the employees themselves create. That seems to be so obvious as to be almost not worth saying, but the fact is that we do place impediments in the way of employee share ownership in Australia which could be removed and which would encourage the greater use of share options and share ownership generally.

My purpose in raising this afternoon is to direct the attention of the Government to the recommendations of ASTEC. The fact that they square with the views of the Opposition should not deter the Government from considering them. I do not believe reform in this area should be delayed until after the next election when we return to government. I wish to encourage the Government to look at both the company law barriers to the granting of both share options and shares and at the taxation laws which put a taxation penalty on employees who receive shares at a discount. This is not part of any suggestion that there should be the promotion of packages for the high-fliers, the top managers and so on; I do not wish to confuse this proposal with that. I am suggesting that both for key members of the work force and for the work force generally there can be a great increase in incentive if employees feel that the effort they are putting in, both mental and physical, is investing not only in the enterprise that employs them but also in their own interests. I hope that the Government will look carefully at the evidence brought forward by the Business Council of Australia and others, which shows that, both in the United Kingdom and the United States, companies that go down the employee share ownership track have markedly better performance in terms of appreciation in their value as enterprises and in terms of their profit performance, productivity increases, and so on.

Closer to home, there are some very encouraging indications that employee share ownership has provided a significant boost to productivity. I recently visited in Launceston one of the old Repco bearing plant factories. That factory, which is competing with South America and the United States, has seen a 50 per cent lift in output since the employee takeover last year with direct employees receiving 10 per cent of the shareholding. That sort of increase in output, almost all of which is going into export, is precisely what we need to see in every enterprise around Australia if we are to get out of our present difficulties. I commend, therefore, that part of the ASTEC report for the Government's very early consideration and action.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Lewis Sen A.W.R

TALK.START.PARA: —In the course of debating the Government papers tabled today, the Senate is currently looking at a report to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) entitled Improving Australia's Competitiveness through Industrial Research and Development. SPEECH.SPEAKER: Cook Sen P.F.S.

—Senator Cook, you have only three minutes in which to speak and if you are interrupted by the sessional order the matter will be placed on the Notice Paper anyway.

—In that case, I will take my three minutes. I am glad that the report to the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) by the Australian Science and Technology Council (ASTEC) entitled Improving Australia's Competitiveness through Industrial Research and Development is coming under some scrutiny in the Senate. My purpose in rising to speak, however, is not to go into some of those matters which the last speaker, Senator Lewis, referred to, although they are vitally important. Any effort to improve Australia's research and development output and to maintain the benefits that that creates within the Australian economy is, of course, central to our industry getting the necessary edge it needs to develop further and to penetrate other markets. From a trading point of view we would want to see that occur in order that the industrial strength of Australia is improved to the benefit of its population. That is a vitally important area. My purpose in rising is to respond to some of the remarks made by Senator Chaney when he referred to the employee share recommendation on page 31 of the report. ASTEC recommended:

SPEECH.PARA: That the Government examine ways of simplifying present regulations to enable greater use of share option schemes, and in particular, allow employees to be taxed upon sale of shares rather than when share options are exercised.

I think that the Senate should be aware that the Government, through the then Minister for Employment and Industrial Relations, now the Minister for Industrial Relations (Mr Willis), has issued a Green Paper on industrial democracy.
