Given that this is what was decided by 70 per cent of the people who voted, it seems to me quite despicable that the Premier of Tasmania took the action that he did with respect to the resignation of Don Grimes. The Premier had no hesitation in subverting the Constitution. In fact, this was much worse than what had been done in the past because, quite clearly, he ought to have followed the spirit of the change that was made to the Constitution and appointed the properly made nomination of the Australian Labor Party.

In fact the actions that were carried out at that stage of the proceedings were far worse than anything that had been done in the past. In this instance, not only was the nominee put up by the Labor Party not appointed but also the Premier of Tasmania in fact tried to blackmail me to the extent of saying that, provided I was prepared to follow his dictates and those of the Liberal Party in this place, he would support the nomination. I find it absolutely disgraceful that that sort of activity can go on in parliaments around Australia.

It is quite remarkable that there has been a deafening silence on the political scene, particularly in my home State of Tasmania, about that occurrence. I guess that silence is really due to the fact that people want us to believe that, because there was an election, the matter is now solved. Quite clearly in my view the matter is not solved at all. If any State government decides now, under the current Constitution, to act in the same way as Robin Gray did in respect of vacancies in the Senate, the very thing we saw in 1975 could happen. My very strong view is that the matter in Tasmania will never be settled. Technically there is still a vacancy in Tasmania because a decision has never been made by the Tasmanian Parliament to fill the vacancy created by the resignation of Don Grimes, albeit that an election intervened.

It is my very strong view that all parties and all members of both Houses of Parliament ought to adopt a position that an alteration should be made to the Constitution which quite clearly spells out that any senator who resigns should be replaced by the nominee of the party to which the retiring senator belonged. I do not think that the vacancy should be left unfilled.

Over the last five months or so since this whole episode started I have been told by people from the other side of this place, `Oh no, we do not support what Robin Gray did. It was quite wrong and you should have been here'. I have heard some of those things said before. But certainly my experience, both as a trade union official and in the political arena, has led me to believe-and it has been a harsh lesson-that just because people say those things, that is not necessarily the course that they follow because when the time comes they can be subject to political expediency. I think it is essential that an alteration be made to the Constitution to prevent that sort of thing happening again.

If in fact some of the things that I have heard about this issue from people on the other side were true, I guess I would be saying to myself, `I wonder why I stood and came to this place in the first place'. I became a trade union official and then stood for a position in political life because I supported equal rights for people. I support people's rights to equality in education and employment. I certainly have a very strong view about the use of our natural resources and the position we ought to be adopting on them for the betterment of everybody in this country.

Having listened to some of the speeches in this place over the last five or six weeks, I thought back to the issue in Tasmania. I thought, `Well, maybe it's true that in this place there are some people who don't hold the same views as Robin Gray. Maybe they wouldn't do the same things'. Of course, I stopped believing in fairies a long time ago. In fact, as I recall it, I stopped believing in them when I was about five years old. If people look back on their childhood, they probably believed, as I used to believe, in the tooth fairy. I remember quite clearly that one night, after a tooth had fallen out, as had happened previously, I put it in a glass of water on the mantlepiece. On such occasions I would sneak out now and again during the night to see whether the fairy had been. It so happened that this night when I was about five I sneaked out, looked around the door and saw my father fiddling with the glass on the table. I thought to myself, `What is he up to? He's pinching my money'. As it turned out, after I had watched for a little while, I discovered that he was putting sixpence in the glass. I said to myself, `There you go, things aren't quite what they seem'. I must admit that I did not tell my father about this. If he is listening to the broadcast today, he might find out about the day that I stopped believing in the tooth fairy.

I was quite often reminded of that event in the course of my career as a trade union official because, as I said, things are not always what they seem. I have been told many times by people during negotiations that they will do certain things, that they are very concerned about workers' rights, and so forth. But the funny thing is that, when it comes down to the wire, that is not what happens. What people say on many occasions is quite false. When I look back over the period of the Senate vacancy and line up what happened then with what happened in this chamber four weeks or so ago, I discover that it is no different here.

I refer to the legislation to do with the ID card. Quite clearly the final death of the ID card legislation did not really concern whether one agreed or disagreed with the legislation. What happened regarding the way in which that legislation was destroyed was no different from what was done in Tasmania by Robin Gray. It was simply an exercise. Regardless of how people try to defend the situation, the truth is that for 87 years no piece of legislation was completely destroyed by the Opposition threatening to disallow regulations. So there is no difference between what happened in the course of that debate and what happened in regard to the Senate vacancy. It was simply a matter of people deciding that some political mileage could be made out of an issue. They said, `Let us not worry about the conventions. Let us not worry about all the principles that have applied for 87 years'. That is a very important point.

Of course, something very important came out of that debate. Many people in the course of the debate talked about their great commitment to the protection of people's civil liberties and their great commitment to ensuring that there was no tax avoidance or social welfare fraud in this country. I am sure that some people will be hoist with their own petard in the next few months when attempts are made by this Government to do something about tax avoidance and social welfare fraud.

I found the position that some honourable senators took on civil liberties during that debate quite amusing, particularly when I heard Senator Bjelke-Petersen talking about the protection of people's civil liberties. As the national president of the Electrical Trades Union (ETU), during the South East Queensland Electricity Board dispute I had occasion to spend some time in Queensland. When I listened to the honourable senator's speech that day, a couple of instances came to my mind.

I will give the background to one incident. Some 200 people had been arrested for picketing outside the New Farm depot. I happened to be one of those people and I was due to appear in the Magistrates Court the next day, after spending some hours on that day as a guest of Her Majesty. The next day I was walking through the streets of Brisbane to the Magistrates Court and a young fellow dressed in a pair of jeans and a tatty old jumper pulled me up and flashed a badge in front of me. He told me that he was a police officer and that I was to go over to the other side of the street. I said, `What for?'. He said, `I'm just telling you to go over to the other side of the street'. I said, `Well, it's a bit peculiar. I'm just on my way to the Magistrates Court. What do I have to go over there for?'. He said, `I'm just telling you to'. I said, `Well, I have some rights. If you're telling me to go somewhere, you can tell me the reason why'. He said, `You've got no rights and if you don't go over there you'll be arrested'. In fact, that is exactly what he did. It took me about another 12 hours to get to the Magistrates Court. When I got there 12 hours late and appeared before the magistrate, I still did not know what I was charged with. It turned out that I was charged with taking part in a procession which was not a funeral. Anyway, we live and learn.

On the same day as 200 people were arrested at the New Farm depot, a number of our officials from around Australia were attending that picket. One of our Victorian organisers was some 200 metres away from the entrance to the depot and was talking to five or six members of the ETU. They were having quite an amiable discussion. A police officer told the official to leave them alone. The six people said, `Well, he is doing no harm'. The official said, `Look, they are members of ours, they are quite happy to talk to me and I have some rights to talk to my membership'. I guess the answer from the police officer summed it up. He said, `You've got no rights here in Queensland. You're under arrest'. With that background, Mr President, I think you could well understand my amusement when I heard certain people here talking about civil liberties and people's rights. I do not propose to say anything more about that subject. I think I may well have made the point.

Before I move on to a couple of matters dealing with my home State, there is one matter that is gaining some notoriety at the moment about which I would certainly like to comment-that is, the proposal that is floating around about a wealth inquiry. I place on record that I strongly support a wealth inquiry. In fact, I certainly agree with Bill Kelty's statement that we probably do not need an inquiry, that we ought to have a wealth tax anyway. I would prefer that there be an inquiry because I believe that that inquiry would reveal a couple of things that the public of Australia ought to be well aware of. I find it quite difficult to swallow the fact that, from 1984 to 1986, the accumulated wealth of the 200 richest people in Australia has increased from $7.3 billion to $14.8 billion-more than a 100 per cent increase. I am sure that the working people of Australia also find it very difficult to swallow that fact when they-and it is a fact-have lost 7 per cent of their take home earnings. There ought to be an inquiry into how that situation could come about when we are all being asked to tighten our belts. I think that that is a very important factor that would come out of the inquiry.

We ought also to be investigating just how some of those people came to have that money in the first place. A very important question is raised. It makes me feel quite ill when I hear some of those people or their agents having the audacity to say that unemployed people, people with low paid jobs, those on pensions and so forth are bludgers. How much work have some of those 200 people who say those things about good honest Australians really done for that money? I suggest that an inquiry would reveal that they have not done much work at all. I doubt that many of them-I would not want to say `any of them'-have even stood very close to a worker. It is wrong that that sort of thing goes on and that sort of wealth is accumulated without some sort of inquiry into the matter. I want to have clearly placed on record my support for that inquiry.

In my experience as an ETU official, I was very much involved at both national and State level with industrial development, particularly the trade training aspects of industrial life and people in the work place. I see my position as a senator as simply an extension of that. In this place, and particularly in my home State, I will be strongly pursuing some of the objectives in those areas that I pursued as a trade union official. I particularly welcome one of those things in regard to education. I find it very welcome that there will be some changes, particularly in the training of people in the workplace, with much more relevance to the needs of industry. For a long time, there has been a myth abroad that all of the demarcation issues in industry were simply caused by workers. Anyone who has spent any time in industry would know that the truth is that many of the problems of demarcation were created by the system that has been built into industry for a long time. I am not saying that workers and unions were not responsible for some of that, but very largely the sort of hierarchy set-up in industry has been just as much, if not more, the fault of industry and the management of industry. I welcome the change there, and I hope that, through the changes going on at the initiative of this Government, a much wider opportunity will be granted for people to gain more skills in industry.

Another thing that I am doing at the moment is to initiate in Tasmania a seminar, to be held on 12 November, of which the theme is the role that education, industry, trade unions and the Government can play in industry development. I think that it will be an important seminar for Tasmania. It is unfortunate that there has been a much greater degree of activity in this area in other States, while there has been a great neglect of such a co-operative approach in Tasmania. I hope that, in running the seminar, I can start some real movement in the State and get true co-operation between people to improve the performance of Tasmania. In the use of our natural resources and manufacturing in the State, our record has been abysmal, particularly over the last few years. There are a few lights on the horizon. In particular, the unions have for some time been pushing Comalco Aluminium (Bell Bay) Ltd. The company has agreed to go in for some downstream production at its aluminium plant. This initiative has really come from the workers and the trade unions in the plant. I hope that that will expand enormously in the future, and I think that it will be a great lift for Tasmania.

We are also talking to the Electrolytic Zinc Co. of Australasia Ltd about a large plant, and I hope that in the future there will be some movement. The EZ company, through the research and development grants of the Federal Government, has made a lot of improvements, with a pilot plant being set up. More particularly, in the area of downstream processing, it has an enormous research and development plant, which unfortunately many people in Tasmania do not seem to be aware of. Also unfortunately, many of its products, while at the state of being commercially viable, are not yet produced commercially in Tasmania. I have been working with other people to try to encourage the company, if not to go into the downstream processing itself, to assist in setting up some other companies around the State to start producing some wealth for Tasmania out of our natural resources.

I want to close on an area that has been a source of great debate in Tasmania, as I am sure that everyone here is aware. I refer to the great waste of our forestry resources over the years. Regardless of what is said, there has been enormous waste in the forest industry in Tasmania. I think that the Federal Government should be applauded for setting up the Helsham Commission of Inquiry into logging in the Lemonthyme and Southern Forests area of Tasmania, which, if nothing else, will assist in doing something about the enormous waste that has been going on. To highlight that waste, I can do no more than read out a letter published in the Mercury on Monday, 28 September, 1987. I ought to read that letter to the Senate because it is very important. If I or some other people were to make some of the points in the letter, they would be immediately construed as coming from somebody on the left wing of the Labor Party or somebody in the Wilderness Society. However, this letter came as a result of meetings that were held in Hobart between people who worked in the forestry industry such as small sawmill owners, people in the woodcraft industry and furniture makers. As a result, a small sawmiller named Darrell Brown took a number of members of the Woodcraft Guild on a tour of the Mountain River area. To finish my contribution, I will read that letter, which is signed by Antony De Lara, the president of the Woodcraft Guild. He said:

At the invitation of Darrell Brown, an operator of a small sawmill at Mountain River, about 30 members of the Woodcraft Guild Tasmania spent an afternoon viewing the logging operations taking place in the Russell River area. We were dismayed to note the large quantity of minor species timbers such as myrtle, sassafras, leatherwood, etc, which had simply been felled and burnt on the ground for no other reason than to provide a seed bed for the replanting of eucalypts.

Within a few metres of the edge of the coupe, Mr Brown showed us a felled and burned myrtle, the timber of which was a deep red and which before borer insects had got into it would have been capable of yielding at least 400 super feet of furniture grade timber probably worth, as completed items, in excess of $5,000.

A few paces from the myrtle he showed us a sassafras log which had started to rot because it was felled about 18 months ago. Before the rot set in that single log, as finished tourist souvenir items, must have been worth $3,000 to $4,000 to the Tasmanian economy.
The coupe concerned exhibited very few eucalypt stumps, the trees for which it was presumably logged, but there was a very large number of felled and burned minor species trunks strewn around.

When asked why the area had been logged in the manner in which it had been, an accompanying senior Forestry Commission officer, who is also a guild member, replied he did not know because logging did not come within his area of responsibility.

That statement highlights the whole problem within our forests so far as specialised timbers are concerned. There is no department within the Forestry Commission or elsewhere which is specifically responsible for the care, maintenance and harvesting of Tasmania's beautiful and increasingly rare so-called minor species timbers. The commission's whole orientation is towards the logging and replanting of eucalypts.

Our host pointed out to us that far from there being 20 years' supply of our specialised timbers available within the Huon region as we had supposed, there are, unless very drastic action is taken concerning the manner in which the area's old growth mixed forests are logged, as little as three years' supply left.

The Woodcraft Guild would like to repeat and emphasise its call for a moratorium on the logging of old growth mixed forest with less than 50 per cent eucalypt canopy cover until such time as a specialised timber industry plan has been drawn up and implemented. The need for such a moratorium and for the establishment of an adequately staffed and financed forestry department with specific minor species timber responsibilities is probably even more urgent than the guild had initially supposed.
I do not think I can say any more than that. With that I conclude my remarks and look forward to taking part in debates in this place in the future.

TALK.START.PARA: —Before I call Senator Chapman, I remind honourable senators that this is his maiden speech in this chamber. I ask that the usual courtesies be extended to him.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Chapman Sen H.G.P.

TALK.START.PARA: —Mr President, may I commence by congratulating you on your re-election as President of the Senate and indicating that I look forward to contributing to the deliberations of this chamber under your conduct of proceedings. I also note the presence in the chamber of Senator David Hamer and I pass on to him my congratulations on his re-election as Deputy President and Chairman of Committees.

SPEECH.PARA: Mr President, your call for the traditional courtesies of a maiden speech to be extended to me reminds me that being elected to serve in both Houses of this Parliament at different times is virtually a unique way in which a person can be restored to maidenhood. In passing, it is worth noting that Mr J. R. Odgers, in his celebrated Australian Senate Practice, states that it is a time honoured custom that a new senator making his initial speech to the Senate is heard without interjection or interruption. However, my research shows that this has not always been the case. Although this traditional courtesy appears to have been afforded new senators for some decades, it seems that early in 1968 was the first occasion on which a presiding officer drew attention to the fact that a senator was about to deliver his maiden speech. Somewhat earlier than that, it appears that the tradition of courtesy had not yet been established. I refer to the maiden speech of my grandfather's cousin, Senator John Hedley Chapman, in the Senate in 1926. His speech received several interruptions by way of interjection, albeit apparently helpful in nature. It is therefore of some interest to see how the tradition of this courtesy has developed to the stage where someone such as me, who was initially afforded the privilege of delivering a maiden speech in the House of Representatives almost 12 years ago, is afforded that opportunity a second time by returning to this Parliament, in a different chamber, after an absence of some 4 1/2 years.

I valued the opportunity to represent the people of the south-western suburbs of Adelaide as member for Kingston in the House of Representatives for some 7 1/2 years from 1975 and look forward to that experience, combined with further experience of private enterprise gained over the last 4 1/2 years in what some would call the `real world', equipping me to make an effective contribution to the policy and issue deliberations of this chamber. I must say that it is a particular pleasure to have been elected to the Senate at this time and thereby have an opportunity to serve in this historic chamber before the move to the new Parliament House next year. It is also satisfying to rejoin so many of my colleagues who were first elected with me at the 1975 election and, in particular, Senators Michael Baume and Short, who, like me, following defeat after several terms in their marginal lower House seats, have returned to service in the Senate.

I well recall the despair we '75ers caused the Labor Opposition as their initial taunts of `oncers' had to be changed to `twicers' and in the case of so many of us `thricers'. It is also a privilege to have the opportunity to serve in the same chamber as the earlier Senator Chapman to whom I referred and also a cousin of my mother's by marriage, Senator Edmund Piesse, who represented Western Australia in this place in the early 1950s, and of course to be here with my present cousin a couple of times removed, Senator Baden Chapman Teague. This comes close to matching the cousins Baume, who surround me closely at the moment, but, of course, falls short of the brothers McGauran in the present Parliament.

I come to this place determined, firstly, to do effectively my job as a senator, recognising that the Senate is the last institution in Australia capable of ensuring that the Executive governs through the Parliament, rather than by decree, Press release, ordinances or regulations. I will resist any attempts to dilute the power, role and responsibility of the Senate as an effective House of review. In particular, the recent suggestions by the Constitutional Commission to limit the Senate's power over legislation to that of delay only, should not be countenanced. To equate this democratically elected chamber with the hereditary and nominated House of Lords lacks all logic.

Secondly, I come to this chamber as a South Australian, elected to this States House with the responsibility of representing South Australia. Notwithstanding the apparent decline of the Senate as a States House, if senators remain mindful of the constitutional intent of this chamber, it can continue to play a role in providing more effective representation for the less populous States than is possible simply through their House of Representatives representation. In proportionate terms, the representative role of senators is much more important to the smaller States than it is to New South Wales or Victoria.

Thirdly, I come to this chamber as a Liberal, both by philosophical inclination and by party identification. I am grateful to those members of the Liberal Party State Council in South Australia who made the judgment to support my preselection for the fourth position on the South Australian Liberal Senate ticket for the recent Federal election, and will do my best to fulfil the expectations which they have of me in representing the Liberal Party. I also thank the many thousands of Liberal Party members and supporters whose hard work throughout that election campaign ensured the election of my colleagues and me. It was no fault of theirs that the ultimate prize of winning government eluded us.

My Liberal philosophy is derived from that of the traditional English Liberals, such as Hume, Burke and Adam Smith, rather than that of the so-called European Liberals. Spontaneity and the absence of coercion are the hallmarks of this Liberal philosophy, with its commitment to limiting the extent to which Government interferes with the lives of individuals, including their economic lives. Liberal parliamentarians must not succumb to the temptation which elected office provides to override these basic Liberal principles, often for the best of motives.

In the context of being a senator, a South Australian and a Liberal, it is appropriate to direct my remaining comments to a subject which received brief reference in the opening speech by His Excellency and coincidentally was part of the subject matter I addressed in my very last speech in the House of Representatives, on what subsequently turned out to be the very last sitting day of the Thirty-second Parliament, 14 December 1982, with the 1983 election having been called during the subsequent summer recess. That subject matter is Australian industrial relations structures and practices, the reform of which I believe to be the single most important issue facing this nation. The rigidities and coercion involved in our present structure are inconsistent with liberalism and detrimental to the interests of small States like South Australia, which require greater labour market flexibility to enable them to compete on interstate and overseas markets, and therefore are appropriate for consideration in fulfilling the review role of a senator.

During my 4 1/2 years away from this place I have watched with interest the new-found `stay in government at any cost' pragmatism of the Australian Labor Party (ALP), which, in pursuit of electoral popularity, has seen it move, or create the illusion of moving, close to the Liberal Party in many areas of policy. However, the one area in which, for the sake of this country's economic health, it has been most important for the Government to move towards the Liberal Party and modernise its approach, but which it has completely failed to do, is in the field of industrial relations. It is the field of industrial relations which continually reminds us that, whatever illusions this Government may create about itself, it remains the creature of the trade union movement and its political purpose is to do that movement's bidding. This explains the bizarre behaviour of the Prime Minister (Mr Hawke) at the Commonwealth Heads of Government Meeting. This fervent republican swore undying allegiance to his Queen. He vowed that, as ever in the past, he would do anything and everything his Queen told him to do. It turned out that he had another faulty earplug. He though that they were saying `Crean', not `Queen'.

During the life of this Government we have seen two analyses of our industrial relations structure and practices undertaken with Government support-firstly, the report of the Hancock Committee of Review into Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems and, more recently, the document Australia Reconstructed. Both of these documents ignore present day realities by reinforcing the continuation of our present outmoded and failed system. Indeed, the Government sought to further entrench this system through the industrial relations legislation introduced in the latter part of the last Parliament, based on the recommendations of the Hancock report. Such was the fury this legislation generated among the growing number of people who recognise the need for drastic change that it was temporarily shelved. But the recent publication of Australia Reconstructed demonstrates that the unions' push for the further entrenchment of their privileged position is again on the Government's agenda.

Professor Richard Blandy of the National Institute of Labour Studies at Flinders University has accurately described the Hancock report on industrial relations as `the last hurrah of the past, rather than a blueprint for the future'. It is a product of the cosy industrial relations club which dominated Hancock Committee membership and establishes no relevant truths about the merits of Australia's present industrial system. Instead, it reflects the conservatism, risk aversion and values of the club. It reflects the fact that industry peak councils, the Australian Council of Trade Unions (ACTU) and tribunals have become a common interest group, concentrating on short term compromise solutions rather than tackling basic problems and longer term issues.

The report attempts to set in concrete our outdated 80-year-old system of industrial relations. Professor Blandy describes the Committee's recommendations as `defuturising'-a term derived from the famous Dutch sociologist, Fred Polak, who said:

. . . a retreat from constructive thinking about the future, in order to dig oneself into the trenches of the present. It is a ruthless elimination of future-centred idealism by today-centred realism. We have lost the ability to see any further than our collective nose.

The Hancock report fails completely to make a positive case for our arbitration system. It does not tell us how, or even if, its proposals will correct the major defects of our present system, which are the lack of productivity related wage levels and the high level of industrial disputation. Nor does it indicate a path to faster innovation and more vigorous entrepreneurship, to higher productivity, to lower unemployment and inflation and, in general, to a better Australia for us all. It resigns itself to the tyranny of the status quo, because that is what the unions want and neither the Government nor the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission is sufficiently independent of the unions. It completely fails to address what ought to be the proper extent of union power in Australia. On the contrary, the Committee has chosen to accentuate the power of the unions in Australia by advocating the removal of all remaining legal sanctions against unions, retaining for the Conciliation and Arbitration Commission only an H-bomb equivalent, of union deregistration for persistent disobedience.

While failing to substantiate its own advocacy of the present system, the Hancock report dismisses the arguments for change on the basis that they have not met the requirement of demonstrating definite and decisive advantages. But it never states the required standard of proof, particularly with regard to a decentralised and deregulated alternative system.

This resistance to necessary modernisation is reinforced by the report Australia Reconstructed. Although this has been promoted as a document of the ACTU, which has, in fact, endorsed the report, the most frightening aspect is that it was sponsored by this Labor Government and written by public servants at taxpayers' expense. When it is understood that a major part of the work was undertaken by Mr Ted Wilshire of the Trade Development Council, it is not hard to understand its analysis and conclusions. Ted Wilshire has been closely associated with Ted Wheelwright, one of the founders of the Marxist political economy course at the University of Sydney, which is often referred to as the Bessy degree. In drafting this document, Wilshire would have received much support for his old guard left wing views from some of the other members of the joint ACTU-Trade Development Council mission that visited Europe in preparing this document. These include Tom McDonald of the Building Workers Industrial Union of Australia, the successor to Pat Clancy of the pro-Soviet Communist Party; Laurie Carmichael of the Amalgamated Metal Workers Union, ex-communist and born-again socialist; and Colin Cooper of the left wing Australian Telecommunications Employees Association.

Indeed, a member of the ALP has suggested to me that Australia Reconstructed is simply the left wing's prescription for gaining more power, while people like Carmichael and Halfpenny are chasing more Government money for their industry, the metal trades industry, which their activities helped to destroy in the 1970s and early 1980s. The words of the present Federal Treasurer (Mr Keating) to the 1986 ALP biennial conference in Hobart are pertinent. He said:
I say this to the George Campbells and others. They carry the jobs of dead men around their necks in the manufacturing industry with the $39 a week in the metal trades agreement in 1981.

The report is purportedly based on investigations carried out in Europe, but it does a good job of rewriting the economic history of Europe, as well as the recent economic history of Australia, before drawing its conclusions and recommendations from that rewritten history. Its implementation would embody the worst excesses of the corporate state of big government, big unions and big business. It is, therefore, not surprising that it is shot full of contradictions. While purporting to recognise the need for wage adjustments to be made on the basis of `price and productivity movements in the internationally traded goods and services sector', this is contradicted in the same breath by limiting it to wages other than national adjustments under the centralised wage system. At page 91 the report says:

Australian industry assistance traditionally relied on barrier protection-tariffs, bounties, import quotas. It is now widely accepted that this assistance contributed to an uncompetitive manufacturing industry.
However, in recommendation 1.6 concerning the establishment of a national development fund based on superannuation contributions, it says:
. . . if insufficient funds are available through the superannuation mechanism, there should be a one per cent tax on all imports supplemented by a surcharge on luxury imports.
Recommendation 4.5 says, in part,
. . . skills accords should be negotiated at the local and enterprise level.

However, this hint at decentralisation is stopped dead in its tracks by the recommendation that for the national employment and training fund, which is to be financed by a tax on companies, the trade union movement be given an effective veto over which companies will be allowed to draw training funds from the fund. Agreement must be reached with the unions-and, it should be emphasised, with the unions, not the employees-on matters such as superannuation, disputes settlement procedures, work and management practices, job security and even purchasing policy before such funds would be available to the company. Chapter by chapter, the analysis and recommendations of Australia Reconstructed resurrect old left wing shibboleths.

Who said the 1970s were dead? Donald Horne has arisen, like Skyhooks or Jimi Hendrix, with a sequel to the sequel to The Lucky Country, with a statement last week finding nothing but virtue in Australia Reconstructed. But, of course, Professor Horne is Chairman of the Australia Council. His job is to promote Australian fiction.

In proposing the establishment of a national development fund, the authors demonstrate their complete lack of understanding of the nature of investment. The history of national economic plans and centralised economic decision-making is that they lead to inferior economic results. At page 93, the report states:

If industry is to make substantial commitments on investment and employees are to undertake appropriate skills development, it is essential that firms and individuals are able to plan ahead with certainty.

Surely the events of the past few days on international share markets demonstrate the impossibility of planning ahead with anything remotely like certainty. This is why decentralised decision-making in economic affairs is essential. The last thing the Australian economy needs in its present situation is a series of five-year economic plans whereby national goals and decisions are determined by powerful representatives of big government, big unions and big business under a corporate state mentality.

In its approach to wages policy, the report ignores the need for all wage determinations to be based on productivity and international competitiveness. In addition, by trying to compress wage relativities, the Australian Council of Trade Unions will obscure a crucial mechanism for delivering signals to individuals to adjust their economic activity. Changes in wages and prices promote restructuring quickly and efficiently. Yet in advocating the approach of Australia Reconstructed the ACTU, while purportedly keen to restructure the Australian economy, seems intent on fudging these signals and instead is proposing to direct change through taxes and subsidies determined by committees.

The recommendations concerning the implementation of industrial democracy programs represent a further union grab for power. Consultation with employees and their industrial representatives is good management practice which can be highly beneficial to an enterprise, but this is a far cry from unions becoming an integral part of the business decision-making process, which Australia Reconstructed seeks. This would make it increasingly difficult for management to make decisions against the wishes of the trade unions.

The recommended creation of 20 super-unions is directly contrary to an expansion of enterprise-level employee participation. It is unreasonable to expect employers to introduce industrial democracy programs at the enterprise level, when the unions intend amalgamating into super-unions which will force the creation of bigger employer groups, more centralised negotiation and arbitration and make the system more remote from the individual requirements and peculiarities at the enterprise level. The prerogative of management to manage an enterprise must not be subverted.

The sad fact is that both the Hancock Review of the Australian Industrial Relations Law and Systems and Australia Reconstructed fail to offer adequate solutions to our industrial problems. Fortunately, there is a better way. That is the approach which I first advocated in 1981 and which I am pleased to see was largely adopted by the Liberal Party as its industrial relations policy for the last election. That better way is a more market-oriented system of industrial relations and wage determination. The need for improvement is obvious. Australia's record of industrial disputation remains one of the worst in the world and continues to be a disincentive for productive investment both from internal and overseas sources.

The advocacy nature of our present industrial relations structure heightens the atmosphere of conflict, rather than co-operation, between employers and employees. The concept of comparative wage justice, with wage determinations in one sector of industry flowing on to other sectors and individual enterprises, irrespective of their capacity to pay, hinders economic growth. Conflict between Commonwealth and State awards leads to strained employer-employee relationships, especially when these complexities impinge on one employer.

Impediments to change, whether they be lack of political will, the influence of the industrial relations club or the unfounded fear that a more decentralised, deregulated system would lead to industrial anarchy must be overcome. The changes to be implemented must recognise that in the post-industrial society there is a movement to small scale organisation, with modern technology and entrepreneurship meaning that smaller scale production units have become more viable relative to larger scale mass production.

Our industrial relations system must therefore incorporate greater flexibility to encourage productivity growth. This requires a more decentralised system of wage determination, to allow direct negotiations and agreements to be reached, between employer and employees, acting at the individual enterprise level. The individual must be allowed to accept employment, if he so desires, at a market level of remuneration, rather than being forced to accept unemployment as the alternative.

Wage determination must be based on a combination of national productivity and Australia's international competitiveness, with the individual capacity to pay at the enterprise level. Highly profitable enterprises should share those profits with the employees who have assisted to create them, but less profitable enterprises should not be sent broke by being saddled with wage structures they cannot afford. To encourage this and generally to ensure an improvement in employer-employee relations, the present craft basis for our trade union structure must be replaced, not with super-unions, but with an enterprise-based structure. This must be linked to voluntary union membership, which would be the greatest incentive for unions to genuinely represent their members' views rather than those of the union leadership. While unions must have the capacity to effectively represent their members, they currently have too much power. This must be curbed by ensuring that employers and unions are equal before the law.

Recent events reinforce the vulnerability of the Australian economy and, with it, our standard of living and way of life. A change to our system of industrial relations is central to the necessary goal of greater national productivity. It is my contention that the changes I have outlined will do much to achieve that improvement. However, they will not be achieved overnight, nor can they all be achieved by legislative fiat. A great deal must be achieved by a marked change in attitude, especially among militant trade union leaders, to allow greater co-operation between employers and employees, in the recognition that they do have common interests and must develop unity of purpose. I trust I will see this necessary change implemented before too many years of my period of service in this chamber have passed.

Before concluding, may I congratulate other newly-elected senators who have made their maiden speeches during this Address-in-Reply debate. May I also pay tribute to those senators from the coalition side who retired at the last election. Senators Collard, Townley, Jessop, Carrick, Dame Margaret Guilfoyle and Withers were all well known to me as colleagues during my previous period of service. I valued their friendship and counsel during that time. They each made effective contributions to the welfare of Australia during extended periods of service, the latter three serving with distinction as Ministers of the Crown.

I pay particular tribute to my former South Australian colleague, Senator Don Jessop, who like me, served in both Houses of this Parliament and as a senator was a stout defender of the Senate's constitutional role. He played a key role in this Parliament in advocating the allocation of greater resources, especially by the private sector, to industrial research and development, particularly while Chairman and Deputy Chairman of what was then the Senate Standing Committee on Science, Technology and the Environment. I understand that his services as resident optometrist will be sorely missed by aging senators and members. In conclusion, I thank the staff of the Senate for the assistance they have extended to me on my return to Parliament. They have ensured that the transition back into parliamentary life has been smooth. I also thank the Senate for the courtesy it has extended in hearing me and trust that my remarks did not transgress the traditions by being unduly provocative.

SPEECH.SPEAKER: Panizza Sen J.H.

TALK.START.PARA: —As I rise to talk to this chamber for the first time, I ask you, Mr Deputy President, to pass on to the President my congratulations on his re-election. I also congratulate you, Mr Deputy President, on your re-election. I would like to thank the Clerk of the Senate, the Usher of the Black Rod and everyone else for the welcome and kindness extended to all honourable senators who come here for the first time. I also thank you, Mr Deputy President, for the courtesy you have asked to be extended to me regarding my maiden speech. I will try not to be too controversial but, should I go over those bounds, I invite those senators on the other side of the chamber to feel free to interject. I hasten to say that I am mainly extending that offer to new senators on the other side.

SPEECH.PARA: I wish to thank the Liberal Party of Western Australia for the opportunity for me to realise the ambition I have had since I was 20 years old-to be elected to this chamber. My interest in the Senate probably arose when I studied Latin history, the Roman senate and so on. And a double dissolution sometime during the 1950s really showed where the ultimate power was. I certainly knew then that this was the place to get to. We had great politicians in the past who enkindled my ideas. I refer to Sir Robert Menzies, and Sir Charles Court from Western Australia.

Before I got here I had a lot of other missions to carry out along the way: helping to consolidate a family business; an extensive interest in industry affairs; raising a family; educating a family; and being involved in local government for 12 years. I also believe that a man must show that he can manage his own affairs and preferably risk his own dollar before offering himself for higher office and thereby shaping the future of other people.

Just two years ago I was approached by the Liberal Party of Australia to be a candidate for a seat in the upper House of Western Australia. The point was that that seat had been held by the same person, a member of the National Party of Australia, for 24 years and he was popular everywhere, or he thought he was. I took on the seat because no one else was game to be led to the slaughter. However, as I have always stood for free enterprise and as the inland areas of Western Australia had been getting a hiding from successive governments, I decided to give it a go. History shows that after only three weeks of campaigning and 18,000 kilometres on my speedometer I finished up about 115 votes short. The previous member was elected and I was not.

It was suggested by party supporters that I should then look at the Senate. When the time came I nominated and I was lucky enough to finish up with No. 3. My joy was short lived because along came a double dissolution. Despite the fact that Western Australia already had five Liberal senators, the Party was of the opinion that we could get six up. At this stage Senator Withers decided to retire. I must pay tribute to the great work that he did in this chamber for Western Australia. In case anyone is wondering how he is enjoying his retirement, he is not. That means that he has not retired. He has returned to the Bar in Perth and, no doubt, extends his regards to everyone who is still here.

At the second preselection I was given the No. 5 spot, which was almost an assurance of election. At that election the Western Australian team consisted of Senator Durack, Senator Chaney, Senator Crichton-Browne, Senator Knowles, Dr Alan Eggleston and young Cam Tinley and me and I consider that to be the most balanced Liberal team that has ever fronted up for Western Australia. I pay tribute to Dr Alan Eggleston and young Cam Tinley, who fought such a great campaign and did not get here. Anyone who does not know Dr Eggleston will get to know him after the next Federal election because he will be here then. As I have said, he is a doctor of medicine and is an institution in the north-west. He does all the other things that one has to do to keep the north-west going and takes an interest in the Royal Flying Doctor Service. He is not very tall. Every time he goes up to a microphone he has to stand on a box. But when honourable senators have the pleasure of meeting him they will know what he is all about.

Generally, at about this stage in a maiden speech, it seems to be quite usual for one to mention the tie that one is wearing or the lack of a tie. I decided to wear my old boys tie today. I am an old boy of a college in Perth called the Aquinas which has turned out many good politicians. There were three old boys in the Liberal Senate team-Senator Chaney, Senator Durack and me. I am very proud to have been associated with that college. The college I am talking about is probably a little more famous than Perth Modern School, which turned out so many politicians, including Senator Stone.

Today my main theme leans towards the importance and future needs of the Western Australian country areas-more precisely, the industries and the people involved in agriculture, mining and fishing in our great State. The agricultural areas are vast and varied and are mainly covered by part of the division of Kalgoorlie, the division of O'Connor, which honourable senators have all heard of, the division of Forrest, and parts of the divisions of Brand and Moore. The main activities are wheat growing, sheep and wool, and cattle, both beef and diary. I consider that there is still a future for the wheat growing industry even though we have had downward pressure as a result of the United States of America subsidising sales to Russia. Mr Acting Deputy President, we do not need a parliamentary deputation to go to America at our expense to tell us that that is the reason why prices are down. We know this. On the visit I made last year to the European Common Market I found that people were blaming the Americans anyhow. Furthermore, I was informed and I worked it out for myself that Europe, having seen starvation during the war, was not going to be caught again.

We have to solve our own problems. Alleviation of upward pressures on import costs is a top priority. We should remove such impositions as all duties on fuel used for farm production and transport of produce. Let Australia buy superphosphate at world prices and remove tariffs from imported chemicals and items of plant that are not manufactured in Australia. We should make government railways compete on the open market and do away with the inefficiencies, in all transport, perpetuated by outmoded regulations. We should put into action any positive recommendations of the royal commission into grain handling and we should look at the notoriously inefficient and unreliable waterfront. Because of the up and down nature of the seasons in Australia, we have had in the past a balancing system-income equalisation deposits. Somehow, one way or another, they have disappeared. It is far better to use this system to overcome problems than for governments to have to contribute to relief measures for drought, fire and floods.

Management, both financial and on-farm, is of the utmost importance and this has to be built into our education system at all levels. The importance of Western Australian's agricultural industry is borne out by these figures: Western Australia produces about 28 per cent of Australia's wheat, 21 per cent of Australia's wool clip and 9.2 per cent of its meat products. In total, Western Australia accounts for some 15 per cent of all Australia's agricultural products of $16.7 billion. This is despite the fact that we employ only 12.3 per cent of the 390,000 men and women working in agriculture and industries supplying the agriculture industry. This is quite an achievement, bearing in mind that our soil types are below those of the rest of Australia. The wool industry seems to be going through a high phase-this was certainly recognised in the Budget-with the market having peaked and retracted to some 12 per cent in the last few weeks. I consider that the growers are getting paid only what they should have been paid over the last few years but for the devalued dollar. There is a future in wool because, if overseas processors are paying only what they are supposed to be paying, bearing in mind the devaluation, I cannot see them going back to synthetics, especially with the oil prices starting to move again.

The meat trade has taken a battering this year because of the pesticide scare. Any danger to health because of tainted meat should be of major concern and everything should be done to clear our name. The industry has asked for help and it should be helped to rectify the situation. I cannot live with replies such as, `Taxpayers' money cannot be used for this purpose'. Farmers are not the only ones who pay tax and they are not the only ones who benefit from the meat. Of every dollar that comes in from meat the producer gets 48 1/2c, the abattoir gets about 2 1/2c, the retailer gets 43c, the transporter gets about 2c, the agent gets about 3c and the Government gets 1.4c. So it does not all go to the farmer. There must be more research into soil testing and on-farm testing of cattle and sheep in suspected areas before they go to the abattoirs. It is too late when they go down the chute.

As I have already said, the pesticide scare is not a problem solely for the farmer. The responsibility must be shared by manufacturers, by State governments, which gave approval for the use of pesticides, and by the Federal Government, which got tariff revenue from them in the past. The main problem that has to be overcome is the perceived disadvantage. Of probably half a million pieces of meat that go overseas one or two might be picked up as tainted. That is used as an excuse to downgrade all our meat, especially in price.

I now turn to the mining industry. It generates 60 per cent of exports from Western Australia. It is facing a growing list of problems despite an exceptionally strong performance by some sectors. Minerals and processed minerals worth some $5.4 billion were produced in Western Australia during 1986. This was achieved by increases in output of most major commodities in the face of falling world prices. The international metal price index was down 11 per cent on the previous year. The weaker Australian dollar compensated to a certain extent for that fall but it also increased costs and the net result was another year of inadequate profits. The outlook is for more of the same. The major exception is the gold section of the industry, which is currently going through a high in terms of Australian dollar prices. This industry sector has increased annual revenue in Western Australia from $150m to $1,000m during the last five years.

There have been noises in this place and others that a gold tax should be introduced. I would like honourable senators to hear the situation from one who lives right amongst the people involved. I live in Western Australia exactly where agriculture finishes and gold mining starts. A small town Marvel Loch, which, three years ago had 30 people in it now has 1,000 people in it. The gold mining industry distributes money for supplies in country towns that were relying on agriculture, the profitability of which has gone down slightly. In such circumstances no one would dare impose such a tax. After all, the gold tax would be paid only by the very core, whereas all those who surround the industry generate wealth which is taxed and the tax paid to the Federal Government.

Future return on investment in the industry is a major concern. During 1986 return on capital invested in the mining industries was less than 5 per cent and the average return over the last six years was only 6 per cent. New capital can be attracted to these areas only if there is a return on the money. The substantial contribution of the export earnings of the industry to underpinning the living standards of all Australians can no longer be assured. Future growth in mineral revenue lies in processing from the raw state to give added value, and this requires new investment. But with the present economic conditions, I cannot see this occurring. The potential value added production can be seen in sections of Western Australian mining such as mineral sands where high commodity prices counter the local adverse conditions. This has encouraged a total investment of $200m in mineral sands production capacity during the last year, including two synthetic rutile plants. Further downstream, processing projects in an advanced stage of planning have the potential to add in excess of $300m per annum in export earnings to the State.

The diamond industry also continues to develop opportunities in added value activities. This has taken place against a backdrop of major long term investment in the North West Shelf which brings with it potentially unlimited downstream processing spin-off benefits. It disguises the fact that, by value, some 70 per cent of the State's mineral production is experiencing severe difficulties from reduced market opportunities, falling international prices and rising domestic costs. Major industry sectors affected include iron, nickel and alumina. Add to this the problems in the energy side of the industry caused by the State Energy Commission's large surplus of gas and it is obvious that a significant part of Western Australia's productive capacity is under threat. Western Australia's opportunities lie in developing further processing industries based on primary commodities. That potential can be realised by the siting of new industries in Western Australia, such as the alumina smelter, et cetera. The future of Western Australian mining lies in being able to reduce costs and to increase sales levels in an increasingly competitive world.

I now turn to access to land, which is certainly a major issue for the minerals industry. It cannot expand without viable and successful exploration. Making land unavailable for exploration through the creation of restrictions of any kind threatens the future of the industry. The mining industry is not against the creation of national parks, nature reserves, forestry reserves and other classifications which isolate the use of the land for single purposes, but it must have access to be able to explore to see what is the real cost of providing such reserves. In areas such as Kakadu National Park the Federal Government has supported access for studies on Aboriginal and natural issues while denying the mining industry the same right. Australia's existing mines have a limited life and exploration for new mineral deposits is essential to ensure that mining continues.

The mining industry in Western Australia views with alarm the amazing degree of concern by the Federal Government for the demands of a very small, vocal section of the conservation movement while it is more and more indifferent to the fate of Australia's export industries. Government policy needs to ensure that the potential of the mining industry is realised. Briefly, the issues to be kept in mind are: minimise costs imposed by government; ensure tariff protection does not push up the cost of major goods and equipment in the production of primary products; support from Austrade; the Government be prepared to take an active interest in dealings with other countries, as in the case of the selling of coal to India.

Western Australia has a large fishing industry involving rock lobsters, tuna and prawns. It is going through a rationalisation phase, which has caused a lot of fishing in areas which would not normally be fished. We hope to see more areas opened up in future. It is important that government grants for export market development and research be maintained so that they assist the ongoing development of the fishing industry in general.

Mr Deputy President, I think I have shown you from the figures I have cited and the statements I have made that the country areas of Australia are in fact carrying Australia. We are fast getting back on to the sheep's back. This year, when the value of wool exports passes the value of coal exports, we will really be back on the sheep's back. Primary producers do not mind this, but we have to be helped so we can help ourselves. Primary products account for 85.3 per cent of Australia's exports but only 8 per cent of the population is involved in primary industry.

So far I have spoken only on the industries of Western Australia; I turn to the people who make up the vast State, from the edge of the cities into the north. Some live in big provincial towns and some in small ones. One of the main drawbacks in living in country areas is education. It should be the right of every child to receive an education up to tertiary level, no matter where he lives. Should country children wish to attend a university or a college of advanced education their families should not have to mortgage themselves or go overboard to allow this; they should have the same opportunities as children in the cities.

There are great water deficiencies in the towns of Western Australia. There are the standard facilities of bitumen roads, electricity, television and so on, but water supplies are sub-standard. Western Australia probably led the world in pumping water into isolated areas in the early 1900s with C.Y. O'Connor's scheme, but I am afraid that that progress was not maintained. I know that there was a suggestion from a Western Australian Minister, Mr Ernie Bridge, concerning the use of a scheme like the Australian bicentennial road development program to do something about that water problem. I urge the Government to support such a scheme.

Local government plays a big part in country regions of Western Australia. Mr President, as you know, there are three tiers of government in Australia. I consider that local government is the nearest to the people and that for that reason it should be supported. I was very disappointed two years ago when local government's 2 per cent share of personal income tax funding was reduced. I thought that, with the numbers of former local government politicians in the Federal Parliament, local government would be looked after.

I would like now to deal with ethnic affairs. I would be remiss if I did not mention that. One thing I will always remember is where I came from. I am the son of Italian migrants. One must put on record the important contribution made to this country by such people. I refer to those who came before and after the First World War, those who came after the Second World War and those who came after the Vietnam War. They came from countries such as Italy, Yugoslavia, Portugal, Greece and Spain. They came from Holland, Germany and a host of other countries. They came to work in the outback. They came to cut sleepers in Queensland, clear bush in the wheat belts of Australia and work in the Port Pirie smelters and in asbestos mines. Their women, who came after, followed them into these harsh conditions.

My own father came off a ship in South Australia. There were no welcoming committees in those days. There was no one to find work for these people. They relied on the goodness of organisations such as the Salvation Army, which met them and got them jobs in the country. My father finished up in Broken Hill at the 2,600 feet level. After that he went to Queensland and to Western Australia. These people worked to start a new life and to give their children an opportunity to make it in this country-an opportunity they never had in their former countries.

Around Australia are examples of the children of those migrants who have risen to the top. They have reached the top of the professions, business and trades and local government, and some have even come to the Parliament. Those migrants were not always welcome. There was a lot of discrimination and they met with hostility. If the Aboriginal people feel that they are still discriminated against-I know they are-they have my sympathy, because I know what it is like.

Mr President, I mention all these things to show that honourable senators opposite are not the only ones who have worked with their hands. Some senators on this side of the House have done so too. Not all farmers were born with a silver spoon in their mouth, although a few eminent farmers may have been. If my children and the children of other farmers become well off it will be because their parents-and nobody else-have worked and provided for them.

According to my research, we have for the first time in this Parliament two members, born either in this country or in Italy, of full Italian parentage. One member is Mr Sciacca, a Queensland member of the House of Representatives. I thank him for coming to the Senate tonight to listen to my speech. Even though he is on the other side of the political fence, I congratulate him on his election. I am humble and proud on behalf of all Italian migrants to have achieved the honour of being the first person of Italian parentage to be elected to the Senate.

As we move to the celebration of Australia's 200th anniversary I express the hope that we can at last be one nation, whether our skin happens to be green, yellow, black or white and whether we are descended from the convicts, the aristocracy, the Aboriginals or European migrants. Hopefully we can be one people under the same flag which, amongst other things, carries the emblem of the Southern Cross. That is my home town.

I have always believed that the Senate should be a House of review and a protector of the States, and in my stay here I will always treat it in that way. I thank members of my family, both immediate and extended, for the help and encouragement they gave me to get here. In a large family partnership such as ours there is much give and take in order to let each partner achieve his or her ambitions. I hope that my time spent here will be of benefit not only to the party that put me here but also to the mighty State of Western Australia.

TALK.START.PARA: —I want tonight to raise a matter that is of some concern to me. It was brought to my notice by the auxiliary of the Blind Society of the Australian Capital Territory, which has organised a function to be held at the Albert Hall on 24 October-next Saturday. This auxiliary has worked very hard for a long time for this very important money raising function, which is to be a cavalcade of historic fashion presented by the Sydney North Shore Cavalcade Group. The auxiliary made the arrangements more than 12 months ago. At that time, on 5 September 1986, it set about making a booking with the Albert Hall, which was to cost $18 per hour to hire. A deposit of $50 was paid at that time. Since then the fee has risen-this is not specially relevant to the story but it is relevant to the auxiliary's finances-to $26 per hour. The auxiliary was instructed to confirm the booking by phone on 2 September 1987-some 12 months later.

SPEECH.PARA: On that date, and not before, the auxiliary was told that it would need a licence to serve supper in the premises. It applied for a licence on 9 September by filling in a form obtained from the health surveillance centre in Curtin. Some three weeks went by and no licence was received. This caused the women of the auxiliary some concern. They started to make their food and to prepare for the occasion. They now have much food stored in fridges and freezers for the supper. On 15 October, still not having received the licence, the treasurer called at the Curtin office to collect it and was told that it would be issued on the day of the function. However, she was told, also for the first time, that they were not to serve home cooked food and had the options of cancelling the supper arrangements, preparing food at the hall or buying commercial food. This, of course, has caused considerable hardship to members of the organisation who, as I said, have already done the cooking for their supper. They contacted the department which issued the catering licences, and were told that these conditions did apply, even though they had not been so informed at the time the reservation was made. I have a copy of the form relating to the reservation and the bookings. I have read through the general conditions and find that there is no mention of this particular regulation.

One of my members of staff contacted an officer of the Australian Capital Territory Health Authority and spoke to him, even asking on what date the regulations came in. She was not impressed with the response which was, first, laughter, then whistling and then the reply that the regulation had applied since 1930. My staff member reports to me that the officer was rude and unhelpful and had stated that it was for the sake of the public health that a licence had to be issued.

No one is arguing that public health is not important. It may be that this regulation has been in existence since 1930, but I can assure you, Mr President, that I know of functions held at the Albert Hall for which a substantial amount of the food has been prepared before and brought to the place by the organisation concerned. In fact, Mr President, I invite you to inspect the cooking facilities at the Albert Hall where you will see that there would be no possibility of putting on any substantial function using the facilities there, as they have not been upgraded for a very long time.

The impact of this is quite significant for members of the Blind Society. They have had to leave in the freezer the food that they prepared and make arrangements for commercial food to be brought in, which will significantly affect the profit that they will be able to make. It seems extraordinary to me that we cannot have arrangements whereby people using this hall can bring their own food. It seems extraordinary to me that they should be told of this decision just a matter of a few weeks before the function and not at the time they made the reservation for the hall in September 1986.

I hope that the Minister on duty, Senator Gareth Evans, will bring this matter to the attention of the people in the relevant department with a view to seeing that facilities like the Albert Hall are available in a meaningful way for people in Canberra and that regulations will allow people to serve on the premises food that they have prepared. They should be able to use the hall for the sort of function that it is meant to be used for-facilitating the raising of funds in this community. I am appalled at the way in which this matter has been handled and at the way this organisation has been treated. I hope that it will not happen again.
